story:
Our Story

We are a co-operative of Equity artists in Ottawa who have come together because of a terrific opportunity: the chance to perform a brilliant adaption of Henry James' "The Turn of the Screw" inside a haunted landmark during the Hallowe'en season -- including Hallowe'en night itself!


It will be pitch black in the house after dark.  The audience will enter through the front door and make their way up to the second-floor landing, where they will take their seats.  Out of the gloom, two spirits will emerge to tell the tale of a governess who took on the job of looking after two orphaned children, and ended up defending them against two malevolent spirits bent on their corruption.  "It is a tale of terror... and horror... and death," intones one of the spirits.  "It made my very heart stop."


We will be performing the play inside the historic former home of two Canadian Prime Ministers -- Wilfrid Laurier and William Lyon Mackenzie King.  Sir Laurier passed away mere feet from the area the play will be staged.  Prime Minister King was a dedicated spiritualist of who conducted seances directly above the area where the audience will sit.  These days, lights in the upstairs room turn themselves on.  A presence can be felt throughout the home, and one staff member refused to return to the house after a single night there.


The tradition of site-specific theatre is young in Ottawa, and this is a perfect opportunity to bring this visceral style of theatre to the nation's capital.


The Impact

Unlike many theatre projects, this production isn't being created by a company.  We are simply a collective of like-minded artists who fell in love with a play, and found a terrific way to present it.  This means we have no operating funding, and limited resources.  We are doing big things without much money.  It's risky, but the up-side of that is that it won't take much fundraising to make this project everything it could be.


We are committed to giving audiences an intimate and powerful experience.  Our staging limits our audience size to 30 patrons at a time, which seriously impacts our ability to recover costs.  It's risky, but we believe it's worth it or we wouldn't be working so hard to make it happen.


Theatre companies that program more than one show per season are not likely to attempt an experiment like this, due to its limited scale; and yet this production gives us an opportunity to create a piece of theatre of the sort that is rarely seen in Ottawa. Take an ideal venue; pair it with an incredible adaptation of a classic ghost story, and some of Ottawa’s most in-demand theatre artists, and you have a recipe for something truly special.


What We Need

Every effort is being made to keep production costs low for The Turn of the Screw. The site-specific nature of our production reduces overhead in many areas, but we still need help. From our budget, our largest-ticket expense items are as follows:

• Venue staffing and rental: $2500

• Script royalties and rights: $800

• Insurance costs: $500

• Costumes and props: $400

• Venue seating: $350


More about us

The core members of our groups have decades of combined experience in the performing arts.  They are working regularly on stages across the country, and have all worked successfully as theatre producers in the past.  Here are just a few highlights:

• Patrick Gauthier (director) holds his MFA in directing from the University of British Columbia, and is the recipient of the 2010 Council for the Arts in Ottawa RBC Emerging Artist Award;

• Kris Joseph (actor) is a past member of Canada's National Arts Centre’s resident acting company and a multiple Rideau Awards nominee and recipient (one of which he shares with Patrick Gauthier);

• Kate Smith (actor) is the 2009 Zonta Arts Award recipient;

• Jane Vanstone Osborn (stage manager) brings 25 years of experience to the table, including seasons at the National Arts Centre and the internationally-renowned Shaw Festival; and

• Sarah Waghorn (designer) is a giften multi-disciplinary designer who holds more awards nominations and wins than can be listed in this space.

All of the artists working on this project are part of a co-operative approved by the Canadian Actors’ Equity Association.

For full bios and photos for all of our artists, please see: http://turnofthescrew.ca/artists/

story:
Hi there!

We're Cinderella Renegade Productions, an independent theatre company in Brisbane, Australia. From left to right in our photo, we are Sharmanee, Sam, Jay, Mitch and Andy.

Cinderella Renegade Productions is Jay's baby, and everyone is helping Jay make her baby grow. Shar, Sam, and Jay all study screen and stage acting together, while Mitch and Andy were roped in through the audition process. We're all under 25 and very passionate about creating quality theatre entertainment. Getting help from the public will really help get our first show on the road.
Spread between us all we have 14 years of dance experience, almost 10 years of acting experience and several years of singing and saxophone experience.



What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

We're hoping to raise $3,000 to go towards our first two shows. The first; a variety show called "Can You See Us Now?", which is all about showing the people who doubt us that we ARE talented and we CAN make it in the industry, and will be closed by punk band Goon on the Rocks. The second; an abstract bastardized physical theatre piece called "Heartsease", which is about a patisserie chef discovering the world for the first time.

 FREE STUFF!
If you donate you could receive a free shirt, drinks, tickets and supporting credits!
 The funds from this raiser would go towards our next show's props, venue fees, and paying our actors for their time.

The Impact

For Shar, Mitch, Sam and Jay, getting Cinderella Renegade off the ground would be the launching of their careers, Shar, Mitch and Sam as actors and Jay as a director. They have dreams of Broadway and Hollywood, and have been dreaming about Oscars and Helpman's since day dot.  And Andy? Well he's just a brilliant guy along for the ride :)
We hope to build our company into something that isn't as elitist and overbearing as a normal theatre company.  Segregation and judging people based on their experience is not what we do. We've found that even the most unexperienced baby giraffe can come up with something brilliant and pull it off. Art is in everyone. Ours just happens to be our future career and dream. To create is to live; so please help give us life!


“Write it. Shoot it. Publish it. Crochet it, sauté it, whatever. MAKE.”  ― Joss Whedon


Other Ways You Can Help

We all know what it's like to be excited about something but having no money to contribute. It sucks, but you can still help us out! By liking/sharing our Facebook page, or using the Indiegogo share tools!
Like Cinderella Renegade on Facebook!

We apologize for the inconvenience, and appreciate your patience and support. Thanks!

story:
Hi!  My name is Gloria Makino, and I'm a mixed-race female writer.  I need your help to fund my new musical, UNTURNING, an adaptation of Thomas Hardy's novel THE RETURN OF THE NATIVE.  It tells the story of a mixed-race young woman caught at the center of a love triangle inflamed by social prejudice, racial bias and family pressures.

UNTURNING has already been selected by 4 new works programs that believe in the show enough to donate their theaters!-- but I need your help raising the funds to cover the other production costs, such as hiring professional actors & musicians and covering expenses for costumes, props, publicity ... Producing theater is expensive, but UNTURNING is worth it, because this show combines the best of drama, music, dance, classic literature and ever-relevant social justice issues into one powerful show.

Thank you for helping fund UNTURNING!  Keep in touch at facebook.com/Unturning for more information about upcoming performances-- with your help, this show can go far ...

story:
Short Summary

This past fall, an ensemble of graduate and undergraduate students in the UMass Theater Department collaborated on a production of Jackie Sibblies Drury’s powerful play, We Are Proud to Present a Presentation About the Herero of Namibia, Formerly Known as Southwest Africa, from the German Sudwestafrika, Between the Years 1884-1915.   Performing to sold-out audiences and inspiring transformational talkback sessions after each show, our ensemble was invited to re-mount our production for a 3-week performance run at UMass in February 2016 invited to present our work at the National Arts Festival in Grahamstown, South Africa, in July 2016.  


Both humorous and harrowing, We Are Proud to Present portrays an ensemble of actors who are creating a work of theater about the little-known first genocide of the 20th century. As the actors wrestle with challenges of representation and encounter their own biases, they realize that the racial dynamics in the play hit very close to home.


Our production of We Are Proud to Present was recently accepted into the National Arts Festival in Grahamstown, South Africa, happening between June 30th-July 10th, 2016.  The Grahamstown festival is the largest arts festival in the southern hemisphere and the second largest theatre festival in the world (outside Edinburgh in Scotland).  We are incredibly excited about the opportunity to share our work with an international audience and to learn more about the culture and history of South Africa.  


As part of this experience, we are also taking part in a UMass summer study abroad program that happens in Grahamstown and Johannesburg.  The course is designed to study the performing arts as a lens through which to examine questions of social justice, race, class and gender politics, history, language, memory, and the role of arts in our global world.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $25,000 to help us fund our trip to South Africa.  This money will go to funding airfare for the 11 members of our ensemble and a portion of our tuition payments for the course.  


  • Roundtrip airfare of $1300 for 11 students = $14,300

  • $1000 toward tuition payments of $2650 each for 11 students = $11,000


Our total expenses required for this trip are $5000 per student.  We also need to secure rights to the play and manage the transport and rental of props. We will need $56,000 to fund this project. This Indiegogo funding request allows us to offset most of our travel expenses and a small portion of our tuition for the UMass summer study abroad course.  By taking the course we will develop a stronger understanding of the cultural context in which we are performing and be able to more fully engage with the other performances at the Festival.  This is a truly extraordinary opportunity for us.

The Impact

When we presented our production in early December, we sold out for each show. We invited audiences to remain for talkback discussions after each performance, and each night, audience members thanked us profusely and emotionally for presenting this play.

During talkbacks, we witnessed our audience members process experiences of catharsis, of connection, of realizations about race, and for some, their own privileges.  

We look forward to sharing our work with South African audiences and entering into dialogue about race and identity with members of a country that not only shares history with Namibia but also shares parallels of racial tensions with the United States.  We hope that this international dialogue about race will support audience members and our own cast in expanding our understanding about race, representation, and ultimately lead to further work against racism in our home nations.

Risks & Challenges

Even in trying to raise less than half of what we need, we realize that we have an ambitious fundraising goal.  However, we created our December despite many challenges and obstacles and we were determined to make the strongest work we could.  Our determination and perseverance despite many personal, financial, and time obstacles culminated in a fierce and powerful work that united our ensemble.


We are prepared and ready to meet the fundraising challenges that lie ahead and we are determined to go to South Africa.  In addition to our Indiegogo campaign, we are contributing personal savings, we are requesting for financial support from the Dean of the College of Fine Arts and Humanities, we are applying for private scholarships, and we are planning various fundraisers on campus.  With your support, we believe we can make this trip of a lifetime happen.


Other Ways You Can Help

No contribution to this endeavor is too small.  If you are not personally able to contribute but can help us get the word out via your Facebook, Twitter, etc., we would greatly appreciate the help.

Thank you!

story:
What is "DADDY"?

¸¸.•*¨*•♫ All proceeds from this fundraiser will go to directly to the production and theater fees of making "Daddy" a reality! This supernatural, sexy and hilarious theater phenomena will arrive this Winter to a NYC stage near you! Stay tuned! ♫•*¨*•.¸¸

Honi Harlow, the NYC burlesque queen, dancer, actress and writer, wrote the script in early 2013 "DADDY" and decided to bring together her closest and most talented friends to make it a reality on stage! 

Honi Harlow, Mistress La Morta, Lady Zombie and Mistress Sasha star as vampire women from several different eras (created by the same vampire) - a Southern Belle, a Hippie, an 80's rocker, and one we're just not so sure about. They struggle to cohabitate, dealing with varying issues from where their next bloody meal will come from, to unusual sexual desires, dealing with the men in their lives, and the repercussions of their (often poor) choices. 

The cast is joined by guest stars Marilyn Mansfield (the Midwife) and Zoth Ommog (Herr Doctor). Our stage manager is Veronyka Herring, and our stylist is Scarlett Cruz. 

What We Need & What You Get

We held a successful fundraiser at "Zombiesque" on September 28th, and now we need a little more help from all of you! All donations received will go towards costumes, props, printing, theater and technical feels. 

We have come up with several awesome perks to thank you for your donations on this campaign!

Ways You Can Help

  • Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help: Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign with the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Help us exceed our fund-raising goal by donating NOW!

Email theladyzombie@gmail.com or honiharlow@gmail.com to learn more and find out other ways you can help!

story:
Our Problem: What We Need

We already have a lot of passion for this, true. But we also need the tangibles to put this production together. In fact, we have already had one cmapaign that was successful! In addition to our upcoming live Improv Game Night, and Meet N Greet events at Hamburger Marys, Faultine, and the Eagle, there are still some costs that will not be covered:

Uniforms

To make an amazing show we need amazing uniforms!  Custom made full-experience Baseball uniforms for the entire cast will set us back an additional $825. 

Getting the Word Out

Finally, after all this hard work, we want people to know about it! We need to pay for publicity. We need to print the playbills and advertisements. We need to pay our publicist, who works hard calling media outlets and shooting off emails all day long. This will be $500. 

Our Goal: Promote Love

We want to relearn how to have successful relationships and communications, and we hope our experiences will inspire our community and, by extension, the world.


Plus One Productions: Our Point of View

For many years, the Los Angles theatre scene has been missing something: the "POP" that audiences feel when attending a performance in New York. Well, that is about to change - as we bring theatre to you - in intimate, ways, that only Plus One Productions and Black Box theatre can do - Plus One Production's marries brash vision and passion with critically acclaimed plays. We are confidant that we will impress audiences throughout our first season and show what a fledgling theatre company can do with little more than heart, guts, and passion.  We aim high, and we've never hesitated to pull out the stops and dig into the passion, heart, and pain that inhabit the world of theatre and drama and we are kicking this all of with Richard Greenberg's TAKE ME OUT - a dark, and often disturbing, real look at relationships and the sportsworld - two of the greatest things known to man. It is achingly real what Take Me Out accomplishes in our heart, mind, and thoughts in just three hours.

Our Project: "Take Me Out"

When star player, and league MVP Darren Lemming holds a press conference - he has big news.   Hes a practicing homosexual, yes he is Gay.  When Darren holds this press conference - he automatically assumes everyone will be okay with it - but they are not. "Take Me Out" follows 11 baseball players on the New York Empires, as they in-brace a journey to bring a 3-peat Word Series title to the great state of New York.   Of course, nothing is at it seems, for these 11 guys try to find themselves, and their purpose in life through dysfunctional relationships. The play is about the struggles harbored in the human heart between fear and love, between faith in our insecurities or faith in ourselves, between succumbing to dysfunction or rising above pain caused by ourselves and others .Why do we hurt others and ourselves in our quest for relationships and love? Take Me Out is a play full of pain, hatred, desire, and fear; bravely marching deep into the heart of darkness in order find that acceptance and understanding we all seek to have within ourselves - and fan it to a full-blown fire that's big enough to encompass our entire lives. Good drama mirrors real-life human issues, and this play tackles what it means to fear and what it means to love; and is super relevant as this summer we had our first two professional athletes take the brave step in declaring their homosexuality to their teammates and the world. 


What Else YOU Can Do!

We will be having some Meet N Greets in the community, and improv show, a fundraiser, and even a Karaoke night! Details will be announced soon on wach one of these. Come to the play! Come to the improv fundraisers! Tell your friends!  Help us get the word out about both this campaign and this production. Connect with us on social media!

Spread the word and remember, relationships keep us human.

Thanks for your support, and donation; we look forward to meeting you at the show!
story_txt:
Our Problem: What We Need
We already have a lot of passion for this, true. But we also need the tangibles to put this production together. In fact, we have already had one cmapaign that was successful! In addition to our upcoming live Improv Game Night, and Meet N Greet events at Hamburger Marys, Faultine, and the Eagle, there are still some costs that will not be covered:
Uniforms
To make an amazing show we need amazing uniforms!  Custom made full-experience Baseball uniforms for the entire cast will set us back an additional $825. Getting the Word OutFinally, after all this hard work, we want people to know about it! We need to pay for publicity. We need to print the playbills and advertisements. We need to pay our publicist, who works hard calling media outlets and shooting off emails all day long. This will be $500. Our Goal: Promote LoveWe want to relearn how to have successful relationships and communications, and we hope our experiences will inspire our community and, by extension, the world.Plus One Productions: Our Point of ViewFor many years, the Los Angles theatre scene has been missing something: the "POP" that audiences feel when attending a performance in New York. Well, that is about to change - as we bring theatre to you - in intimate, ways, that only Plus One Productions and Black Box theatre can do - Plus One Production's marries brash vision and passion with critically acclaimed plays. We are confidant that we will impress audiences throughout our first season and show what a fledgling theatre company can do with little more than heart, guts, and passion.  We aim high, and we've never hesitated to pull out the stops and dig into the passion, heart, and pain that inhabit the world of theatre and drama and we are kicking this all of with Richard Greenberg's TAKE ME OUT - a dark, and often disturbing, real look at relationships and the sportsworld - two of the greatest things known to man. It is achingly real what Take Me Out accomplishes in our heart, mind, and thoughts in just three hours.Our Project: "Take Me Out"When star player, and league MVP Darren Lemming holds a press conference - he has big news.   Hes a practicing homosexual, yes he is Gay.  When Darren holds this press conference - he automatically assumes everyone will be okay with it - but they are not. "Take Me Out" follows 11 baseball players on the New York Empires, as they in-brace a journey to bring a 3-peat Word Series title to the great state of New York.   Of course, nothing is at it seems, for these 11 guys try to find themselves, and their purpose in life through dysfunctional relationships. The play is about the struggles harbored in the human heart between fear and love, between faith in our insecurities or faith in ourselves, between succumbing to dysfunction or rising above pain caused by ourselves and others .Why do we hurt others and ourselves in our quest for relationships and love? Take Me Out is a play full of pain, hatred, desire, and fear; bravely marching deep into the heart of darkness in order find that acceptance and understanding we all seek to have within ourselves - and fan it to a full-blown fire that's big enough to encompass our entire lives. Good drama mirrors real-life human issues, and this play tackles what it means to fear and what it means to love; and is super relevant as this summer we had our first two professional athletes take the brave step in declaring their homosexuality to their teammates and the world. What Else YOU Can Do!We will be having some Meet N Greets in the community, and improv show, a fundraiser, and even a Karaoke night! Details will be announced soon on wach one of these. Come to the play! Come to the improv fundraisers! Tell your friends!  Help us get the word out about both this campaign and this production. Connect with us on social media!Spread the word and remember, relationships keep us human.Thanks for your support, and donation; we look forward to meeting you at the show!

story:
Short Summary

 

Did you know carnaval parades in Rio de Janeiro actually tell stories?

And that these stories are usually absurd, humorous and abstract?

 

I'm Anzolin Borges, I'm an AMDA graduate. I have also studied playwriting and acting at Harvard and with well known teachers such as Howard Fine, Larry Moss and Susan Batson.

I have a show that will let you see a side of Brazilian carnaval you have never seen before and will make you laugh your heads off along the way!

I have been working on SOS! since 2008 and this show is a pure celebration of Shakespeare, samba and the artist's journey!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds for costumes, music, sets, samba dancers and actors. This show is in Rio carnaval style format - as seen on the big parades. As you can imagine this is no small production. 

Those who help us will get "thank you" notes on our theater brochure and website, SOS! t-shirts, SOS! pins, SOS! postcards, SOS! posters, SOS! tickets, kisses from SOS! samba girls and many other surprises!

 

The Impact

Shakespeare On Samba! combines what carnaval does best: people from all walks of life and enlighten them with a samba story just like the ones Brazilians see in February. It's an artist's journey and all the elements and characters the make that journey unique to each artist.

I have been working on SOS! since 2008 and have great support from a lot of people but now I need yours. Help me present  to the American audience an spectacular experience that will make their hearts beat as if they were at the SambaDrome in Rio de Janeiro!

Other Ways You Can Help

Go to our website, like us FB, follow us on Twitter and Instagram, tell your friends about it. 

Get the word out!

story:
Hello, Mysterians!

For two years, we've performed the Sunday Night Mystery Show on a semi-monthly schedule. Since then, it has grown from a sober performance of a mostly coherent stageplay to a decidedly-not-sober battle with a heckling audience.

During that time, I've met new people, made new friends, had awkward experiences, and witnessed hilarious performances. Hopefully, you all feel the same.

For the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival, I have signed us up to do three performances, three Sundays in a row. Hopefully, not only will this introduce new people to the show, but it will be a good time for all of us. (And also, something to put on our CVs.)

So, why do an Indiegogo?

While the Fringe is a unique opportunity, it also comes with some unique costs, such as registration fees and a mandatory theater tech.

But I also want the show to be better than ever. I want to print huge posters and buy hilarious props, and I want to give a copy of the Spellbook to everyone who attends. (The new edition features pieces by Julie Pearson, Lauren Cannon, Juan Rubalcava, and hopefully Chai Hecht, among others!)

In addition, I want to expand the universe of the show by presenting a sister-show, Dan Donohue and Eric Siegel's The New Bad Boys of Magic (the Winner of the 2017 Mystie for Best Opening Act), and by hosting a Free Improv Class.

All of this will make the Show bigger and wilder, but it will also cost more money.

So I'm turning to you, faithful Mysterians. If you have enjoyed participating in the Sunday Night Mystery Show, either as a witness or a suspect, and you think the Hollywood Fringe Festival is a good next step, then please give your vote of support in the form of a small donation.

I set up the standard perks: $6 gets you an Executive Producer credit, $16 gets you a T-shirt, and $30 gets you VIP front-row seats to all three episodes, plus a ticket to Dan and Eric's comedy-magic show, The New Bad Boys of Magic.

For $66, we'll have a team of Mystery Sorcerers ready to perform a powerful magickal seance to grant you fame and fortune*.

Regardless of whether you donate, I want to thank you all so much for everything you have done for the show in the last two years. Performing each Mystery Show with each of you has been a wonderful experience I will never forget (unless I never remembered it in the first place). Thank you for being a part of it.

Sincerely,
Greg Karber

(*As with all magick, no guarantees.)

story:
What is The Prophecy? 

The Prophecy is a musical stage play that displays the life of Jesus from his miraculous birth to his betrayal and crucifixion:  

  • Written and Directed by Pastor Keith Powell
  • 23 original songs
  • A cast of more than 50 actors.
  • Broadway style  production.
  • The pages of the Bible come to life on stage. 

This production is more than a play; it is an experience!

The Director

Keithron (Keith) Powell, of Jacksonville, FL, is a writer, director, composer actor, choreographer and author. He as shared the stage with Yolanda Adams, Vickie Winans, William Murphy and others. 

What We Need

  • Set construction and costumes
  • Venue Rental.
  • Special Guest (cast member)
  • Sound equipment
  • Travel & lodging for special guest

The Impact Of The Show

The Prophecy has been a life changing event to those that have seen it in the past:

  • The first time this play was staged, in 2003, more than 4500 people experienced it and are still speaking of it today.
  • The soundtrack causes people to mentally view the Bible narratives.

Challenges

 A lack of funding has prevented us from moving forward. The total projected budget to produce this play is $86,000. The dwindling economy caused potential investors to place finances on hold for events of this type.

What We Are Doing to Offset Our Challenges

  • Investing what we can of our own resources into the play.
  • Begin working on this show in a very small segments to build public interest. 
  • Sell the CD soundtrack to generate capital for our long term goal for the show.
  • Working with local talent to get the show off of the ground.

story:
Please support and experience Stuart Meyers' On The Rocks at Studio 34 on June 24th and 26th at 7pm or 9pm!!

Who IS Stuart Meyers??

Stuart Meyers is a a new and emerging multi-disciplinary artist from the great Garden State bridging the gaps between dance, theatre, the visual arts and fabulosity For the months of April, May and June, he is working with Hybridge Arts Collective as a Blueprint Breakout Artist to produce his first evening length solo, On The Rocks!

New to Philadelphia, he is a recent graduate of Boston University’s School of Theatre where he earned his BFA in Theatre Arts with a minor in Dance.  Studying all over the place during undergrad, such as in Boston, France, Italy and at Connecticut College, Stuart began to craft his provocative dance theatre pieces and received great praise.  This past summer, after performing in a musical in Boston and a new play workshop in NYC, Stuart had the pleasure of apprenticing visionary theatre director Robert Wilson at The Watermill Center in the Hamptons.  Beginning his Philly life in mid-September, Stuart was a majestic moth in Mason and Megan’s Mining The Mine of The Mind For Minderals, performed in Darcy Lyons’ work in Group Motion’s Spiel Uhr and danced in Christopher William’s dance-opera Wolf-In-Skins.  Iterations of On The Rocks, Stuart's most recent solo work in-progress, has been shown at Boston University, Bates Dance Festival, The American College Dance Festival, The InHale Performance Series, The Watermill Center and most recently at the Judson Church in NYC.   Stuart is also sharing and selling his visual art on Etsy.  Check it out!: http://www.etsy.com/shop/StuartbArt

 

First, what the heck is On The Rocks?!  

On The Rocks is a new dance theatre experience performed and created by none other than Stuart Meyers.  A blurb about it:

A queer clown with a red bucket walks into a room and explodes it into a nightclub. He’s looking for lust, transcendence, and maybe even love. With a wink to the club kids, this fantasy unfolds like a feverish music video. But is this dream built to last? Prepare to be inebriated, disoriented and transported by On The Rocks.

Cool things Stuart will do in this piece:

- Dance with a red bucket

- Pour ice all over myself

- Make funny faces

- Butcher Voguing

- Cry

- Sing a little

- Walk in slow motion

- Fake Breakdancing

Best part!!: On The Rocks will be presented on June 24th and 25th at Broad St. Ministry in Philadelphia, PA as a part of Hybridge Art Collective's "Blueprint Breakout Series!"

 

Ok... So what is Hybridge Arts Collective?  

They're the group helping Stuart produce On The Rocks!  To give a bit more deatil:

"Hybridge Arts Collective presents original works created by emerging artists in Philadelphia.  Hybridge encourages audiences to discover a new generation of artists by offering affordable evenings of live performance. We bridge the gap between artists of varying disciplines by presenting them within the same program. These introductions create the opportunity for future collaborations and provide the artists with new resources. Hybridge is committed to producing accessible events that engage, connect and inspire." ~ hybridgearts.org

Basically they're awesome.

 

And what is the Blueprint Breakout Series??

The Blueprint Breakout Series is a residency and mentorship that helps young emerging artists like Stuart bring their creative dreams to life.  In their words:

"The Blueprint Breakout Series is a residency program curated by Hybridge Arts Collective and presented in collaboration with Broad Street Ministry. It is geared towards emerging artists with bold ideas for medium to full length works.  Hybridge partners with artists over 3 months as they create their piece. Hybridge offers feedback, guest mentors and technical support. At the end of the residency we produce a show on the last Monday and Tuesday of the 3rd month. A home cooked meal is served after the show as a part of low key community oriented feedback session." ~hybridgearts.org

A meal, a show at such a cheap price and an opportunity to see Stuart perform his OWN performance work...what else could you ask for???

 

Alright... Tell me dear... Why is On The Rocks important?

"Well... to start, at age 19, I ran around to Boston gay bars with a fake id.  My experiences resulted in feelings that ran the gammit: free, ecstatic, passionate, angry, impulsive, sexy, heartbroken, frisky, uneasy, anxious and fabulous to name a few.  It was complex to say the least.  But the most surprising detail I discovered is how a gay bar functions as a vaccum for lost souls.  As a young person, I thought gay bars were spaces to celebrate our ferocity against the odds, but instead I realized they're a whole other monster.  I found that so many people bring their insecurities to the club and with only a few sex-positive gay role models, young gay people just follow suit.  Therefore, my question is what we do to promote and own self-acceptance?

This is just a microcosm of a universal connundrum." ~Stuart

 

And why is this opportunity so important for Stuart?

"I truly believe that I was born to make art and inspire.  It's my gift and a damn good service I can provide for this world.  This is a pinnacle for me as a young artist.  I'm trying to facilitate a lifestyle in which I can have time and space to do what I do best and give back to the communities that have given so much to me.  Hybridge Arts Collective is providing me with an invaluable opportunity to make a radical mark as the artist I believe myself to be.  Presenting my work as their Blueprint Breakout Artist, I am sure this will be the key to continuing on my creative path towards a bright, prolific future.       

So On The Rocks is the first step.  After 3 years of gestating this work, it needs to be born, inspiring us all on our quest for self-love and inner peace.  This piece, my first full-length solo, is on the cusp of greatness and has the potential to create revolutionary change, but I sincerely need your financial support to share the best version of this dream.  I know that once On The Rocks is made, it will move on to even greater heights.  The sky's the limit!  The trick is just making this initial push to allow this nugget to explode." ~Stuart  

What is it we need to make On The Rocks soar??  

Money.  And your emotional support.  But mainly money.  $1,900 to be precise.  

What for?:

$ to pay a dynamite Dramaturg/Director (Adam Kerbel is on it!)

$ for a sensational Sound Designer

$ for a capable Costume and Set consultant

$ for majestic Makeup and Costumes

$ for Rehearsal Space 

$ to afford Marketing (so people will know about this thing!)

$ to purchase plenty of Ice (for when I dump it on my head)

$ to buy a few more Red Buckets

$ for a Photographer

$ for a Videographer

 

What if I'm too broke too help? :(

Every penny helps!  Really!  Think about it...if you spend what you would for a sandwich on this project, you'll get something even more delicious.  But if you really are broke...Tell someone about this campaign who isn't!   

Also, VOLUNTEER!!  We need help with a bunch of stuff, like each night, we will need at least FOUR people to make this gem run smoothly.  So if you're broke but extra caring, please come forward.  Your support is invaluable!!

Spread the news!  On facebook, twitter and any social media you got! And of course... come to the show!  June 24th and 26th. 

Hope to see you there, fully funded :)

story:
***UPDATE***

WE DID IT!  Thanks to your dedicated efforts, we hit phase 1 of our goal, and the show is fully funded for its world premiere this June in NYC!

Now, let's take a look at Phase 2. Phase 2's goal is to raise another $2700; $200 for fundraising commissions, $500 for more rehearsal studio time and money towards filming a performance of the show, and $2000 for bringing the show to Southern California for 1-2 performances this Fall 2013.

Tickets for the show can be purchased HERE:

http://planetconnections.org/ghost-on-a-stick/ 

If you haven't already, please LIKE the FB page:

https://www.facebook.com/ghostonastick 

********************************************************

Hi! We are Jara Jones and Megan Jeannette Smith.  Jara's an Off-Broadway actor and playwright in New York City, and Megan's a director.  Jara's one man show, Ghost On a Stick, has just been accepted into the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity in NYC this June.  This piece of theatre is an intense semi-autobiographical tale highlighting the years when he worked on a "haunted" ship, and it addresses the fallout which can occur when one succumbs to fear and mental illness.  We plan to use the world premiere of this play as a means to promote awareness and advocacy for crisis counseling/suicide prevention centers in New York City.

We need to raise at least $2700 for the following:

  • $750 for stipends for the cast and crew (director, stage manager, designers)
  • $400 for performance/venue fees
  • $300 for props/costumes/furniture (liquid latex, blood, a simple desk and chair, for example)
  • $450 for a projector and a screen
  • $400 for marketing and publicity (website, postcards, press materials, programs)
  • $200 for fundraising gifts and shipping
  • $200 for Indiegogo commission fees

Any funds raised after $2700 will go toward additional rehearsal studio time and plans to tour the show for a limited Southern California run.

We're looking to our most ardent supporters to ask for contributions.  In return, we're offering the following perks:

  • A mention in our program and website
  • Signed programs from the cast and crew
  • Personalized scary short stories recorded just for you by Jara (spooky!)
  • Signed copies of Jara's book of poems: Ramshackle
  • Commissioned songs created by Jara
  • A chance to have your name featured as a character in the play
  • An opportunity to bring Ghost On a Stick to your hometown

Please spread the word about this exciting production and fundraising campaign!
story_txt:
***UPDATE***
WE DID IT!  Thanks to your dedicated efforts, we hit phase 1 of our goal, and the show is fully funded for its world premiere this June in NYC!
Now, let's take a look at Phase 2. Phase 2's goal is to raise another $2700; $200 for fundraising commissions, $500 for more rehearsal studio time and money towards filming a performance of the show, and $2000 for bringing the show to Southern California for 1-2 performances this Fall 2013.
Tickets for the show can be purchased HERE:
http://planetconnections.org/ghost-on-a-stick/ 
If you haven't already, please LIKE the FB page:https://www.facebook.com/ghostonastick 
********************************************************
Hi! We are Jara Jones and Megan Jeannette Smith.  Jara's an Off-Broadway actor and playwright in New York City, and Megan's a director.  Jara's one man show, Ghost On a Stick, has just been accepted into the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity in NYC this June.  This piece of theatre is an intense semi-autobiographical tale highlighting the years when he worked on a "haunted" ship, and it addresses the fallout which can occur when one succumbs to fear and mental illness.  We plan to use the world premiere of this play as a means to promote awareness and advocacy for crisis counseling/suicide prevention centers in New York City.
We need to raise at least $2700 for the following:

$750 for stipends for the cast and crew (director, stage manager, designers)

$400 for performance/venue fees

$300 for props/costumes/furniture (liquid latex, blood, a simple desk and chair, for example)

$450 for a projector and a screen

$400 for marketing and publicity (website, postcards, press materials, programs)

$200 for fundraising gifts and shipping

$200 for Indiegogo commission fees
Any funds raised after $2700 will go toward additional rehearsal studio time and plans to tour the show for a limited Southern California run.
We're looking to our most ardent supporters to ask for contributions.  In return, we're offering the following perks:

A mention in our program and website

Signed programs from the cast and crew

Personalized scary short stories recorded just for you by Jara (spooky!)

Signed copies of Jara's book of poems: Ramshackle


Commissioned songs created by Jara

A chance to have your name featured as a character in the play

An opportunity to bring Ghost On a Stick to your hometown
Please spread the word about this exciting production and fundraising campaign!

story:
Born out of the 1980's Dinner Theatre in Weirton WV. Producer/Director Kelsey J. Hayward reunited the group in 1994 and continued to do Theatre and dinner theatre until 2007. The Theatre Group won many awards at OCTA the Ohio Community Theatre Association and WVTC the West Virginia Theatre Conference. The Group has done productions since then, but not on a consistent basis. With the number of inquiries and requests, Hayward has decided to regroup and go head on into a production. The first production will be this June in Newell's Laurel Hollow Park.
Theatre provides a place for many kids who do not have other places to go, but more then that it gives people a place to express themselves. I am sad to say that currently there aren't a lot of options for people to do Theatre in our area. Along with Kelsey Hayward and others I am trying to do a "Summer Stock" to full on Community Theatre program for our area. Shows require money though, for Royalties, Space, Costumes, etc. We are looking for contributors to donate even the smallest amount. Larger donations will earn you a producers credit.


When I was in High School our little Theatre group kept kids working on goals and expanding their minds, we as a community need that again.

If you can't donate

Spread the word and let people know by using the Indigogo share tools.

story:
Laboratory Dancers is an inclusive artist collective that provides Chicago with accessible and affordable dance performance and education. Our utmost goal is to bring dance to communities and individuals who might not otherwise encounter it. We explore sensation and experiential based movement, and our multimedia partners add depth to our work and broaden our reach to the public.

Our first cross-country tour will take place in June 2013! In order to share our work nationally and create new artistic collaborations, we need to raise enough funding to support travel and accommodations for 10 artists.  We are hoping to take our work to Minneapolis, Portland, Seattle, and a few stops along the way.  Every donation helps us spread Laboratory Dancers’ unique approach to the creation of dance, while exposing us to new experiences which will inspire future work. 

On the Lab Cab, we will bring new works  by company choreographers Emily Lukasweski, Ally Subak, Beth Berta, and Haley Bergshneider. Musicians Sam Hertz and Ira Ochs will perform live with the dancers, and we will collaborate with visual artist Jessie Winslow to create shadow paintings and visual documentation throughout the tour.

Our Seattle performance will take place at Washington Hall, June 12th and 13th. The lineup of artists is:

Laboratory Dancers

MaryAnn McGovern and Dancers

Kate Corby

Peter Carpenter

Jessie Young

We are thrilled to be performing on the crest of the Beyond the Threshold: Seattle International Dance Festival wave. 

 

Your donation will go directly to one of the following categories:

*Renting the van (or LAB CAB, if you will)

*Gas

*Space rental for performances and workshops

*Accommodations

 

Check out more at laboratorydancers.com

 

HOP ON THE LAB CAB!

story:
Flip Flop Wearing Floridians Invade Texas!

Background

Alyson and I have been chosen to present work at the Big Range Austin Dance Festival in Austin, TX! The festival features numerous dance exhibitions by choreographers from around the world, who present work ranging from ballet, to modern and everything in between. The four programs at Big Range present quality dance works that aim to strengthen and bring the arts community together. Alyson and I are excited to be a part of this supportive and diverse experience with the Austin community, sharing our vision for music and dance collaboration.

As artists, we not only share a passion for the performing arts but are both native Floridians with adventurous spirits. Alyson, who has been dancing her entire life, currently performs, choreographs, and is the Rehearsal Director for the professional modern dance company Fuzión Dance Artists, as well as an Adjunct Instructor of Dance at Booker High School and St Petersburg College. I have been banging on the drums since the age of 13 and currently play for The Wallies. I am also a teaching artist with Very Special Arts Florida where I have the opportunity to share my passion for music with students of all ages and abilities.

Alyson and Drew, Texas Bound!

The exhibition we were chosen to participate in is quite an interesting and exciting one, and has been called an audience favorite. Imagine this: 10 choreographers, each creating four 1-minute long pieces, cycling though each choreographer and back again, in a non-stop 40 minute long spectacle. This is called Dance Carousel and plays with the idea of creativity through confinement. The challenge is to present a complete idea, in movement, sound, and atmosphere, in 60 seconds. A challenge humbly accepted by your own redheaded dance vixen and Puerto-Jew bearded drummer!

Alyson was chosen as one of the ten choreographers (one of only two chosen from outside of Texas) with the music accompaniment provided by myself. Together we are exploring four different themes on human reliance: technology, relationships, adventure, and creation.

Why Indiegogo?

So now the obvious part, why an Indigogo campaign? As individuals who’s only real calling and passion in life is to create and share, funding is an extremely crucial element in making our vision come to life. All of the gracious people in our lives have helped us in so many ways with emotional, spiritual and literal support, so here we are again asking for whatever you can give to help make this experience possible for us and our audience. Thank you so much in advance!

 

Here’s the breakdown of how we would use your generous contributions:

Gas/Travel Expenses: $500
Instrument Rental (Djembe & Timpani): $55
Set Building Supplies: $45
Texas Love-Seat : $50
Food: $200

 

Please pass the word on about our campaign, we couldn't do this without you!

Sincerely,

        Drew & Alyson

story:
UPDATED NOVEMBER 27, 2013: We've moved onto the final stage of this project and have launched a new campaign that will raise money to pay the cast and crew throughout the performances.

Thanks to all who've contributed! 


ABOUT THE PROJECT 

TYSON vs ALI realizes the greatest heavyweight boxing match that never happened.  The production drops my signature combination of live-action and video into a boxing ring.  Leather hits flesh, as “Iron Mike’s” brute pugilism goes toe-to-toe, literally, with the larger-than-life poetry of “The Greatest.”

Fans of boxing could argue endlessly if Muhammad Ali’s legendary footwork, speed, and reach would be an effective antidote to Mike Tyson’s unparalleled fierceness in the ring were it possible for them to fight one another in their primes. What makes the realization of this fantasy dramatically compelling – set in a real boxing ring and taking place over a 12 rounds fight – is that both of these boxers outshine their athletic reputations and achievements. 

Both fighters still loom large in the world’s cultural imagination; their stories carry special resonance and both are major players in America’s cultural evolution.  TYSON vs ALI explores how differently these two heroes of the black community reigned, how their histories and personalities affected the world, and how boxing both made them the heroes they are and destroyed them both.

WHY WE NEED YOUR FINANCIAL HELP TO MAKE IT HAPPEN!

This round of funding is dedicated to the training of our Fighter/Performers. They are going to learn to spar and to carry themselves like our two champs. We are working at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn three days a week with our trainer Daniel Burnam. You financial support will go directly toward paying for our gym membership and equipment. Get to know the team, below, and donate any amount you're able today so that we may bring you the very best show we're able to come January. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Dusty Shoes is about a woman who is not listening to her inner voice, who happens to be a bouffon harkening back to the ‘20’s. Madame Rouge, the bouffon, encourages her to follow her passion. We see the woman take a more difficult journey until she bucks up, listens, and puts her creative energy into action.

It’s about my journey, and perhaps, yours.

Hi my name is Trilby Jeeves. I did change it when I was 5 years old. My artistic parents were cool and let me pick my own first name! I grew up in a visual arts home, and to probably the dismay of my parents, I ended up venturing into the performing arts.

I studied acting, l’art de jeu, en Francais (a language I was just learning) in Quebec City for three years, and then went on to a varied career of acting, costuming, and other jobs in between to keep those financial wolves at bay.

But my dreams of creating my own work kept getting postponed. I watched others do it.

Then, I had a back operation due to a massive herniated disc. I needed to revisit my dream. It would be the main way for me to work in my acting field. My foot and leg had nerve damage and limited the roles for which I could audition.

Time to create my own work!

I’m a late bloomer, but I’m finally doing it. I’m writing, producing, and acting in my solo show Dusty Shoes this summer at the Edmonton and Regina Fringe Festivals.

And, I need your help to support my venture. A solo show… isn’t. Lots of people have come forward to help me launch my dream and as they are artists, too, I would like to reward them financially. (funny how landlords don’t barter for rent… sigh ;))

What We Need & What You Get

Money… not our favourite topic as artists! But, here is our budget for putting ‘Dusty Shoes’ on the road.

(all fees are considered honorariums because if everyone was paid what they truly were worth, for all the hours they contributed… well, you get the picture!)

Production Team

Director: 2,000.00

Stage Manager (Vancouver): 500.00

Stage Manager (Regina): 200.00

Stage Manager (Edmonton): 1,000.00

Sound Designer: 700.00

Costume Designer: 200.00

Photographer: 300.00

Graphic Artist: 300.00

 

Pre-Production Costs

Rehearsal Space Rental: 800.00

Costume Materials: 200.00

Props: 100.00

Fringe Admission Costs (Regina): 600.00

Fringe Admission Costs (Edmonton): 800.00

 

Marketing & Publicity

Regina (5 days):

Flyers/postcards (500): 149.00

Posters (100): 50.00

Programs: 225.00

 

Edmonton (10 days):

Flyers/postcards (2000): 400.00

Posters (100): 50.00

Programs: 225.00

Crowdsourcing Perk Costs (buttons/mailings): 200.00

Indiegogo Fundraising Fees: 500.00

 

Travel

Regina (11 days)

Car/Gas: (6 tanks @ 30.00 ea/maintenance): 380.00

Food: (11X 25.00): 275.00

Accommodation: (2 nights on the road): 160.00

 

Edmonton (17 days)

Car/Gas Actor: (6 tanks @ 30.00 ea/maintenance): 380.00

Car/Gas Stage Manager: (6 tanks @ 30.00): 180.00

Food Actor: (17X 25.00): 425.00

Food Stage Manager: (17 X 25.00): 425.00

Accommodation: (2 nights on the road): 160.00

 

GRAND TOTAL: 11,384.00

RECEIVED: -750.00 (previous donations)

SPONSORSHIP: -500.00 (printing)

 TOTAL: $10,634.00

 (*A live Fundraiser in Vancouver will also help us to meet our final budget)

(*if we don't meet our goal, most funds will go toward the production team)

(*if by some tap dancing happy shoe moment we go beyond our goal, the remaining will go towards producing Dusty Shoes in Vancouver!)

The Impact

With 'Dusty Shoes', my goal is to have people leave the theatre questioning what their inner voice has been telling them to do (whether it’s write a snail mail letter to a long lost friend, or write that book) and then begin. Creative ideas beget more creative ideas and soon one person is an inspired being, inspiring another. With this mission, our communities have a chance to be a better place, one person at a time.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, don't worry or fret! If you like our project, maybe you could just share our link, (on twitter consider adding #DustyShoes) and that will make us super happy. Thank you for taking time to read this, and consider helping keep the arts alive. With all the cuts that are happening within our country and world wide, this is a crucial time to teach our young, and beyond to keep our right brains, our creative ideas going so the world can truly be a better place. As Daniel Pink says in my favourite book: A Whole New Mind "The keys of the kingdom are changing.

story:
My name is Marc and have been performing magic since I was 9. I am an award winning “close up” magician
 
I am a Lifetime member of the International Magicians Society (IMS), member of the International Brotherhood of Magicians (IBM), member of the Society of American Magicians (SAM) and a "honorary" member of Gary Darwin's Magic Club in Las Vegas, Nevada.
 
My campaign is to be able to do a first class Las Vegas style illusion and variety show that will be used as fundraising for anyone needing to raise funds for their cause, be it a large organization or any place in need of assistance.
 
There are many small organizations/schools/individuals who need to do fundraising but are doing it the “hard” way, selling candy, magazines etc. and receiving a small percentage of the sales, with my project what would take normally take them a “month” to receive in funds they can obtain in “1“ evening using my show.
 
Everyone knows the “big” charities but it is the lesser know ones that are in need of the most help, volunteer fire departments, service dogs for veterans and disabled, little league teams that have old equipment, the family who lost their home in a fire etc, These are the ones who need someone like myself and my project to help them.
 
I have done many benefits in my time and was even recognized by the Magic Circle in London, England for my charitable work. What I do is EXTREMELY important to me, not only as a performer but also as a human being!
 
With you help and pledges you will not only have the satisfaction of knowing you are helping out myself but also helping others, not just at this Holiday time but throughout the years to come. My project is one that keeps on giving, if you could see the smile on a child’s face who has cancer because they enjoyed my magic, you would definitely understand where I am am coming from.
 
To do my project I am seeking $75,000, this will basically cover the illusions, costuming, choreography, entertainers, music, etc. Everything will be “A-1“ as far as these are concerned, it WILL be a first class show and obviously the more it can get funded the grander it will be, ALL funding will be used for the show. If this goal is not met any funds will be used to have a condensed version of a show.
 
The perks I have are quite unique, from an “angel on my shoulder" pin to my instructional magic trick DVD to having you live “on stage" with us performing a trick!
 
Any
“corporate sponsorship” will get a special place in our program and a SIGNED cast member photos along with a “Certificate of Corporate Sponsorship"
 
Being a contributer to my project won't get you any “monetary" return but will give you a “heartfelt” return on assisting me, knowing you helped me help others and to make this world a little bit better, show by show.
 
Anything you can pledge will help and be greatly appreciated, please tell others about my project, get the word out. What I need is a “holiday” miracle so that I can help give others “their” miracle. Thank you.

I have done many benefits in my time and was even recognized by the Magic Circle in London, England for my charitable work. What I do is EXTREMELY important to me, not only as a performer but also as a human being!
 
With you help and pledges you will not only have the satisfaction of knowing you are helping out myself but also helping others, not just at this Holiday time but throughout the years to come. My project is one that keeps on giving, if you could see the smile on a child’s face who has cancer because they enjoyed my magic, you would definitely understand where I am am coming from.
 
To do my project I am seeking $75,000, this will basically cover the illusions, costuming, choreography, entertainers, music, etc. Everything will be “A-1“ as far as these are concerned, it WILL be a first class show and obviously the more it can get funded the grander it will be, ALL funding will be used for the show. If this goal is not met any funds will be used to have a condensed version of a show.
 
The perks I have are quite unique, from an “angel on my shoulder" pin to my instructional magic trick DVD to having you live “on stage" with us performing a trick!
 
Any
“corporate sponsorship” will get a special place in our program and a SIGNED cast member photos along with a “Certificate of Corporate Sponsorship"

 
Being a contributer to my project won't get you any “monetary" return but will give you a “heartfelt” return on assisting me, knowing you helped me help others and to make this world a little bit better, show by show.
 
Anything you can pledge will help and be greatly appreciated, please tell others about my project, get the word out. What I need is a “holiday” miracle so that I can help give others “their” miracle. Thank you.

story:
Meet Proud Kate:

We are the Proud Kate Theatre Project: a confederation of actors, directors, designers, and artisans who specialize in the production of stylized and classical works that explore the changing roles of women in the world.  

Our current project, Harold Pinter's The Dumb Waiter, is part of a new venture we call TURNABOUT.  Proud Kate is primarily concerned with promoting women in theatre, and exploring women's issues.  That said, there are a great number of extraordinary men who have contributed blood, sweat, tears, and time to each of our projects.  In recognition of this, we have TURNABOUT, which features some of Proud Kate's proud men, and shines a light on how uncertain EVERYONE'S lives can be.

This campaign allows us to thank our men by letting us sink their teeth into a juicy text, and to create a revolutionary take on a classic piece of theatre.  It will be packed with action, laughs, screams, and a little bit of black magic.  It also allows us to create a great piece of theatre.  And now we need YOUR HELP.


How It Works:


Every production has a core set of expenses before deisgners and acotrs even begin their work!  The company must rent the theatre for performances and a hall for rehearsal, provide insurance, and license the rights to the script.  These can total around $5000 on their own!  We're asking for $1800 to create the things YOU can see and hear onstage, so when you walk into the theatre, you'll know that you were a part of it.


Where It Goes:


Here's our design budget below:

$100 - Costumes (2 three-piece suits, shoes, ties, suspenders, and handkerchieves)

$100 - Props (guns - not real ones!, crockery, bed sheets, picture frame, fake cigarettes and matches)

$300 - Lights (rental lights and fixtures, light bulbs, extra cable, gels - for colored lights)

$50 - Sound (tracks for sound and effects, extra cable and speakers)

$700 - Set (lumber, paint, screws, drill bits, rope and pulley, beds)

$200 - Marketing (printing programs and posters to publicize)

$310 - Script License (the rights to the words the actors are speaking)

Remember, this doesn't include space, insurance, or salaries.  Our crew and design team are only getting a fraction of thier usual rate, so that we can put more into the materials that will build this show.  And the actors and director believe enough in this project that they're not taking any pay at all!

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you don't have the ability to contribute now, you can still help this show succeed!  You can make a friend donation - pass this along to other people you know and let us borrow your friends!  If you can't afford our tickets, contact us - we always need an extra set of hands during our tech week, and we want you to see the show!

Thank you

It's you that makes theatre possible, and that allows our talented artists to keep working and creating magical performances that foster thought and change.  Thank you from Charlie, David, Shane, Kroy, Matthew, Kroy, Kat, Josh, Brittany, Thomas, Josh, Jackie, Kevin and Tiffany for making this happen.

story:
Who We Are

For 25 years, in a rambling school building just off the chaotic SV Road in suburban Mumbai, dance has changed lives. When Odissi dancer Jhelum Paranjape started Smitalay in memory of her dearest friend, the actor Smita Patil, she had little inkling of what lay ahead. Since 1989, Smitalay has been an active presence in Mumbai's dance scene - nurturing and promoting the classical dance style of Odissi through its dance academy and performing unit.


What We Do

At Smitalay, we believe that traditional dance forms will have a vibrant future if they are practised by students who come from all walks of life. To ensure this, our classes are made affordable to all. The really underprivileged pay only INR 50 a month (about 80 cents). In this way, we ensure that classical dance is not an elitist preserve; it is a joy afforded to one and all. And we have seen the results - senior students have come back to teach at Smitalay, also becoming established performers along the way. Some also work independently, taking Odissi to unlikely corners of the globe. 
To make Odissi more accessible, we choose subjects beyond mythology, exploring areas like mathematics, ethnopolitics, the Dalit  movement, women’s education and mystic poetry. 


What We Need

At Smitalay, students learn more than just dance. They learn how to live - how to be confident, sensitive and empowered artists and citizens with a voice of their own. Rising costs have meant that the sum earned from fees no longer suffices to pay the salaries of teachers and sustain the institution. The funds raised through this appeal will go towards several urgent causes at Smitalay.
  • A dance festival. From October 11 to 19, Smitalay stages 5 of its landmark productions and the traditional Odissi repertoire, across three venues in Mumbai. The performances are not ticketed, enabling easy and widespread access.
  • Renovating our facilities. Years of training on cement and tiled floors have left many of our dancers injured. Wooden flooring will make Odissi at Smitalay more injury-free!
  • Paying better salaries to Smitalay's teachers, all full-time dancers who must earn a living from their chosen profession.
  • Offering scholarships to underprivileged students.

How You Can Make A Difference

Your contribution will - 

  • Invigorate the dance scene in Mumbai, by giving Smitalay the opportunity to stage its productions for a diverse audience. 
  • Help us offer subsidised dance training to more students.
  • Create better working conditions for performers.
  • Bolster the rich dance culture of India through pedagogy and performance. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    For more payment options (netbanking etc.), go to http://getfbpay.in/smitalaydance or get in touch with us at smitalaydance [at] gmail.com. Also, we would love for you to help in the following ways (psst - they'll only take a minute!)

    • E-mail your friends, share our campaign on social media, challenge your friends to contribute and make some noise about our campaign. 
    Thank you!

story:
About the project

Second Generation Productions (2g) is a New York City-based Asian American theater company that commissions, develops, and produces new plays and musicals. This summer, for the first time in six years, we’re presenting a full-length workshop production of a new musical, Galois written by Sung Rno, composed by Aaron Jones, and directed by Victor Maog.

We’ve been developing this new work over the past year with presentations at New Dramatists, 54 Below, and Second Stage Uptown.  We’ve  now been chosen to be part of the legendary, OBIE-award winning New Ohio Theatre’s Ice Factory Festival. We’re joining a stellar line-up in this annual summer festival where artists and companies take risks, try out new ideas and bring their projects to a new level.

Galois?

Galois is a rock-mathematical-musical expression of the chaotic, revolutionary, and brief life of the historical figure, Evariste Galois. Galois was a French mathematician whose breakthrough advancements in the field of polynomial equations and group theory went firmly against the popularly accepted knowledge of his day. He discovered a branch of mathematics as a precocious teenager, yet died too young at 21 in a duel over a woman. Galois gives voice to the contradictory passions of this math rock star: he was a genius of abstraction, but also a fervent revolutionary; he was brilliantly cerebral, yet madly in love; he was a gifted prodigy, yet unappreciated by the establishment. 

We need your help! 

Mounting a new musical takes a ton of resources even at the workshop stage. After months and months of crystallizing big ideas, brainstorming, pushing, pulling, public readings, going back to the drawing board, blowing things up, and the never-ending joys of the creative, collaborative process, we’re at a moment where we are bringing this piece on its feet. We’re working with some remarkable, accomplished collaborators such as J. Oconer Navarro (The Adding Machine, Minetta Lane Theater; Barrio Grrrl!, The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts) as music director, and Camille A. Brown (A Streetcar Named Desire, Broadway; tick, tick...BOOM!, Encores! at City Center; the upcoming Fortress of Solitude, The Public Theater) as choreographer. And we have the most rocking cast featuring Julian Cihi, Diane Phelan, Jonathan David, Robbie Tann, Shelley Thomas and Andrew Guilarte. Our design team is Mikiko Suzuki MacAdams (Sets), Yael Lubetsky (Lights), and Josh Liebert (Sound).  The stellar team also includes Shae Candelaria (Production Stage Manager), Courtney Golden (Production Manager), and Nikki Chalas (Associate Producer). 

Your support will go a long way in bringing this piece into the next stage that it needs to continue development.  

Why is an Asian American theater company producing a musical about a French mathematician set in 1830's France?

Good question. The simple answer is: Galois explodes the notion of what an Asian American musical can be. Come and witness it for yourself. July 23-26.

Vive la révolution!

To celebrate the close of this campaign and the show, we're throwing a Bastille Day party on the evening of Monday, July 14th at Von, 3 Bleecker Street. All are invited to join the creative team and cast to raise a glass to the storming of the Bastille. Save the date!  

More about 2g

Led by Artistic Director Victor Maog and Managing Director Jane Jung, 2g is dedicated to creating contemporary, world-class Asian American theater that reaches across cultural and racial boundaries. 2g has partnered with some of the country’s most prestigious theatre companies to co-produce world premieres of new Asian American plays. Since its inception, Second Generation has supported several hundred artists, through full productions of new plays and community-based events, as well as grassroots developmental work in service of cultivating new generations of excellence in Asian American dramatic arts. The goal of 2g is to commission Asian American playwrights and provide them with a cycle of development from initial workshop to final production.

Second Generation Productions is supported by NYSCA, DCA, and the ART/NY Creative Space Grant and Nancy Quinn Fund. Galois is funded by The Ensemble Studio Theatre/Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Science & Technology project

story:
Update: Donations made by Lincoln County residents are now being matched by a generous supporter of the arts! Contribute now to make your gift go twice as far!

Hi, I'm Drew. I grew up in small towns in Eastern Washington, moving to Davenport in high school. Theatre has been part of my life for almost as long as I can remember. Theatre is vital to every community. It allows us to exercise and grow our ability for empathy, compassion, and understanding. I started Davenport Theatrical (DT) in 2008 because I believe that everyone should have access to the arts. With your help, we can become the cultural institution that Lincoln County needs. 

Davenport (population 1,700) is a small wheat-farming community in Eastern Washington. It is the county seat of Lincoln County, which contains eight small towns and has a population of 10,000. For the past six years, DT has staged one or two plays and musicals annually, performed and directed by local volunteers in the high school auditorium.

Davenport Theatrical is kept running by some of the most talented and hardworking volunteers that I’ve ever worked with. But, because of Davenport’s remote location, these volunteers have limited access to training and support.

The Guest Artist Program

This program will bring 2-3 professional theatre artists to Davenport, WA each year. Their contributions will help DT produce a new level of theatre for the people of Lincoln County by bringing their professional talents (in acting, directing, design, and/or technical theatre) to the stage and by mentoring local volunteers.

Guest artists will infuse Lincoln County with new stories for our stage and new ways of telling them.  Your support will make this a reality.

Our goal is to launch a guest artist program that will provide at least two professional theatre artists (actors, directors, designers, and/or technicians) per year. These guest artists will come to Davenport for about a month and apply their skills and experience to our productions while also mentoring local volunteers or teaching theatre classes for kids and adults. It will also expand the range of the stories that we’re able to tell. The guest artist program will allow us to bring in actors to fill roles that would be difficult to cast locally, such as people of color and young adults. 

Almost, Maine in February 2015

We will be launching the guest artist program in February 2015 with a production of Almost, Maine, a play about love in a small town, set against the backdrop of the Northern Lights. I’ll be coming from Boston to direct the production, and I’ll be joined by two other theatre professionals: Erika Kae, a lighting designer based in Denver, and Emily Butzi, an awesome stage manager based in Baltimore. In order to launch this program, I will be donating my time, and Erika and Emily have agreed to work on the production in exchange for travel expenses and a small fee. I like to describe the play as “a love letter to small town folks.” It’s the perfect show for Davenport and, oh, did I mention that we’ll be creating the Northern Lights inside the theatre?! You can see why we’re bringing in a professional lighting designer!

How You Can Help

This year, we need $1900 to hire our first guest artists and bring them to Davenport. Going forward, we’ll need an average of $2000 to fund each guest artist, including travel expenses. Our goal is to raise $5900 by October 1, 2015. This will ensure that we can fund guest artists for our next two seasons, including both Almost, Maine and a large musical to be produced in July 2016.

We are hopeful that you will see the potential in this innovative new program to bring professional theatre artists to rural areas and be excited about what this program will make possible.

All money donated will go directly to bringing professional theatre artists to Lincoln County.

If you have any questions about Davenport Theatrical, the guest artists program, or this fundraising campaign, please feel free to reach out to me directly at drew@davenporttheatrical.org.

Thank you for your support.

Drew Kowalkowski
Co-Founder, Davenport Theatrical

story:
O U R   S T O R Y

 

ShPIeL-Performing Identity will mount the Skokie premiere of THE INVASION OF SKOKIE in May 2013. It occurs in Skokie in the 1970s, when a Neo-Nazi group planned a demonstration (becoming a celebrated court case about civil liberties), which was an affront to the traumatic memory of those who had perished in and survived the Holocaust. But award-winning playwright, Steven Peterson’s play is also humorous and bittersweet, telling the story of a Jewish family’s desire and struggle to pass down their heritage and beliefs to the next generation. In other words it is about the future!

 

A B O U T    S H P I E L    &    T H E    P R O D U C T I O N

 

ShPIeL – Performing develops and produces theatre from identity heritage and culture http://shpieltheatre.com/ In association with Lookingglass Theatre, the Tony Award winning theatre, as well as working with Silk Road Rising and Piven Theatre Workshop -- ShPIeL is an innovative source for transcultural theatre. Bearing these principles in mind, and as a member of ShPIeL, Peterson promises a newly developed version for the Skokie Premiere.

 

Rachel Edwards Harvith who will direct the show will bring a very personal approach to the show, to be performed in the fully equipped theatre at the Mayer Kaplan Jewish Community Center on 5050 Church, west of Gross Point Road. The production will also feature forums or educational talkbacks after every performance, a study guide and will tell the story of a community that was determined to do the right thing.

 


J O I N    T H E    I N V A S I O N    O F    S K O K I E    

C A M P A I G N

 

$5 SHPIELER --a shout out on Social Media. Helps cover office supplies.

 

$10 SHPIELNIK --a shout out on Social Media + a hand written thank-you note. Helps cover script copying.

 

$25 SHPIELMACHER --a shout out on Social Media + hand written note - name in the program. Helps cover production team meetings.

 

$50 GANTSE-SHPIEL -- All of the above plus a signed cast poster. Helps cover research at the Skokie Historical Society.

 

$100 SKOKIE VILLAGER -- All of the above and exclusive behind the scene photos, 2 tix. Exclusive party with the theatre-makers. Helps cover set and costume build.

 

$250 SKOKIE SUPPORTER -- All of the above plus plus a ShPIeL mug, 2 tix; attend rehearsal. Helps cover lighting and set designing.

 

$500 SKOKIE MENSCH -- All of the above, a DVD of show's highlights, plus 4 tix. Helps cover educational materials packets and talkbacks.

 

$1000 SKOKIE TRUSTEE -- All of the above plus lunch with director or producer; an original work of art, song, or short play + cookies - because you deserve cookies. Helps cover subsidies for groups at discounted prices.

 

$2500 SKOKIE MAYOR -- All of the above plus lunch with 2012 Dorothy Silver Award winning playwright Steve Peterson. Helps cover royalties and director.

 

When the curtain goes up on THE INVASION OF SKOKIE this May, your contribution will be responsible for the sound, lights, publicity materials, actors, program and costumes. Every dollar you invest will be used and reused as our creative energies will produce a show you will feel proud to be part. Best of all your gift is tax-deductible through ShPIeL-Performing Identity, a 501(c)3 non-profit.

 

R A V E S    F O R   2 0 1 0   P R O D U C T I O N

 

"Peterson's play offers a nuanced, warm and sympathetic portrait of a postwar, newly suburban generation…Skokie — singular, complex and yet emblematic of so much in American history — stands tall."  Chris Jones, Chicago Tribune

 

"The Invasion of Skokie magnificently represents multiple sides to the attacks on the Jewish heritage in 1978. Even now, I’m certain the debate continues. How to preserve 2010+ years of customs and history? Tradition, Tradition, tradition. Even as a shiksa, I get it!"  Katy Walsh, Chicago Theater Beat

 

“Highly Recommended!!!"  Second City Tzivi

" …this is a warm, touching story that gets to the heart of the characters." Al Bresloff, Around The Town Chicago

 

T E L L    Y O U R     F R I E N D S 

Spreading the word is a huge help to this project. Blog, email, tweet and post this on Facebook! Tell your neighbors, your college classics professor, your mom, your local deli and your falafel stand and we'll see you at the theatre! We are incredibly grateful for whatever you can donate, including your continued enthusiasm and encouragement.

 

Visit us on facebook, twitter, or our website

 


S h P I e L   –  P E R F O R M I N G   I D E N T I T Y

 

David Y. Chack - Artistic Director & Chief Vision Officer

Joan Mazzonelli - Managing Producing Director

Eli Taylor -  Artistic & Engagement Associate for New Initiatives

Benjamin Goldman -- Business & Development Officer

Davood Dehnavifar - Internet & Digital Associate

Anita Silvert - Development Advisor

 

Board of Directors & Advisors 

Terry Taylor 

Steven Peterson 

David Chack 

Joan Mazzonelli

Charlotte Newberger 

Mark Roth 

Steven Rogin

Roslyn Alexander Grodzin
story_txt:
O U R   S T O R Y 
 
ShPIeL-Performing Identity will mount the Skokie premiere of THE INVASION OF SKOKIE in May 2013. It occurs in Skokie in the 1970s, when a Neo-Nazi group planned a demonstration (becoming a celebrated court case about civil liberties), which was an affront to the traumatic memory of those who had perished in and survived the Holocaust. But award-winning playwright, Steven Peterson’s play is also humorous and bittersweet, telling the story of a Jewish family’s desire and struggle to pass down their heritage and beliefs to the next generation. In other words it is about the future!
 
A B O U T    S H P I E L    &    T H E    P R O D U C T I O N
 
ShPIeL – Performing develops and produces theatre from identity heritage and culture http://shpieltheatre.com/ In association with Lookingglass Theatre, the Tony Award winning theatre, as well as working with Silk Road Rising and Piven Theatre Workshop -- ShPIeL is an innovative source for transcultural theatre. Bearing these principles in mind, and as a member of ShPIeL, Peterson promises a newly developed version for the Skokie Premiere.
 
Rachel Edwards Harvith who will direct the show will bring a very personal approach to the show, to be performed in the fully equipped theatre at the Mayer Kaplan Jewish Community Center on 5050 Church, west of Gross Point Road. The production will also feature forums or educational talkbacks after every performance, a study guide and will tell the story of a community that was determined to do the right thing.
 

J O I N    T H E    I N V A S I O N    O F    S K O K I E
