story:
Can You Keep The Secret?


  • We are The Secret Theatre in LIC, NY.  We promote new works through our New Voices Project, our two annual short play festivals, we produce both Classical and Contemporary in-house shows, we are the only theatre in the borough of Queens producing weekly children's theatre shows, we also work with a range of great theatre companies like Gideon Productions, Flux Theatre Ensemble, Boomerang, Caps Lock, Anti Matter, Going to Tahiti and many more, we produce musicals such as our critically lauded Steampuk Oliver!, Urinetown, & Parade, we hold classes for students from 6 to 16 and provide coaching services to many. In addition we have become a center for great improv with over 5 improv shows a week & classes taught by Face Off Unlimited, we have hosted many contemporary dance shows and specialty music events like the Queens New Music festival, our hugely popular Johnny Cash festival alongside special tribute shows for Alex Chilton and Bill Withers.
  • After a tough year when we discovered that the building we were in was not compliant we were hit with Dept of Buildings fines, architect fees and we had to move the Little Theatre to a different location with all the attendant moving and construction costs. Our budgets are tiny and with no real reserve to speak of we are dealing with a cash hole that threatens our existence.  The Secret has become a major contributor to the cultural life of Western Queens and LIC and has been responsible for creating a theatre scene in LIC where none previously existed.  With your help we can continue to win  plaudits from The New York Times [multiple critics pick awards] also many shows and artists have won or been nominated for the New York Innovative Theatre Awards, we can continue to support awesome artists and to push the envelope of what can be achieved in a borough that needs us.
  • So many people in this community and in the general NY theatre and arts community think of us as an Institution and yet we receive no money from either the city council, the New York Foundation for the Arts nor from the Dept of Cultural Affairs.  If you help us you will keep a truly grassroots supported organization alive. And Kicking.

What We Need & What You Get

Let's break down what we need and what for...

  • We need around $10,000 + to help us close our funding gap and to enable us to make crucial upgrades.
  • If you donate to this campaign you can get really cool perks such as sponsoring a chair [your name or business on the back of the chair], at a higher level we will make you a sponsor of one of our annual festivals with full credit above the title line, logos on all our publicity, sponsor our Children's theatre programs - just $300 gets you 6 months with a full page advertisement on the back of either Pirate Pete's or Princess Particular's programs. Or get a full semester's tuition for 22 weeks for an aspiring actor [ages 6 - 16], get free tickets + a custom designed T-Shirt and much more...

The Impact

We are making essential changes to how we run the business and your contribution can help us transition to a much healthier place where we can imagine existing for another 10 years and beyond.

  • The Secret Theatre doesn't receive tax dollar money nor does it get capital or project grants. If you contribute you will help a theatre that has survived in a difficult market, on mostly ticket income only, to carry on providing the entire community of NY theatre lovers a a vibrant performance space for theatre, dance, improv, comedy, music and more. There is no Queens Art Center but the Secret Theatre has been giving artists the kind of platform including gallery space for years.  Help us keep it going!
  • Our successful track record includes hit in house productions such as our Steampunk inspired Oliver! the Musical [5 glowing reviews, sold out crowds every night], Richard III [all reviews over the top positive, sold out crowds] as well as outside productions such as Flux's Hearts Like Fists [New York Times critics pick], Gideon Productions Advance Man, Blast Radius and Sovereign [all three NYT Critic's Picks]
  • All contributors will be invited to a free Ball if we reach our fundraising target. If you want any more information about the work of the theatre or how we intend to keep the wheels on our wagon please email our Artistic Director Richard Mazda - richard@secrettheatre.com

Risks & Challenges

  • We thank you for your support. Be assured that the team at the Secret Theatre is committed to keeping our theatre alive with your help. We have done wonders in the last 7 years, what can we achieve with the support of our community? Miracles?  Why not!
  • Our plan for surviving this challenging period is already been put into action. Bookings until Spring 2015 are coming in and we have many new ideas to encourage growth including an expansion of our Children's Theatre programming, increased daytime classes to offset 'dark' hours which currently produce no income, we have also instigated a 'SECRET LOVES' campaign to identify and collaborate with local businesses. The Local NYC. Uncle Jimmy's Pizza [Sunnyside], Court Square Diner. Tiny You [LIC & Sunnyside] have already signed up. We expect to have collaborative cross-marketing stragegies with up to 20 local businesses by early September with no limit to the number of partners.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute please consider helping us by getting the word out.   Please email links on your friends facebook pages or merely email any interested parties that you think would be receptive to helpin out?

  • Please us the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Project Snapshot

Hi everyone! We are a small team of makers, educators, STEM professionals and enthusiasts bringing Maker Faire back to the south side of Chicago this summer!  While Chicago is rich with programs, events and learning opportunities, there exist areas of the city where resources and attention are not as plentiful. The Chicago Southside Mini Maker Faire aims to help change that with its 2nd annual event on August 2, 2014!  Our primary goals are to:

  1. Bring high-quality and fun maker-based experiences to the south side of Chicago

  2. Highlight local and national Makers with diverse backgrounds and expertise

  3. Showcase  cultural and international making

  4. Spark excitement in attendees and makers of all ages

  5. Foster connections and relationships within the local community of makers and learners

What We Need

Our total project budget is a lean $11,000 and we are committed to contributing and securing half that amount ourselves.  But we need your help with the other half to make this second annual event even better than last year’s! Your support will help fund the costs of this outdoor event, including:

  • Event permits and insurance costs - $465

  • Tent, table and chair rentals - $5,215

  • Generator power for makers - $3,255

  • Breakfast, water and snacks for makers and volunteers - $300

  • T-shirts for volunteers and sponsors - $838

  • Website and license fees - $342

  • Printing, event wristbands and other day-of small needs - $340


If we don’t make the entire goal, funds will be allocated in strict order of priority: we’ll cover the costs of all maker needs (tents, electricity, etc.), mandatory event requirements (permits and insurance) and event safety and management needs (signage, volunteer support). We also may need to limit the number of makers and attendees in order to ensure a safe, fun event with the resources we have available. We’re committed to producing this event and making it the best experience we can!  And if we exceed our goal, we'll be able to invite more makers, offset transportation costs for attendees with limited resources, invite large-scale attractions or performers, and possibly save funds for next year's event.


Other Ways to Get Involved

In addition to the generosity of financial contributions, there are lots of other ways to help make this event happen!

  • Spread the word to your friends and colleagues, via email, social media, and old-fashioned word of mouth!
  • Like our page on Facebook and follow us on Twitter@ChiMakerFaire
  • Volunteer with us! Email us at volunteer@ChicagoSouthsideMiniMakerFaire.com to learn how to join our team!
  • Join the movement and be a Maker at the event - the Call for Makers application is now live!


About the Chicago Southside Mini Maker Faire

Part science fair, part art fair, and part something entirely new, Mini Maker Faire is a fun and energetic community-based event that brings together science, art, crafts and engineering in an exciting public forum. This celebration will showcase Chicago area makers with a focus on the diversity of people and thought that makes Chicago an innovative city of deeds.  Tech enthusiasts, crafters, educators, tinkerers, hobbyists, engineers, science clubs, authors, artists, and students will inspire people of all ages to roll up their sleeves and become makers!  

About Maker Faire:  

Maker Faire is the Greatest Show (and Tell) on Earth—a family-friendly showcase of invention, creativity and resourcefulness, and a celebration of the Maker movement. It’s a place where people show what they are making, and share what they are learning.

Makers range from tech enthusiasts to crafters to homesteaders to scientists to garage tinkerers. They are of all ages and backgrounds. The aim of Maker Faire is to entertain, inform, connect and grow this community.

The original Maker Faire event was held in San Mateo, CA and in 2013 celebrated its eighth annual show with some 900 makers and 120,000 people in attendance. World Maker Faire New York, the other flagship event, has grown in three years to 500+ makers and 55,000 attendees. Detroit, Kansas City, Newcastle (UK), Rome, and Tokyo are the home of “featured” 2013 Maker Faires (200+ makers), and community-driven, independently organized Mini Maker Faires are now being produced around the United States and the world—including right here in Chicago.

story:
Interactive Opera Vitruvian European Tour

Vitruvian is an innovative interactive opera that combines contemporary dance performance, classical opera and audio-visual,projection mapping. The music performance consists of classical baroque and electronic music alternated with noises.

The creative team behind Vitruvian opera is based in Berlin and consists of composer Tatsuru Arai, visual artist Arístides García, choreographer Anna Anderegg, dancer Elisa Pluta, soprano Xenia Romanova and costume designer Antoniya Ivanova.

EuropeanTourVitruvian

With your help we are planning to tour with Vitruvian opera in Europe in 2014-2015.The tour includes participation in the International Art Festivalin Europe for which the performance was selected: STOFF August 14-17th, 2014,Stockholm; KineticArtFair October 16-19th, 2014,London; STEIMinAmsterdam.

To be able to take part in these events we need your financial support to cover transportation and accommodation costs. The total amount is 3000 Euro for all three destinations (Stockholm, London, Amsterdam).

Invited

STOFF 2014

Kinetica Art fair 2014

STEIM Amsterdam

Team

Tatsuru Arai :concept, composition Arístides García :visulal-system

Anna Anderegg :choreography Antoniya Ivanova :costum 

Elisa Pluta :dance Xenia Romanova :soprano


concept by Tatsuru Arai

My artistic approach falls within the category of “New-Renaissance Art” in which I am exploring how a Gesamtkunstwerk can coexist with recurrence/evolution, Human/Technology, organic/inorganic matter, Chaos/Order. Vitruvian uses real-time painting and a projection-mapping system; otherwise know as visualization. This performance features a singer and a dancer. The basis for the inspiration of my operetta Vitruvian is from the “Vitruvian man” of Leonardo da Vinci, where the piece attempts to make both an analysis and mapping of the human-body. The movements and vocalizations of the performers are mixed with different musical styles, which are composed and programmed with complex chaos systems/geometric forms/abstructuristic choreography and so forth. Beside this, the work is a combination of extremes and tries to induce the audience into an odyssey of perception.

The Visualized Opera:Viruvian Melds Dance,Digital with Operetta

comment by Peter Kirn Create Digital Motion

Get ready for the high Renaissance of the digital.

The individual ingredients remain the same. But the threads of transmedia work, spanning everything from traditional costume design and choreography to the latest generative projections, draw ever closer.

A new generation of artists treats projection in the theater as something elemental, something that demands exploration.Vitruvian has gradually evolved in the ways it interweaves dance with opera, projected visualization and interactive sound with dance theater. An “interactive opera” in one act, it unapologetically adds digital imagery as an additional performer. But the human body insistently remains, in movement and voice, bathed in electronic light but not upstaged.

Just reading the bios of these artists is telling. True to the Renaissance icon the piece references, Leonardo, these are artists who are coders and conventional artists, drawing primarily from neither source.

The latest trailers and teasers give a bit of a taste of what they’re on, but consider this a preview. I think part of the challenge of this kind of work is that it tends to multiply the requirements for development and rehearsal geometrically. And it does that not only on the obvious technical side, but my making greater demands on the performers, too – it adds additional burden. But that’s also what makes it more exciting, and why I believe it’s essential to get these pieces in regular workshops and performances. Opera, the original transmedia spectacle, does the same: the convergence of different disciplines adds development atop development, even before you add digital technology.press CDM

recent performance 

03.2013 “salon Revolutioner vol.3”Platoon kunsthalle Berlin(old version) 

12.2013 “zoom focus” HfM Hanns Eisler Berlin (New version premiere) 

02. 2014 “unrender” Lehrtersiebzehn Berlin

 "Vitruvian"(old trailer)

cooperation

Fellini Gallery Berlin

Platoon Kunsthalle Berlin

LEHRTERSIEBZEHN Berlin

HfM Hanns Eisler Berlin

klangzeitort

Quartet Berlin Tokyo

thanks

wooguru/Orhan Selamaz/Rebecca Uliczka/Natalia Medvedeva

Challenges

The Vitruvian team is challenging opera genre staging innovative performance combining opera, digital audio video technologies, and dance and mixing various styles. The European tour we are going to take part in in 2014-2015 will be a major step to present this innovative performance to a wider audience and push boundaries of opera genre.

In the future I will continue to develop experimental opera performances and present new opera Ergosum that is being composed at the moment. To keep working on these projects and explore new media performances I need and highly appreciate your support.

Interactive Opera Vitruvian European TourVitruvian is an innovative interactive opera that combines contemporary dance performance, classical opera and audio-visual,projection mapping. The music performance consists of classical baroque and electronic music alternated with noises.The creative team behind Vitruvian opera is based in Berlin and consists of composer Tatsuru Arai, visual artist Arístides García, choreographer Anna Anderegg, dancer Elisa Pluta, soprano Xenia Romanova and costume designer Antoniya Ivanova.EuropeanTourVitruvianWith your help we are planning to tour with Vitruvian opera in Europe in 2014-2015.The tour includes participation in the International Art Festivalin Europe for which the performance was selected: STOFF August 14-17th, 2014,Stockholm; KineticArtFair October 16-19th, 2014,London; STEIMinAmsterdam.To be able to take part in these events we need your financial support to cover transportation and accommodation costs. The total amount is 3000 Euro for all three destinations (Stockholm, London, Amsterdam).InvitedSTOFF 2014Kinetica Art fair 2014STEIM AmsterdamTeamTatsuru Arai :concept, composition Arístides García :visulal-systemAnna Anderegg :choreography Antoniya Ivanova :costum Elisa Pluta :dance Xenia Romanova :sopranoconcept by Tatsuru AraiMy artistic approach falls within the category of “New-Renaissance Art” in which I am exploring how a Gesamtkunstwerk can coexist with recurrence/evolution, Human/Technology, organic/inorganic matter, Chaos/Order. Vitruvian uses real-time painting and a projection-mapping system; otherwise know as visualization. This performance features a singer and a dancer. The basis for the inspiration of my operetta Vitruvian is from the “Vitruvian man” of Leonardo da Vinci, where the piece attempts to make both an analysis and mapping of the human-body. The movements and vocalizations of the performers are mixed with different musical styles, which are composed and programmed with complex chaos systems/geometric forms/abstructuristic choreography and so forth. Beside this, the work is a combination of extremes and tries to induce the audience into an odyssey of perception.The Visualized Opera:Viruvian Melds Dance,Digital with Operettacomment by Peter Kirn Create Digital MotionGet ready for the high Renaissance of the digital.The individual ingredients remain the same. But the threads of transmedia work, spanning everything from traditional costume design and choreography to the latest generative projections, draw ever closer.A new generation of artists treats projection in the theater as something elemental, something that demands exploration.Vitruvian has gradually evolved in the ways it interweaves dance with opera, projected visualization and interactive sound with dance theater. An “interactive opera” in one act, it unapologetically adds digital imagery as an additional performer. But the human body insistently remains, in movement and voice, bathed in electronic light but not upstaged.Just reading the bios of these artists is telling. True to the Renaissance icon the piece references, Leonardo, these are artists who are coders and conventional artists, drawing primarily from neither source.The latest trailers and teasers give a bit of a taste of what they’re on, but consider this a preview. I think part of the challenge of this kind of work is that it tends to multiply the requirements for development and rehearsal geometrically. And it does that not only on the obvious technical side, but my making greater demands on the performers, too – it adds additional burden. But that’s also what makes it more exciting, and why I believe it’s essential to get these pieces in regular workshops and performances. Opera, the original transmedia spectacle, does the same: the convergence of different disciplines adds development atop development, even before you add digital technology.press CDMrecent performance 03.2013 “salon Revolutioner vol.3”Platoon kunsthalle Berlin(old version) 12.2013 “zoom focus” HfM Hanns Eisler Berlin (New version premiere) 02. 2014 “unrender” Lehrtersiebzehn Berlin "Vitruvian"(old trailer)

cooperation

Fellini Gallery Berlin


Platoon Kunsthalle Berlin


LEHRTERSIEBZEHN Berlin


HfM Hanns Eisler Berlin


klangzeitort


Quartet Berlin Tokyo

thanks

wooguru/Orhan Selamaz/Rebecca Uliczka/Natalia Medvedeva







Challenges
The Vitruvian team is challenging opera genre staging innovative performance combining opera, digital audio video technologies, and dance and mixing various styles. The European tour we are going to take part in in 2014-2015 will be a major step to present this innovative performance to a wider audience and push boundaries of opera genre.
In the future I will continue to develop experimental opera performances and present new opera Ergosum that is being composed at the moment. To keep working on these projects and explore new media performances I need and highly appreciate your support.

story:
This September in partnership with Bad New Days performing arts, The Kadozüké Kollektif is proud to present the world premiere of Richard III, The Pleasures of Violence   directed by Tatiana Jennings. We've been working on the piece since 2012 and we're excited to invite Toronto audiences to its full realization.

Richard III, The Pleasures of Violence marks The Kadozüké Kollektif's 10th Anniversary and it is their most ambitious project to date. The text of Shakespeare’s Richard III comes alive in an intimate performance mixing Kadozüké’s signature visual aesthetic with a stunning set designed by renowned Russian stage designer Vladimir Kovalchuk in collaboration with Tatiana Jennings along with cutting edge 3D projection mapping designed by Montgomery Martin.

Who we are

The Kadozüké Kollektif  ( ZUKÉ) is an ensemble of 9 actors led by of one of Canada's best kept secrets, Russian born and trained director Tatiana Jennings.
We've worked together year-round since 2004. We are dedicated to developing a theatrical language, which illuminates everyday reality and creates a poetic, visceral experience. 

How you can help us

With this critical contribution from you, our generous supporters, you will enable us to realize our most ambitious and technically complex project to date. 

Tatiana in collaboration with Vladimir Kovalchuk have developed a lego-like set, which will be assembled and re-assembled by the performers as part of an ongoing physical poetry of the space.

The avant garde design combined with the use of 3D-mapping technology will create a layered morphing landscape taking place on multiple levels of reality.

With your donations we will be able to bring our work to it's full potential.


Kadozüké’s Take on Richard

Richard III, The Pleasures of Violence will take a fresh, new look at Shakespeare’s time-worn classic.

Coincidentally, not long after we started working on the piece the real Richard III’s body was dug up in a parking lot in Leicester, England. New evidence discovered in the wake of our hero’s ‘excavation’ led us to look closer at the historical figure of Richard, his family and the real relationships between the people that inspired the characters in the Shakespeare’s play.  In our interpretation Richard III is a family story.  Skewed, incestuous and perverse.

The work engages nine performers in a moving Jenga game of “the family household” -- a claustrophobic environment plagued by death, manipulation, sex, black magic and white lies. 

The nine performers will remain on stage at all times. They dress, undress, shave, put on make-up. They cannot hide themselves as actors, rather, they are forced to openly transition between their various roles right in front of the audience.

      What will you be funding?

      A project of this size takes a lot of talented artists, production staff, equipment, set, props and time.

      We would like to show you how every penny is spent. Your support of our campaign will go towards:


        Set & Costume Design

        Set Construction, Materials and Labour - 3,000

        (steel pipe & sheet metal, plywood, labour) 

        Costumes for 9 performers - 1,500 

        (fabric, footwear, accessories, seamstress)

        Video Projection Mapping Design - 1,500 

        (programming time, use of software, computers)

        Equipment  

        Lighting & Projection Rentals - 800

        Production Team

        Stage Manager for a period of 6 weeks - 1,500

        Publicity - 2,500
        Artists
        The remainder of the funding will go towards artist salaries.
        (9 performers & Director, Designer)


      The work will feature Lacey Creighton, Caitlin Morris-Cornfield, Lee McDonald, Sefton Jackson, Scott Edwards, Dave Fish, Shawn Lall, Barbara Amponsah and Tyler Winn

      Tatiana Jennings is the director, choreographer, set and costume designer


      View Our 2012 Richard Workshop Trailer


      About The Producers

      The Kadozüké Kollektif

      Founded in 2004 by award winning director/choreographer Tatiana Jennings, The Kadozüké Kollektif is a Toronto theatre ensemble that works together year-round to develop and produce large-scale original work. We rehearse slowly and deliberately over a long period of time to develop our pieces, often producing them in stages. Our work is highly visual, and tells the story as much through the images as though the text. Our shows, often performed in site-specific locations are a unique experience for the public, inviting them to experience different perceptions of reality.

      In 2010 we acquired our own rehearsal and performance space in the Junction neighbourhood of Toronto. We are excited to be a part of this neighbourhood’s transformation and have begun to carve a niche as a cultural hub in the area.

      **To learn more about the ensemble, where they got their name and more about the collective's past productions please visit their website


      Adam Paolozza and Bad New Days performing arts

      Adam is a Dora award winning performer, director, writer and producer.

      In 2008 he created BAD NEW DAYS (originally called TheatreRUN) to produce his own projects. Since it's inception Bad New Days has created, developed and co-produced over 10 original productions - including Spent & The Double - exploring Adam's vision of a poetic theatre of gesture. www.badnewdays.com


      "I'm thrilled to be helping Tatiana and the company with this show. I can't think of another company in Canada that does what Kadozüké does. Their work is enigmatic, sexy, beautiful and funny. When watching a Kadozüké show one feels like a voyeur, peeking into another world that at once disturbs and fascinates us. The only reference I can think of is that it's like a theatrical Peter Greenaway film."

                                                                                                                     - Adam Paolozza

story:
The Show

The Producer's Club 

358 W 44th St, New York, NY 10036

December 1, 2014 @ 7 pm 

Order your tickets on brownpapertickets. PRESALE ONLY. 

The 2015 Senior Showcase will feature a variety of artistic mediums.

THE PLAY

Everything Must Go is a children's devised theatre production directed by Briana Schwartz and Assistant Directed by Zackary Kellet. The piece takes place on the 50% off self of a toy store where teddy bears have been placed and will be thrown away at the end of the night if they are not purchased. Written and performed by Kenny Bernisky, Brianna Egri, Vaughn Brodrick, and Rianna Ronquillo. The cast will also feature Brett Temple, Hailey Turiello, and Victoria Menendez. Prior to the piece, a childrens acting workshop will be conducted by the cast. 

THE FILM

The Wake, a short film written & directed by Brett Temple and produced by Rianna Ronquillo. In the aftermath of an event that disrupted a small suburban town, Riley’s best friends encourage her to ditch the wake. But something keeps drawing her back. Featuring Rianna Ronquillo, Hannah Suchomel, Dominic Mistretta and Vaughn Broderick.

THE SPOKEN WORD

Imani Redman will be showcasing her original physical theatre/performance art piece #IfTheyGunnedMeDown on how black youths deaths are portrayed and responded to in the media. Directed Written and Choreographed by herself and Rianna Ronquillo, with co-direction by Briana Schwartz. The piece will star Imani Redman, Hailey Turiello and Rianna Ronquillo as the main cast.

About Us

Novus Productions was formed in 2009 when a group of seniors attending MCVTS School of the Arts Theatre decided to bring their senior showcase outside of the small scope that is Middlesex County New Jersey. 5 years later, a new generation of seniors will be following in their footsteps.

What We’re Doing

The MCVTS Theatre Class of 2015 will be bringing their Senior Showcase to Manhattan this coming December to showcase the talents and abilities that they have learned over the course of their four years of high school.

Here’s Where You Come In

We need the help of anyone with money and sympathy for a group of students tackling a college level process on a high school budget. We are in need of set materials, costume and makeup, means of transportation, marketing materials, as well as a New York City venue. Think of the goals you set for yourself in your senior year of high school that you could have completed with a little bit of support!

Why It Matters

To wrap up their college applications, the senior class would like to add the finishing touch to their resumes: A piece completely produced and directed on their own, something that not many high school students have under their belt. They are using this piece as a farewell to their high school careers and as an introduction to their future lives as young artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand what it means to be tight on money, so don’t feel too bad about not being able to make a donation. However, don’t shy away from helping the cause!

Spread the word! Tell your friends about what we are doing by sharing our Indiegogo Campaign on your social media accounts!

COME SEE THE SHOW DECEMBER 1, 2014! 
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/898172. 
No tickets will be sold at the door. 


Who’s Who

Christa DeMaio(Technical Director) is a senior studying Technical Direction in Design and Production at MCVTS Theatre. Her theatre credits at MCVTS Theatre include: Assistant TD for The Education Project, Stage Manager for Shakespeare’s the Tempest, Stage Crew and Front of House for Winter Dance Concert 2014, Student Choreography Show 2014, Student Choreography Show 2013, Vivaldi’s Four Seasons, Spring Dance Show 2013, Winter Dance Show 2013, Student Choreography Show 2013, Spring Dance Show 2012, and Student Choreography Show 2012, and lastly Assistant Technical Director for New Plays Festival 2012. Christa hopes to go on to double major in both Theatre Technology and Architecture come Fall 2015.

Zack Kellett (Dramaturg/Projection Designer/Projection Operator/Producer) is a senior in the MCVTS Theatre program. He majors in Dramaturgy and technical operation. Previous MCVTS productions he has worked in include: 2012 Freshman Showcase, New Plays Festival 2012, The Tempest, and The Education Project. Zack seeks to take an alternative approach to his college education and career by taking the creative thinking of the arts and applying them to scientific processes.

Rebecca Niola (Stage Manager/Light Designer/Light Operator/Animator/Producer)

Imani Redman (Actor/Writer/Director/Choreographer/Producer) is a senior currently studying acting and playwriting. She began as a freshmen and returned to MCVTS her junior year. Previous MCVTS credits include The Education Project (Performer), Freshmen Showcase 2012 (Jane Agnus, Clarice) and New Plays Festival. She is currently a member of TDF’s playwriting workshop WordLab as well as a writer for TDF’s magazine PXP. Imani was a member of McCarters Theatre’s Summer Acting Intensive with Tarell Alvin McCraney and Solo Performance Workshop with Paula Alekson. She would like thank everyone who continues supporting her on her artistic journey.

Rianna Ronquillo (Actor/Producer/Marketing) is a senior actor. Since transferring to MCVTS Theatre her sophomore year, she has acted in The Education Project , Swagspeare, and The Tempest. Her first professional credit was Mirror Exercise (Fictional Films). Her production credits: she served as Production Assistant for Cake/ATEH Theatre's production of Learned Ladies and received her first paid internship as an Assistant House Manager with the help of Lucy DiRosa. She strives to be admitted into a BFA Acting program.

Briana Schwartz (Artistic Director/Director/Producer)  is a Senior majoring in Design and Production with a focus in directing. She began her time at MCVTS as an actor, performing in Freshman Showcase 2012 and The Tempest, in which she played Ceres. Her technical credits include New Plays Festival 2012, 2012 New Works Film Festival (Stage Hand), and Senior Showcase 2013 (Front of House), as well as recently gaining her first film experience as a production assistant in Fictional Films’ “Mirror Exercise”. She is a company member and directing fellow for the all girls theatre company, Girl Be Heard, located in New York where she assistant directed Estrogenius Festival: The Narrator of My Life. With Girl Be Heard, she has also performed her original pieces in Girl Be Heard Unplugged: Winter 2013. She most recently assistant directed MCVTS Theatre’s The Education Project which is where her passion for devised theatre started and inspired her senior showcase piece. She hopes to be admitted to a BFA Theatre Arts program focusing in directing within the next year.

Riley Stein (Sound Designer/Sound Engineer/Costume Designer/Animator/Producer) is a senior at MCVTS - School of the Arts. He's currently majoring in Design and Production with a focus on being an animator and or graphic novelist. Besides theatre work, he has been self producing his own graphic novel, CAPTOR, which can be read at captor.smackjeeves.com. Professional credits include None of the Above with Pegasus51 (Sound Engineer/Asst. Set Designer) Educational credits include The Education Project (Sound Engineer)  Freshman Showcase 2014 (Light Operator and Tech), Senior Showcase 2014 (Set and Costume Designer), The 2013 Film Festival (Exhibitor), The Tempest (Wardrobe, Asst. Costume and Asst. Set Design), Freshman Showcase2012 (Set and Costume Designer), and Fly in The 2012 New Play Festival (Projection Artist). He hopes to get into a BFA Animation program.

Brett Temple (Actor/Director/Writer/Producer) is finally a senior. At MCVTS he has been involved in a few shows: The Education Project, The Tempest, Swagspeare, The Tales of Dr. Hyde and Frankendoll, DMV Tyrant, Forty Minute Finish, The Truth About Us, New Play Development, and Crystal Skillman’s New. Outside of school Brett does some pretty cool stuff. He is a leading role in the feature-film, When The Moon Was Twice As Big and recently shot an episode for a new tv show on Discovery ID. Other Professional Credits: Teddy & Alice (Shadow Lawn Stage), Mirror Exercise (Fictional Films), Delirium (Do It Live Pictures), Hypnosis (New York Film Academy), Catfish 3.0 (Fencesitter Films), also some cool commercials with Escape Goat Productions and an ad for Toys-R-Us. Brett hopes to pursue a BFA in Acting and do some exciting things in life!

Brett hopes to pursue a BFA in Acting and do some exciting things in life!

story:
*Click above to hear cast and creatives discuss the The A-Z of Mrs P*

*AND hear Isy Suttie sing 'Lovely London Town' by visiting the gallery tab!*

'Best Foot Forward...'

In 1936, Phyllis Pearsall makes the life-changing decision to leave her husband in Venice and follow a new path to find her way in London.

She then receives a telegram from her father, map publisher Alexander Gross....

And here begins the story of how an eccentric Bohemian artist put down her paints and picked up the drawing board to follow in her beloved and impossible father’s footsteps to map an entire city!

The A-Z of Mrs P is a brand new musical fable, written by author/playwright Diane Samuels and composer/singer Gwyneth Herbert, based on Phyllis Pearsall's autobiographies. The show opens in the very same borough in which she was made a celebrated resident, at Southwark Playhouse on 21st February 2014.

'This is our time/My lovely London town...'

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Cast Recording

A cast album means that the show will have a life beyond the initial production. This is an original British musical with a unique soundscape, written by an all-female creative team - all these things are too rare in British Musical Theatre! Help us capture this landmark show with a world class company. £9000

Costumes

Phyllis Pearsall was famous for her colourful and eccentric style - we would love to stay true to her character and enhance our costume budget to do the woman justice! £1000

Very special Lighting Effects

This is something a little extra special to give the show that magical quality it deserves - we have a few lighting tricks up our sleeve that we would love to add onto Southwark Playhouse's rig. £1000

For all this we need your help! We are looking to raise £11,000 to cover all the costs of the recording including hire, production and marketing; the costume budget for Mrs P's outfits; and the extra lighting hire/creation to make this production as beautiful as it can be.

WHAT YOU GET!

We have some fantastic perks up for grabs as rewards for your generous donations. For just £5 you can have your name inscribed on the set of the show. We also have recorded demo songs and signed show goodies to send to you – including a copy of the cast recording of course! Tickets for the show, the press night party and question and answer sessions with the cast and production team are all available. 

We’ve also teamed up with the artist Su Blackwell who has created and donated the sculpture for the flyer, as well as Geographers' A-Z Map Company Limited who have very kindly donated vintage maps, original Phyllis Pearsall artwork and her hat, which Isy Suttie will wear in the production – all up for grabs! 

*An amazing chance is available for you or your company and business by becoming an Associate Producer of the cast recording: you will be there while we record, get a number of copies of the CD on which you will be fully credited, plus tickets to opening night.*

And finally Southwark Playhouse can be yours for the night with our premium reward – a performance of the show just for you and your closest friends (all 250 of them!). Have a look through the right hand side of the page to see what takes your fancy. We very much appreciate every donation made.

Please visit our 'Gallery' on the next tab to see images of some of the perks plus listen to Isy Suttie singing 'Lovely London Town' from the show under 'files'!

MEET THE TEAM!

Read below for thoughts from our fantastic cast and company!

CREATIVE TEAM

Playwright - Diane Samuels

Diane Samuels is a playwright and author, raised in Liverpool, now living and working in London. Plays include award-winning Kindertransport, touring nationally in 2014, The Arrest of Rosa Gold, Swine and recently BBC Radio 4 Woman's Hour five-part drama serial Tiger Wings. Her new book, Author's Guide to Kindertransport is published in Jan 2014 by Nick Hern Books.

"What a creative adventure writing The A-Z of Mrs P has been with Gwyn! Working closely together we have found inventive ways to interweave words, music, song storytelling, autobiography and mythology to create a seamless, flowing, highly theatrical and heartfelt show that is as much about family business as mapping a city."

Music and Lyrics - Gwyneth Herbert

Gwyneth Herbert is a mesmerising performer, writer of striking original songs and versatile musical adventurer, fleetingly inhabiting the worlds of the great singer-songwriters, jazz vocalists and traditional composers whilst never quite fitting easily into any of their camps. She has just been on tour around the UK promoting her acclaimed new album The Sea Cabinet.

“I’d never seen a musical before I started this crazy journey 5 years ago. Thing was, I loved stories, I loved music, I loved the theatre. And now, after working intensively and intimately alongside Diane exploring Mrs P’s own inspiring journey, I find myself in love with this huge beast of an art-form: its limitless possibilities for creative invention, the way you can plant one thought or feeling and make it shudder through the whole piece, music and words and action and visual art all weaving together. For me, I have found it’s the most multi-dimensional and exciting way to tell a magical story.”

Diane and Gwyneth are joined by musical arranger Sarah Travis (Tony Award for Sweeney Todd on Broadway).

Director - Sam Buntrock

Sam Buntrock is a theatre and film director, previously resident assistant director at the Donmar Warehouse. His many credits include the Olivier and Tony award nominated revival of ‘Sunday in the Park with George’ Menier Chocolate Factory/West end/Broadway, and ‘The Real Thing’ West End/Broadway.

Conceived by - Neil Marcus

Neil is Executive Director or Mercury Musical Developments and Artistic Director of London Festival Of Cabaret. Producing credits include Maria Friedman and Adam Guettel at The Hippodrome, Alexander Armstrong Celebrates The Great British Songbook at The St. James Theatre, Soho Cinders - Soho Theatre/Queens Theatre and Michael Feinstein at The Palace with Elaine Paige and Julian Ovenden.

‘5 years ago Gwyn and I had a drink at Kings Cross to discuss a possible musical about Phyllis Pearsall…and here we are! I hope you enjoy the show as much as we have enjoyed putting it together’

Set Designer - Klara Zieglerova

Klara's design credits include Sister Act and Jersey Boys(Broadway and West End). She has designed for the Public Theater, MTC, NYTW as well as numerous regional theatres in the US and has won many awards including The Green Room Award 2010 (Australia) and The Best Set Design of the 2009 Theatregoers’ Choice Award London (both for Jersey Boys) and 2005 Lumen Award (New World Stages). Klara is also the interior architect for New World Stages in NY.

'I’m fascinated by the story of one woman who by losing her way in London once has helped millions of others to find theirs. This piece is an homage to the human spirit as well as the city of London and I’m honored to be working with the authors, Gwyneth Herbert and Diane Samuels.'


 CAST

Isy Suttie - Mrs P

Sony award winner Isy is known to TV audiences as Dobby in Peep Show and Esther in Shameless (Channel 4). She is also a prolific musical comic and is currently recording series 2 of her BBC Radio 4 show, Isy Suttie’s Love Letters.

'I am very excited to be joining the Mrs P team. Although music features heavily in my comedy shows, The A-Z of Mrs P will be my first proper musical. As soon as I heard the song Lovely London Town, I felt that this to be a really special show that is as much about a gripping, funny and heartbreaking story as it is spectacle and wonder. Also I have literally no sense of direction so I’m hoping that by osmosis, by the end of the run I’ll be able to find my way home from the theatre without looking at my phone.'

Frances Ruffelle – Bella Gross

“I had heard the buzz about the A to Z and was intrigued to hear the music and read the script. Once I had read it, I couldn’t resist the opportunity to take this show out of its workshop state and to be privileged enough to perform it for the first time to the public.

'It’s a brilliantly written piece and I have to say that Bella, my role, is a wonderful part and she is just the sort of character I enjoy to play. She is Phyllis' mother - eccentric, artistic but tragic. In the show she ages from fifteen to forty-five which is certainly a challenge for any actress. Bring it on.”

Michael Matus – Sandor Gross

Recent work includes "The Sound of Music" (Regent's Park Open Air Theatre), "Yes Prime Minister" (UK tour) "Taboo" with Boy George,"Wonderful Town" with Sir Mark Elder and the Hallé, "Lend Me A Tenor" (West End) as well as 8 shows with the RSC, 2 with Shakespeare's Globe and created Benoit in "Martin Guerre".

This show fills me with a love of London, a rare, home-grown bit of magic with a brilliant score. And I get to be Frances Ruffelle's husband and Isy Suttie's Dad. There will be fireworks!!

The cast also includes: STUART MATTHEW PRICE (Parade, Shrek) as Phyllis’s brother Tony Gross; SARAH EARNSHAW (Wicked); DAWN SIEVEWRIGHT (Glasgow Girls), SIDNEY LIVINGSTONE (Acorn Antiques the Musical, Oklahoma!) and MAX GALLAGHER (History Boys - Colchester) is our latest addition!



Sarah Earnshaw

Stuart Matthew Price

Sidney Livingstone

Dawn Sievewright

PRODUCERS

Paul Tyrer & Jamie Clark for The Booking Office and Michael Peavoy Productions are producers of the show alongside Neil Marcus.

Paul Tyrer & Jamie Clark for The Booking Office

The Booking Office has become the foremost tour booking company working alongside many leading UK and International theatre producers. Recently and currently, they have created tours for The Mousetrap, Strictly Come Dancing’s Vincent & Flavia, The Siberian State Ballet of Russia, The Hairy Bikers with the BBC, See How They Run starring Warwick Davis and Pitcairn, a new Richard Bean play produced by Out of Joint, The Globe and Chichester Festival Theatre.

Current productions include; The Mummy (National UK Tour), Kindertransport (National UK tour, as associate producers), Peter James’ first stage adaptation The Perfect Murder (National UK tour, as associate producers) and more.

‘We are delighted to be part of this enigmatic fable – Phyllis is an inspiration simply because she was tenacious and determined – both in her pursuit of mapping London alongside her Father, but also in her ability to cope at home as part of a family with familiar strains and difficulties.  Her battles were big and small, public and private.  We all instinctively know her. The A-Z of Mrs P is a celebration of tenacity!’

Michael Peavoy Productions

Actor/Producer Michael Peavoy’s credits include Hamlet, National Theatre, Billy Elliot West End and UK Tour and Sweeney Todd, West Yorkshire Playhouse/Manchester Royal Exchange. Michael co-produced the twitter search for a composer and is currently developing Dougal Irvine’s new musical 'The Buskers Opera'.

WE WOULD LIKE TO THANK...

Geographers' A-Z Map Company Limited 

Started in 1936 as Geographers' Map Company Ltd, we are now the largest independent map publishing company in the UK, producing iconic products such as the London A-Z.

We produce over 340 mapping products and employ 40 staff, many of whom joined from school, and have been with the Company for over 25 years.

Our founder, Phyllis Pearsall MBE, gave us a motto- "ON WE GO" and as a team we can, and will, do just that, providing high quality mapping products and priding ourselves on customer satisfaction. Managing Directors: Steve Berger and Steve Egleton. 

‘We’re absolutely thrilled and delighted that the story of the pioneering  founder of our company is being shared through such a powerful platform. We’re certain that everyone involved in the production of the musical and all who come to see it will become as proud of Mrs Pearsall and her amazing achievements as we are’.

Steve Berger, Managing Director

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Thank you so much for visiting our campaign page – although you might not be able to purchase one of our rewards we still very much appreciate your support! Here are other ways you can help if not financially:

  • Building the set: we will be installing a drop off box at Southwark Playhouse from Tuesday 10th December every weekday Monday to Friday 5pm - 6pm where you can donate ‘all things London’; every day personal objects connected in some way to the city (the older they are the better!). We are looking for:

Postcards

Letters (written or received here)

Inscribed/stamped envelopes

Taxi receipts

Bus tickets

Tube tokens

Receipts

Guides

Books

Bills

Keys

Street signs

Notices

Old photos

Models of any kind (street lights, houses, cars/ trains)

  • We are also looking for 7 to 8 real London exterior doors from early 1900s, which can be well used! If you do happen to have one of these in your possession please email our Company Stage Manager Kathryn Rosendale companymanager2014@gmail.com to arrange collection.

(Draft image of the set by Klara Zieglerova)

  • We would of course love you to come and see the show: to book tickets visit: http://southwarkplayhouse.co.uk/the-large/the-a-z-of-mrs-p/

TICKETS: All previews £12 (20-23 February 2014). £22 / £18 concessions. Disabled people can bring one companion free of charge. BOX OFFICE: 020 7407 0234

  • Spread the word:  help us make the campaign widespread by telling everyone you know – use the Indiegogo share tools to create a buzz.

THANK YOU!

Again a big thank you from the whole A-Z of Mrs P team!

The A-Z of Mrs P – mapping an entire city in a foot tapping new British musical

story:
Who am I?

Hello! I'm Imogen Stirling and I'm bringing my spoken word show, #Hypocrisy, to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2018.

I'm a Scottish spoken word performer, musician and theatre maker. Following an extensive music tour of mainland Europe, I broadened my horizons and began creating and reading poetry for audiences in Berlin. Returning to Scotland, I swiftly garnered acclaim within our country's spoken word scene and since then have appeared in venues all around the UK. I will be coming to Edinburgh fresh from an extensive UK tour with poetry/music collective Words w/ Friends. Having previously been involved in the Fringe extravaganza as part of a company, I am thrilled to be bringing my first solo creation to the capital. 

This will be the show's absolute, ultimate debut - I'm looking for your help to make the ambition a reality.
 

 

What's the show?

#Hypocrisy is a response to the bizarre world we're living in. One where dangerous politicians prevail, where the media constantly sells us fictions masquerading as realities, where an ocean of social media sympathy can pour forth for Western terror victims but backs turn on the migrant crisis. It’s a world full of staggering hypocrisies. 

The format of #Hypocrisy is unique. It’s a blend of spoken word poetry, dark comedy and completely original music throughout. The show is presented from my perspective as a young white woman. Beginning by looking into my experiences travelling as a musician through Europe (during which time I often found myself reaping the benefits of my skin colour) it opens up to explore what is evidently becoming an increasingly racist world. The show is a contemplation and an interrogation of western privilege. It's an exposure of hypocrisy and a reminder of perspective. It is provocative, uplifting but funny too! It hands us back our own responsibility and reminds us to respond to people as people. I think it is an important piece to perform at this time.


What do I need?

I'm trying to keep the budget as low as possible but, with the Fringe, some costs are unavoidable! These include:

  • Registration costs
  • Fair fees for all collaborating artists
  • Accommodation 
  • Travel expenses
  • Props and equipment
  • Promotion (flyers, posters and social media campaigns)
  • Merchandise
  • A videographer to document the show

As incentives to contribute to this campaign, I have perks on offer to accommodate every budget. These range from personal shout outs to a featured cameo role in the show (you heard that right...).

Any amount reached below the set target will still be a huge help, while anything above will be invaluable in supporting the future of #Hypocrisy, post-Fringe.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many non-financial ways to support #Hypocrisy. 

Word of mouth is invaluable. Tell your family! Tell your friends! Get the show out there!

Follow me on social media where I'll be documenting the show's progress.

Share this campaign far and wide to generate attention. 


Thank you so much for your support of #Hypocrisy.

I'm a Scottish spoken word performer, musician and theatre maker. Following an extensive music tour of mainland Europe, I broadened my horizons and began creating and reading poetry for audiences in Berlin. Returning to Scotland, I swiftly garnered acclaim within our country's spoken word scene and since then have appeared in venues all around the UK. I will be coming to Edinburgh fresh from an extensive UK tour with poetry/music collective Words w/ Friends. Having previously been involved in the Fringe extravaganza as part of a company, I am thrilled to be bringing my first solo creation to the capital. This will be the show's absolute, ultimate debut - I'm looking for your help to make the ambition a reality. 

 

What's the show?
#Hypocrisy is a response to the bizarre world we're living in. One where dangerous politicians prevail, where the media constantly sells us fictions masquerading as realities, where an ocean of social media sympathy can pour forth for Western terror victims but backs turn on the migrant crisis. It’s a world full of staggering hypocrisies. 
The format of #Hypocrisy is unique. It’s a blend of spoken word poetry, dark comedy and completely original music throughout. The show is presented from my perspective as a young white woman. Beginning by looking into my experiences travelling as a musician through Europe (during which time I often found myself reaping the benefits of my skin colour) it opens up to explore what is evidently becoming an increasingly racist world. The show is a contemplation and an interrogation of western privilege. It's an exposure of hypocrisy and a reminder of perspective. It is provocative, uplifting but funny too! It hands us back our own responsibility and reminds us to respond to people as people. I think it is an important piece to perform at this time.

What do I need?
I'm trying to keep the budget as low as possible but, with the Fringe, some costs are unavoidable! These include:

Registration costs
Fair fees for all collaborating artists
Accommodation 
Travel expenses
Props and equipment
Promotion (flyers, posters and social media campaigns)
Merchandise
A videographer to document the show

As incentives to contribute to this campaign, I have perks on offer to accommodate every budget. These range from personal shout outs to a featured cameo role in the show (you heard that right...).
Any amount reached below the set target will still be a huge help, while anything above will be invaluable in supporting the future of #Hypocrisy, post-Fringe.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
There are many non-financial ways to support #Hypocrisy. 
Word of mouth is invaluable. Tell your family! Tell your friends! Get the show out there!
Follow me on social media where I'll be documenting the show's progress.
Share this campaign far and wide to generate attention. 
Thank you so much for your support of #Hypocrisy.

story:
Play synopsis: Choi and Rhoul haven’t seen Marty in a while. Then, over coffee and a stale muffin, he casually tells them he has cancer. And he wants to go to Hawaii. MARTY HAS CANCER is a dark comedy about friendship, coming-of-age (in your 30’s), and the absurdity of “American Idol.”

The goal: Our aim, with the help of four actors, some creativity, and (hopefully) an audience, is to produce the world premiere and Utah premiere of this bizarre, funny, and heart-wrenching play. 

We would love to bring this story to audiences at the Hollywood Fringe Festival and Great Salt Lake Fringe Festival this summer, but Prufrock is just getting on its feet. Basically, toddling.

With a bit of help, Director Madeleine Gail Rex, Playwright Austin Archer, and others involved are confident we can bring something both entertaining and thought-provoking to audiences in these communities.

What your donation will do: Any money raised will be used first for festival fees, production costs, basic marketing needs, and, potentially, travel expenses. Once these costs are satisfied, and should there be remaining funds, we would hope to set those aside for future Prufrock Productions projects. To be clear, no money raised through this campaign will be used to pay artists; such payment will only come from ticket sales. Essentially, it is through aid with these other expenses that we will be able to use ticket sales for this purpose.

What we can give you: A whooooole lot of gratitude! We'll thank you in the program for any donation of $10 or more, for $20 Austin will send you a personalized thank you letter and a photo of him doing anything you want. ANYTHING. Except for skydiving. Or scuba-diving. Nothing too expensive. Okay there's a lot of things he won't do, but a lot he might. Donate $25 or more, and you can join the cast, playwright, and other creatives for an after party following the close of the SLC Fringe production. There will be music, appetizers, and, you know, lots of good stuff. But mostly, we'll love you forever.

story:
The power of individual story can do more than incite dialogue - it can be a call to action.  This July Convergence Theatre returns to their Guerrilla Theatre Works series to follow four immigration stories, providing light into the complexities of "home".  A New Nation will open at the Anacostia Arts Center on Saturday, July 7th and will run through Sunday, July 29th.  To fully realize this work's layered artistic languages, Convergence Theatre, a non-profit organization, seeks the support of DC Theater patrons and the artistic community through this grassroots campaign. Through this campaign, Convergence Theatre will be able to: 

  - Provide accessible, affordable theater to a wide audience in the DC community (under $20).

- Be able to fully compensate all  the artists/designers/directors working on this project and purchase needed materials.

 - Bring visibility and provide support to organizations that serve the immigrant community.

Past production partnerships demonstrate Convergence Theatre's commitment to community engagement and social justice. Partners such as Art Enables,  The Arc of Northern Virginia, Walk One Day in Our Shoes, Domestic Violence Resource Project and Stop Modern Slavery DC are just a few organizations that have joined with Convergence to activate theater outside the performance. A New Nation continues to extend performance into practice, making it possible for everyone to be an active force for change by providing activities and resources. We are excited to be joining organizational forces with Just Neighbors and Public Justice Center through this production.

We know that partnerships make it easier for the individual audience member to be a part of the change they see onstage.  We saw this happen through our production of This Is All Just Temporary and the Converging Minds partners that lead the community through mindful action.  Your tax deductible donation will help all of us be the change we need in the world today!  Donations of any amount are greatly appreciated.  Please also share the word - post on social media, send email and join our conversations on our Facebook page.

Convergence Theatre is a Section 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation. Donations may qualify as charitable deductions for federal income tax purposes.

story:
LET US NOW PRAISE SUSAN SONTAG is the inaugural production for the 7 Daughters of Eve Thtr & Perf Co.  We are so excited to be presenting this original work, written and directed by Sibyl Kempson, at Abrons Arts Center as part of the launching of this theater company.  The show opens on April 28 and runs through May 17. With your help, we will be able to pay our performers what they deserve to be paid, as well as fund the physical aspects of this play including sets, costumes, and a live band!

We are asking for $15,000 from you to pay for artist fees, and set and costume production needs.  Any contributions made here through Indiegogo are sponsored by Abrons Arts Center/Henry Street Settlement and are tax-deductible.

We have received a generous grant from the Jerome Foundation to get us started, but it only covers part of what we need to pay the incredible performing and design artists involved.  We have raised about half of what we need to pay our 9 performers and two band members, and still need to raise the money to pay the top notch designers, our composer and our choreographer. Though almost all involved are veterans in their fields, this is our first time out as a company, so we've kept costs very lean. Writer/director Sibyl Kempson is able to forego payment altogether for this project, thanks to a USA Artists Rockefeller Fellowship awarded to her this year, and Abrons Arts Center is providing us with free use of their rehearsal space and theater, plus marketing and PR in-kind contributions. Development of the play has been shouldered by workshops at New Dramatists, Duke University, and Sarah Lawrence College. So all of the money we are hoping to raise goes directly to the people involved in the production.

Amanda Villalobos is designing some fabulous t-shirts to help launch the company. She is a world-renowned graphic designer who designed and illustrated the 53rd State publication of Kempson's THE SECRET DEATH OF PUPPETS & ICH, KÜRBISGEIST in 2012. She also happens to be playing the role of "Jean Ann" in LET US NOW PRAISE SUSAN SONTAG! So one of the perks will be a wonderful t-shirt that Amanda is making.

You could also garner an original cast recording of Ashley Turba's dizzying songs for LET US NOW PRAISE SUSAN SONTAG.

Or what about a special seed-planting ceremony using the guaranteed methods depicted in the play?

This is the first time I've ever done any kind of a fundraising campaign - in fact, I've never asked anyone outside of the INSTITUTIONS to donate money to any of my productions! And oh, man. It ain't easy for a lady to ask for help in this day and age, in these tough times - I'm terrified! But as I embark on the adventure of starting this company, the importance and the urgency of what we are setting out to do pushes me before you to ask for your support.

As a playwright, I am looking to counter the narratives of American mass culture, to multiply interpretations of the signs surrounding us, to upend preconceptions of gender, genre, structure, language, and space - to call into question our perceptions of the civilized in relation to ideas of the barbaric, in relation to ideas and preconceptions of the sacred, the profane, the true, the ordinary, and the animate. This particular play is about our relationship to the land we live on, what it gives us and what we give it, and it also contains a vision of possibility, of how things COULD and CAN be in our relationship to this land. My hope is that we can start to work together, using new narratives made together in our collective imagination, to steer our human progress in a direction that we can really actually truly feel good about. And this piece is my first step in making a space for that kind of imagining.

The decision to begin this company has come about at the years-long urging of fellow artists who I trust, who have really pushed me toward taking this action to realize the visions contained in my own writing more clearly. For me it's a return to the way I began doing it earlier on in 1999, but this time with added experience from the incredible collaborations I've enjoyed in the years since and with the renewed encouragement from colleagues, students, mentors, and family. Even more importantly, it gives me the opportunity to more actively curate the assemblage of humans in the room with whom I am working. That's already proved (proven?) to be enormously exciting and rewarding. Hope you'll join me in applauding and making possible their stunning presence. 

$15K is a lot of money to be raising this way! Honestly, I have very little sense of whether it's actually possible or not. We simply came up with the number based on what we need to pay the people involved what they deserve to be paid for the work they are putting in. I am late getting this campaign underway because I feel VERY VERY SHY about asking ANYONE for ANYTHING! But once we started rehearsals and I started working with this group of human beings, each with their own love to lavish on the world through the work they do, each so enormously expressive, flexible, funny, vulnerable and outrageous, full of questions, many of whom are hiring babysitters and packing their lunches, it lit a new fire under my butt to get this money raised to pay these remarkable humans for their contribution. 

And then I think of all the people I know, and how much encouragement I've received in this tough, tough world of making artwork in NYC over the years - from friends, relatives, co-workers, employers who have watched me schlep and grunt and heard me whine and cry and shout as I build all the stuff, I think, "Oh, hell. The answer's always 'no' until you ask." So we're just going to give this a try and see what happens!

So, do you feel like you'd like to help but just don't have the dough to cough up? Well, maybe you wouldn't mind helping me get the word out about the piece and the fundraising campaign! No pressure, but they at Indiegogo provide "share tools" of some kind that can help you to do so.

Or just show your support by coming to see the show! April 28 - May 17 at Abrons Arts Center, NYC. Tickets available here: http://www.abronsartscenter.org/performances/si...

Thanks very much for your support, monetary and otherwise.

Sibyl

story:
I'm Jessica Lucia Andrade, a British Asian Actress and aerialist. I've created a new show called The Brownie Club, combining spoken word, physical theatre and aerial circus. The Brownie Club is based on events that have happened to me because of my skin tone, and explores how those events have affected me. This campaign aims to raise funds to provide free tickets for young people of colour to come and see the show, as well as to offer free workshops to explore some of the shows' themes. I want young people to have opportunities and positive experiences that I didn't always get the chance to, because they are the future.

I'm using the term ‘people of colour' because I'm talking about the things I've experienced based on my skin tone, and that has always been associated with the colour brown. I have always called myself brown and celebrate that fact, and I would also describe myself as Asian, South Asian and Goan. I would love people of all races, ethnicities, and genders to come and see the show as I want to have a conversation with the audience as well as talk about my own personal experiences. This can sometimes be a difficult conversation but it doesn't need to be if we come from a place of understanding each others circumstances. I am encouraging young people of colour to come and see the show because they are not often reflected in our audiences, and in that conversation.   

What We Need & What You Get

We've already budgeted £150 to enable 20 young people of colour to come and see The Brownie Club for free, and we'd love to be able to provide at least 60 more free tickets throughout the run.  We also want to offer free workshops to local secondary schools and local youth groups, to explore the themes of the show. 

If we raise less than £400, all the money will go directly towards offering free tickets to young people of colour to see the show. Once we exceed £400, the money will be divided between free tickets and workshops. How much we raise will directly inform how many tickets, and how many workshops we can offer. The money for the workshops will cover staff to assist with facilitation and an education consultant to help us plan, coordinate and deliver them.  We'd love more than anything to exceed our target, and if we do, we'll simply buy more free tickets and offer more workshops!

We've got some perks on offer to show how grateful we are for your support. These include some awesome signed images and posters from the show, an invitation to attend an open rehearsal, behind the scenes tours, and free tickets. 

This project means a lot to me as when I was younger I rarely saw people like myself in the worlds of Theatre, circus, performance and mainstream media, and I therefore had no idea they were available to me.  I want to be part of the change that means younger generations don't have this experience. The Brownie Club is my way of making that change. I want younger generations to be positively encouraged that they can do anything they put their mind to in the same way I did.  It takes hard work and determination but there are support networks out there to reach your goals. 

I've been teaching aerial, circus and gymnastics in boroughs across London and understand the benefits of physical and creative arts. To have a teacher that understands and nurtures your drive, ambitions and talent is really important.

I came across aerial circus though an outreach programme with Upswing aerial when they were doing a call out for BAME actors and dancers.  From that opportunity they mentored me and encouraged me to train and develop my artistry, since then I have gone on to perform professionally, and lead classes and workshops for them.

I'm also working with a brilliant producer, Jo Mackie, to help produce the project. Jo has been producing dance, circus and theatre shows since 2013 and has run a number of high profile education and outreach projects with The Old Vic and Almeida. We've been working as a team since the beginning of 2018 and we're super confident we can pull this off - your support will just make the sky the limit!

Risks & Challenges

With the brilliant, co-producing support of Jacksons Lane, a huge amount of development support from Proteus Theatre, and an incredible team of artistic collaborators, as well as funding from Arts Council England already in place, there are little to no risks in this campaign. With funding secured, we're already making the show, and we've started to build some links with local schools and organisations who are keen to take up the offer of free tickets for their networks of young people, including WAC (Weekend Arts Centre) and the Young London Goan Society. We have a degree of flexibility as to when we run the workshops, which means that as and when we know how much money we've raised, we can begin planning and coordinating them. Jacksons Lane are already holding 20 seats for us, which is the amount we've already built into our budget. They're ready to put more on reserve as and when the crowd funder raises money. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone will be able to make a financial contribution towards this project. However, your support in sharing this campaign will make a huge difference, and we'd love you to come and see the show and tell us what you think! Another way you can really help is by giving me a follow on social media, keeping an eye out and sharing information about the show to others. 

Thank-you from Team Brownie Club, and we hope to see you at the show! 

Jess x

Twitter: @JessyLAndrade

Facebook: Jessica Lucia Andrade Artist

Instagram: @JessyLAndrade // @TheBrownieClubShow

Thank-you from Team Brownie Club, and we hope to see you at the show! 
Jess x
Twitter: @JessyLAndrade
Facebook: Jessica Lucia Andrade Artist
Instagram: @JessyLAndrade // @TheBrownieClubShow

story:
Short Summary

We (Shelley Farmer and Alex Hare) are theatre artists who began collaborating on this project based on Shelley's experience as a teenage fanatic of the groundbreaking films of the French New Wave -- films like Jean-Luc Godard's Breathless and Pierrot le Fou, Agnes Varda's Cleo from 5 to 7, and Truffaut's Shoot the Piano Player -- who then grew up to question the politics of these films and the world around her. The play uses live-feed filming (sometimes controlled by a cameraman, sometimes by audience volunteers)  to explore the connection between how women are captured on camera and how women are treated behind the scenes, on the street, in daily life, etc. Movies have shaped the way we look at each other, and while it can be wonderful to be looked at, it is also dangerous. It seemed worthwhile to gather a group of people together in a theatre to take a look at that dynamic in action, as well as to dream up alternatives to the narrowness of the male gaze.

We've assembled a team of inventive designers and committed actors, and we're raising money to ensure that 1) they are paid for their labor and 2) they have the resources to realize their essential roles in making this show. While the French New Wave was seen as an auteur-driven movement, we are striving to create a more egalitarian experience, and that means lifting up our team, which includes:

Greg Balla (actor), Erin Healani Chung (actor), An-lin Dauber (set/costume designer), Shelley Farmer (actor/co-writer), Jennifer Fok (lighting design), Michael Gildin (composer), Madeleine Goldsmith (producer), Alex Hare (director/co-writer), Abraham Marlett (stage maanger), Adam Weppler (actor), John Zhao (film consultant)

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

The money will go to:

1) $1,870 - fees for our actors, set/costume designer, lighting designer, sound designer, stage manager, and other staff 

2) $1,100 - Set, costumes, video technology, and lighting equipment

3) $200 - Marketing costs (digital, postcards, posters)

That's all! 

The Impact

The present moment is one of rare frankness about the structural disadvantages, obstacles, and abuses that women face in the entertainment industry (along with other industries). We want to be a part of that discussion from a different angle, using cinematic language as a lens. We also strive to harness the power of theatre to serve as a space where people of all or no genders can dream together about a better world, one in which a multiplicity of gazes is valued. We're sincerely grateful to anyone who is interested in helping us make that come to life.

And if you can't donate, we understand! We've been there. Sharing this Indiegogo page with people who might be interested in donating is hugely appreciated.

story:
Help Justine return to the source!

Justine Lemos, PhD, (that's me, director of Nataraj West) has been studying and performing classical Indian dance in the lineage of Guru Ranjanaa Devi for 18 years. Such an intense and long-term relationship with a Guru (teacher) is rare in the contemporary world. It is my artistic path to learn and embody as much of my Guru's vast repertoire as I possible in my lifetime.  I regularly perform throughout the US including annual performances in Mendocino, CA. This fall My teacher, Guru Ranjanaa Devi, has given me an opportunity to study choreographies to expand my repertoire by traveling to the East Coast twice for dance intensives. I will travel to study dance with her in October and in November. Please support this campaign so I can continue to study with my teacher and that I might continue to offer performances of classical Indian dance to our community.

This is the deal:

  • Nataraj West will raise $1000 to offset travel costs to the East Coast, guru dakshina (payment to one's teacher), and as seed money for a performance in Mendocino of new (to me) choreography
  • All sponsors will be listed on our website and in playbills. All donations are tax-deductible.
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal we still can use funds to offset travel costs. 

The Impact

  • My teacher's lineage is precious. Please help me preserve these teachings. 
  • If you loved our Bhakti performance of classical Indian dance and Music here is a chance to support this sacred art in our community.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
    • Just use the share tools! It is easy!

story:
Short Summary

WE WILL NOT BE ABLE TO ACQUIRE THE RIGHTS! Please don't donate. Unfortunately the rights to the script are not available right now. We will refund those who have donated when the campaign ends. Our deepest apologies and we hope we can put on a great show for you in the coming future.




"Skill and talent and the balls to arrive at your own conclusions." 

-American Buffalo by David Mamet.

This winter we will be launching a stage production of David Mamet’s American Buffalo in a Chicago venue. Mamet’s play is a character piece, set in Chicago. It’s a 3-man show that brings us inside the lives of an everyday American in Don’s resale shop. One of Mamet’s earlier pieces of work, it is credited with working “The iambic pentameter out of the vernacular of the underclass.” It is a play rich in language, character, meaning and cultural significance. The New York Post called it “a gripping and exciting play which provides the richest and best qualities of theater experience.”

 We could not be more excited for our performance, but we’re going to do things a bit differently.

There will be three different performances. Our actors will switch roles every night.

 That means three opportunities for you to see three different performances of one incredible show.

3 nights, 3 actors, 3 roles, 3 entirely unique performances.

  • As artists, it is important to find plays that challenge us and make us grow. American Buffalo is one of those plays. Not only is it an amazing show for artists to perform, but it is a story that shines a light on the types of people in our society that we see every day on the streets, but never notice. It is an underdog story, sprinkled with realistic irony that makes for a great dark comedy.
  • With your contribution we will be able to put on the play. With a little bit MORE of your contribution we'll be able to make the play look great!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise enough money to pay for the performance rights to the script. Without your help we will not (legally) be allowed to perform the play in public.

The rest of the contributions will go toward building the set and making the costumes and other technical production needs.

If we make our full goal, we will also be able to fund advertisement’s, such as posters, flyers, and postcards.

 I (Tess, the director) have worked with Mamet's text before, and have directed several plays and short films. The actors are well seasoned, although they look young! Our crew is incredibly passionate with resumes that make me feel like I should step up my game! I believe that this show will be more than just a successful play.

The Impact

This is a great opportunity for us as artists, but also for our community. David Mamet is a Chicago raised writer, director, and actor, this play is in a way a portrait of the working class of the city. This play focuses on the seedy characters in our society and gives us some insight into the lives of those we might ignore. Even if you’ve never heard of Mamet or American Buffalo, even if you’re not from Chicago, you will be able to relate to the everyday struggle of the American dream present in this script. We will be able to give the people in our community a chance to see an exciting new take on a very relevant and powerful play. 

.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest obstacle is securing a venue. We need your funding to make our performance a reality. With your help we can rent a performance space and get to work! However, if worse comes to worst, we can probably find a church, school or library that likes us!

The second biggest obstacle is securing the rights. If we don’t raise the funds in time, it is possible for another company to buy out the rights for a winter show. If that is the case we will have to push our performance into the spring.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money we have options for you!

You can share (Indiegogo tool) the link to this campaign, WITH EVERYONE YOU LOVE!

You could also get in touch with us about donating set pieces. The play takes place in a pawn shop, so if you have a few boxes in your basement with old-school/broken artifacts that you have just never brought to the thrift store, we'd love to see them!
