story:
The Crowbait Club

In 2012 The Crowbait Club (CBC) was founded in Portland, Maine with a specific mission: bring the performing arts community together on a monthly basis and encourage newcomers to explore the arts.

How? By giving people a barrier free, no pressure experience in the arts. The monthly CBC Deathmatch is simple to understand yet hard to master. Audience members can submit a ten minute play, act, watch or all three. The plays and the actors are chosen at random. The playwright has two minutes to brief their cast and then it's go time. Ten plays are read over the course of the evening. At the end of the show, the audience votes with their applause for best actor and best play The winning play becomes part of the lineup for our annual short play festival: King of Crows. 

Because to be in it, you have to win it. And anyone, ANYONE can come and be part of the excitement. It is not unheard of for a newcomer to walk in and win with a great script or give a terrific acting performance and take home the Best Actor award.

We have discovered that the audience is a very good judge indeed. They know what they like. And every year we take the scripts they have chosen and fully produce them in our notorious short play festival, King of Crows.


King of Crows III : Long Live the King

The annual King of Crows show has been very popular. It also gets more expensive every year. This year, King of Crows is moving to the St Lawrence Arts Center so we can offer more seats, add more technical elements and help the playwrights and directors realize their unique visions.

This year King of Crows III: Long Live The King will be held at the St Lawrence Arts Center, 76 Congress St, Portland, ME on September 3-5, 2015

We are asking for funding in the amount of 2,500 dollars. These funds will help us pay for the hall and a very small stipend for the actors, musicians, crew, and staff. Not to mention the countless small expenses that occur in mounting a creative endeavor like this: funny hats, lighting gel, gaffers tape, strange props and the like. Whether the goal is met, exceeded, or not, all funds will be used for production expenses or saved for King of Crows IV.

2,500 dollars covers about 40% of the show's cost. The rest is funded by saved funds from previous King of Crows shows and our monthly Deathmatches. Crowbait Club runs a tight ship financially: it's five leaders are not paid and they even pay out of their own pockets every month for the silly prizes awarded to the Deathmatch winners. 

What about perks? We've got them! Simple and to the point. Give $35 and get two tickets to your show of choice. This perk includes a $5 donation to the cause and our heartfelt gratitude for your support. $50 gets you KOC III's "Dropping Crowns" poster beautifully designed by Lynne Cullen. $100 is the price for the poster signed by the company and two tickets to the show of your choice. The tip top is $200: you get two tickets to the show of your choice, the poster signed by the company AND the legendary original Deathmatch logo T-shirt designed by founder Cullen McGough in your size.

What's not to love?


Why Should I Care?

Because we care.  And caring is important.

Because we are passionate about playwriting, acting and all the associated crafts the theater contains.

Because in 2012, three artists came together to figure out a way to make an arts opportunity accessible to anyone who wanted to try it. And they did it. With their own time and out of their own pockets. It's a party, it's an instantaneous literary event, it's cutting edge theatre and it's a chance to try something new and different without any barriers whatsoever. 

People measure success in different ways. We are proud that our Deathmatches have generated over 320 new ten minute plays. We are proud that some of these plays have found production not only in King of Crows but coast to coast. We are proud that actors whose first experience on the stage was at CBC are now working actors in our community.

We are proud that we can do this cheaply and effectively. The cost of admission to a Deathmatch is $5.00. Five dollars. To write, act, watch or all three. When we say we want to kick down barriers to participation in the arts, we absolutely mean it.

Do you love the arts? Then please consider a donation so we can continue doing what we do.


Other Ways You Can Help

That's the pitch. Thanks for reading it. We understand that sometimes money is tight. If you can't contribute to the cause, please talk us up, share this campaign with the IndieGoGo tools or like our page on Facebook. We would be grateful.

Check us out on Facebook at The Crowbait Club

Visit us on the web at thecrowbaitclub.org

But most importantly...


Get with us!

Do any of the above activities sound like fun to you? Do they sound like something you've always wanted to try? Get with us!

Crowbait Club's Monthly Deathmatch is held at Mayo Street Arts, 10 Mayo St, Portland, ME, the first Wednesday of every month except September. 7:30 to 10 pm 

Come with a ten minute play, come to act, or just come to watch the fun. Admission is $5.00 cash at the door.

The August Deathmatch theme is "The Feeling is Mutual" 

Consider yourself invited. :)


Credits:
Artistic Director - Elizabeth Chasse
Producing Director - Michael Tooher
Music Director - Victoria Stubbs
CBC Committee Members - Charlie Cole
                                                        Jody McColman
All KOC III art by Lynne Cullen
Original Deathmatch logo by Cullen McGough

story:
Short Summary

Before "I Love Lucy", he loved Lucy.

Love is a thread that weaves together everything about this production! It has been in the loving hands of Robert Bartley and Danny Whitman for a number of years, and now it is time to make its full production debut at Pegasus Theatre, in Dallas, TX.  We're thrilled our friends and colleagues at Pegasus have thrown their heart and soul into this project! Pegasus Theatre has been in operation since 1985 and has an impressive track record with large and small productions. If you're local to the DFW area, you've more than likely seen at least one of their signature Living Black & White™ stage shows.  In January of this year, they were even featured on the TODAY Show!

Make no mistake, this will be a full-scale Broadway-style musical!  Pegasus has produced musicals in the past, but those shows were relatively small as their previous space didn't allow for a large cast onstage at a given time.  Today, working out of the beautiful Eisemann Center in Richardson, TX, as they have for the past twelve years, Pegasus has the opportunity to fill that space with an incredible new musical. More singing, more dancing, and more color than ever before!

Pegasus will be mounting the first fully staged production of this charming love story. The Cuban & The Redhead will bring to life the heartwarming story of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz long before "I Love Lucy" hit the air waves.

With your contributions, we can make sure this production gets the star treatment it deserves!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,000 to make this dream a reality.  That may seem like a lot, but it's only 10% of the total cost. Musicals are expensive to produce, and this one is no exception. There are costs we have never encountered before: paying a 25-person cast, costuming and wigging that 25-person cast, body microphones, a music director, a band, extra lighting and sound equipment, etc.   

"But what do I get?" We hear you.  That's a lot of money to ask for. For varying levels of contributions, you'll get:

  • Access to Behind-the-Scenes information
  • Your name listed in our program
  • VIP tickets to the show
  • A signed photo of the cast
  • A signed copy of the musical score
  • A signed copy of the script
  • A backstage meeting with our Lucy and Desi after a performance
  • Meeting with the show creators
  • AND MORE!

The Impact

Pegasus Theatre's mission statement has always focused on bringing new comedies to life.  There's nothing more steeped in comic gold than Lucille Ball.  But her story (and Desi's) haven't always been the bust-a-gut rollicking misadventures their show gave us.  Robert and Danny have worked on this show for years, fine-tuning and rewriting, to make sure this is the pinnacle of perfection. This has been a labor of love for these two and Pegasus Theatre is more than excited to mount this show.

Pegasus Theatre has been in operation for more than 30 years.  Our original Living Black & White ™ series has been a staple of the Dallas theater scene for ages.  And since our move to the Eisemann Center, our shows have gotten bigger, more technically refined, and grayer than ever before.  We have deft hands handling our big-budget shows, and this one proves to be no exception.  The only problem we have is that our coffers such as they are just won't support the extra needs of a large-scale musical.  And that's why we NEED you.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute very much financially, there are more ways for you to help Pegasus Theatre reach our goal. Share, Share, Share! It's a numbers game. If we were to email every single person on our email list, statistics say only 2% will respond with a donation.  Not a huge number, right?

Well, if you share this on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, we can expand our reach. Who do you think would enjoy a show about Lucy and Desi? Did you grow up watching the show live? Do you want to introduce your kids, your grandkids, to this comic couple? DO YOU LOVE LUCY?

We've set up dedicated accounts on these social media platforms to be accessible! Check out our links to find us and follow our progress.

Pegasus Theatre on FaceBook

On Twitter @CubanandRedhead    

On Instagram @TheCubanandTheRedhead

If you can contribute to our campaign, thank you. We are so excited about this leap we are making. It's a thrilling and daunting leap, and we know we can do it with your help.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Before "I Love Lucy", he loved Lucy.
Love is a thread that weaves together everything about this production! It has been in the loving hands of Robert Bartley and Danny Whitman for a number of years, and now it is time to make its full production debut at Pegasus Theatre, in Dallas, TX.  We're thrilled our friends and colleagues at Pegasus have thrown their heart and soul into this project! Pegasus Theatre has been in operation since 1985 and has an impressive track record with large and small productions. If you're local to the DFW area, you've more than likely seen at least one of their signature Living Black & White™ stage shows.  In January of this year, they were even featured on the TODAY Show!
Make no mistake, this will be a full-scale Broadway-style musical!  Pegasus has produced musicals in the past, but those shows were relatively small as their previous space didn't allow for a large cast onstage at a given time.  Today, working out of the beautiful Eisemann Center in Richardson, TX, as they have for the past twelve years, Pegasus has the opportunity to fill that space with an incredible new musical. More singing, more dancing, and more color than ever before!
Pegasus will be mounting the first fully staged production of this charming love story. The Cuban & The Redhead will bring to life the heartwarming story of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz long before "I Love Lucy" hit the air waves.
With your contributions, we can make sure this production gets the star treatment it deserves!
What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,000 to make this dream a reality.  That may seem like a lot, but it's only 10% of the total cost. Musicals are expensive to produce, and this one is no exception. There are costs we have never encountered before: paying a 25-person cast, costuming and wigging that 25-person cast, body microphones, a music director, a band, extra lighting and sound equipment, etc.   
"But what do I get?" We hear you.  That's a lot of money to ask for. For varying levels of contributions, you'll get:

Access to Behind-the-Scenes information
Your name listed in our program
VIP tickets to the show
A signed photo of the cast
A signed copy of the musical score
A signed copy of the script
A backstage meeting with our Lucy and Desi after a performance
Meeting with the show creators
AND MORE!

The Impact

Pegasus Theatre's mission statement has always focused on bringing new comedies to life.  There's nothing more steeped in comic gold than Lucille Ball.  But her story (and Desi's) haven't always been the bust-a-gut rollicking misadventures their show gave us.  Robert and Danny have worked on this show for years, fine-tuning and rewriting, to make sure this is the pinnacle of perfection. This has been a labor of love for these two and Pegasus Theatre is more than excited to mount this show.

Pegasus Theatre has been in operation for more than 30 years.  Our original Living Black & White ™ series has been a staple of the Dallas theater scene for ages.  And since our move to the Eisemann Center, our shows have gotten bigger, more technically refined, and grayer than ever before.  We have deft hands handling our big-budget shows, and this one proves to be no exception.  The only problem we have is that our coffers such as they are just won't support the extra needs of a large-scale musical.  And that's why we NEED you.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute very much financially, there are more ways for you to help Pegasus Theatre reach our goal. Share, Share, Share! It's a numbers game. If we were to email every single person on our email list, statistics say only 2% will respond with a donation.  Not a huge number, right?Well, if you share this on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, we can expand our reach. Who do you think would enjoy a show about Lucy and Desi? Did you grow up watching the show live? Do you want to introduce your kids, your grandkids, to this comic couple? DO YOU LOVE LUCY?We've set up dedicated accounts on these social media platforms to be accessible! Check out our links to find us and follow our progress.Pegasus Theatre on FaceBookOn Twitter @CubanandRedhead    On Instagram @TheCubanandTheRedheadIf you can contribute to our campaign, thank you. We are so excited about this leap we are making. It's a thrilling and daunting leap, and we know we can do it with your help.

story:
For the past few months, students from over ten different schools and universities have been preparing a production of Jaqueline Goldfinger’s new play Babel, an empathetic story about paranoia, privilege, and playing God in an emerging future of eugenics. Throughout the play, we follow two young pregnant couples as they encounter moral concerns involving a new technology that can predetermine the ethics of their unborn child. Our rehearsal period is finally arriving, and we'll all be moving at a breakneck speed over the next few weeks.

    In the spirit of this project and New Play Exchange, we will not be requesting any entry fee for the performance. That being said, any extra support you would be willing to lend now will go toward production needs and creating an evening to be shared with all of you. The next month will require a lot of technical assemblies to transform the backyard into a theatre space so, as always, every little bit counts. If you aren’t in a place to support Babel financially, no fear! We look forward to your moral support and hopefully your presence on August 9th. 

    This project was created as a reminder that revitalization and creativity lives close to home, right in our backyards, and as a means to connect. Thank you in advance for whatever you can lend to the Babel team, we appreciate you!

 

List of people very grateful for your donation who coincidentally are also on the team:

Director— Samantha Ozeas

Assistant Director— Nour Zuaiter 

Stage Manager— Kierstin Kimball

Dramaturg— Chris Jensen

Lighting Designers— Olivia Feldman and Milan Levy

Lighting Technician— Miles Parsons

Sound Designer— Quinn O’Connor

Costumes— Moira Rogers

Other Lovely Hands-on-Deck— Alyssa Lopez and Kyle Tomlin

 

~ Featuring Nour Zuaiter, Sophie Megaw, Nicole Tenorio and Solomon Jackson-Hardy~

 

 

Special thanks to New Play Exchange for making new works accessible! We love ya.

story:
Support Michael Kearns' Theaterpiece

Bang Bang Opens At Highways Performance Space on April 10
Highways Performance Space and Moon Mile Run present the world premiere of Bang Bang, the newest addition to Michael Kearns’ arsenal of theatrical work that examines societal “headline” contentions with uncompromising passion.Inspired by the myriad responses to gun violence in America – from Sandy Hook to Ferguson – Bang Bang, directed by Mark Bringelson, weaves a battered, shredded tapestry of characters who face the consequences of what happens when the trigger is pulled.

Ryland Shelton as Laurence, Jr. (photo by Gina Long) 

Peter, one of the play’s main characters, is a documentary filmmaker and his film-in-progress (titled Bang, Bang), reveals the heartbroken lives of the viscerally wounded. The documentary that is being filmed becomes the play: a collage of confessionals and testimonies, intimacies of sexual rage and arias of palpable loss.


A man loses his black son in a white cop shooting; a woman loses her husband and daughter in a random school shooting; an elderly man plans to off his wife, who is in the throes of Alzheimer’s; a prostitute murders her boyfriend-pimp; a gay therapist morphs into a meth-addicted serial killer; a cop relives his experience of removing children from a schoolroom that was “a sea of blood.”

Lizzie Peet plays Sandy (photo by Gina Long)

But Peter's film shoot in interrupted by Padric, a charismatic Irish con'man who steals not only hearts, but stories.

Bang Bang is both a departure and a familiar undertaking for Kearns. His motifs – addiction, sexuality, familial unrest, HIV/AIDS, Hollywood – are extant in this endeavor. Bang Bang was initially workshopped last year at Skylight Theatre Company, as part of its INKubator Play Reading Series.

Michael Kearns plays Himself (photo by Gina Long)

Getting Bang For Your Bucks

Your donations will go to many things that fuel the particulars to produce a play including (but not limited to): 

  • Promotion: if there's not a great team (and we have one), the seats will not be filled. It's as simple as that. Green Galactic will not rely on what happens after the play opens but has already begun to find ways to make Bang Bang a known entity in advance.
  • Payment to actors, director, and playwright; they need to eat, pay their rent, and buy an outfit for opening night. Simple as that. As minimal as these payment may be, we are trying to show artists our respect.
  • Props, costumes, and all those miscellaneous items that present themselves from now until opening night.
  • Producing the musical motif that will heighten the urgency of the words.
  • Photography,printing, postcards, postage--yep, we know all about the value of social media but we also know that the old fashioned ways still work. 

David Pevsner plays the Doctor (photo by Gina Long)

Your Emotional Investment Matters  

 Bang Bang is an art piece and we intend that its impact extends beyond the "normal" theatergoing experience. Bang Bang digs deep into many of the social contructs that are destroying our country (and the world):  the glamorization of violence, school shootings, homophobia, racial injustice, and many of the attendant headline issues having to do with pulling the trigger of a gun. 

Beyond Financial Contributions

MOON MILE RUN: Mark Bringelson, Shelton, and Kearns (photo by Gina Long)
We all know that word of mouth and social media can create an enormous buzz. And that buzz translates into people buying tickets, checking out this page, chatting Bang Bang up at a party. Let your peeps know that Bringelson, Kearns, and Shelton have formed a production company: MOON MILE RUN (under the umbrella of Indecent Exposure Theater Company). So if you're short on cash, you can still help get Bang Bang on the boards. Forward this campaign info, put a few words on your Facebook page (repeatedly between now through April), buy at least two tickets to see the show and get a couple of buds to come with you. And if you want to volunteer to be part of the actual production team, contact Michael at mkla@att.net and let up know where your expertise lies. There's a good chance there will be a way to involve you in making Bang Bang snap, crackle and pop.

story:
The Facebook event can be found here: Bondage Ball and the details of which will be relayed below.

Our goal is to raise enough money prior to our campaigne date to cover all of the event expenses so that 100% of the door proceeds and whatever extra money that may possibly be raised will be donated directly to Breast Cancer Research! Our goal of $1200 will supply the means to power this machine by providing the costs of advertising, staffing, performance fees, equipment expenses, Bondage Ball clothing to help raise even MORE money at the event, food and drinks, and all that will comprise this collision of kink, art, performance, and music the likes of which Pittsburgh has yet to encounter!

You are invited to attend a truly wondrous night of entertainment for a great cause!

Prepare yourself for an event so inclusive and spectacular that it will be a veritable Noahs Ark for the arts, performances, music, and fetish! Join our incredible line up of talented individuals as we unite to raise money for Breast Cancer Research and help spread breast cancer awareness!!!

The Bondage Ball was also created to enlighten and inspire. To unburden yourself and give us a chance to experience one another in our most powerful and passionate of forms. To learn and grow with each other whilst sharing our desires, knowledge, and experience in a safe, welcoming environment amongst like-minded souls.

Important and likely questions that may arise when creating this event and their answers are as follows:

Q: I'm going to donate, but what entertainment will be provided?

A: Good fucking question! There will be flesh suspension, grind performances, burlesque dancers, fire sideshows, an aerial silk contortionist, and dj's from all of Pittsburgh's goth, industrial, and alternative dance nights! And even more to be announced!

Q: Sounds pretty cool, but is that all?

A: Fuck no! Free full body painting, free vac bed experience, free poi lessons, There will be a shibari play area, a spanking booth, BDSM equipment open for use, 2 bars to avoid crazy wait times, and kinky vendors!

Q: WHOA, I can't miss this! But i'm from out-of-town and am unfamiliar with the city of Pittsburgh. Where might I stay?

A: I know the fucking perfect spot! For our out-of-town guests we suggest a stay at the Westin Convention Center that is only blocks from the venue and of whom we have no official affiliation. But it is gorgeous, close, comfortable, and you'll have an exquisite view of Pittsburghs downtown to help fulfill your stay in our beautiful city. Address: 1000 Penn Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15222 Phone: (412) 281-3700

Q: That sounds great, i'm ready to donate! I'd also love to donate! But what happens if you don't reach your indiegogo goal? are you going to cancel the event? If not, will we lose any of the awesome things that are planned?

A: Not a fucking thing! Some of the boundlessly generous and talented performers chosen for this event have agreed to accept smaller forms of payment if necessary. And keep in mind a lot of people helping are already doing this for free! T-shirts may not be printed if the goal isn’t reached, but other than that the show will go on! Of course to make up the difference we will unfortunately have to cover those costs by taking what little remainder there is from the door proceeds. Something we would REALLY like to avoid since the goal is to donate 100% of the proceeds and whatever extra money that could potentially be raised through our indiegogo. But all the performances and activities will stay in effect, we’re ALL determined to raise a lot of money for the cause!

Q: I’ll be there for sure! But I don’t know much about the Breast Cancer Research charity you chose. Is it really a good charity?

A: Abso-fucking-lutely! I can no longer display their name as they do not wish to be associated with the context of this event directly which is of course understandabl;e, but never the less, unfortunate. Where and how we will be donating the money can be learned through direct message inquiry either here or through facebook. But our charity of choices statistics are distrubted as follows, according to Charity Navigator, ONLY 2.4% goes to administrative expenses! And a whopping 91.9% goes to program expenses and the rest goes to the fundraising expenses and efficiency. But unfortunately in 2014 only 21.9% was raised by fundraising events. Let’s raise that fucking bar!

Q: I donated a little and I am going to pay at the door, but is there anything else I can do to help?

A: Fuck yes, spread the motherfucking word!! You can go to our event pages and share our links or tell your friends or even invite your friends list from the event page directly!

And honestly every little bit helps. every penny, every post, every word of mouth conversation is a contribution that creates a snowball effect that will assuredly make Pittsburgh’s 1st annual Bondage Ball a huge success. We can’t thank all of you enough for your kindness, generosity, love, and understanding. We will raise the money needed, we will raise tons more to donate, and with our contribution to breast cancer research we are ensuring a beautiful tomorrow. Thank you all!

And a whopping 91.9% goes to program expenses and the rest goes to the fundraising expenses and efficiency. But unfortunately in 2014 only 21.9% was raised by fundraising events. Let’s raise that fucking bar!Q:  I donated a little and I am going to pay at the door, but is there anything else I can do to help?A: Fuck yes, spread the motherfucking word!! You can go to our event pages and share our links or tell your friends or even invite your friends list from the event page directly! And honestly every little bit helps. every penny, every post, every word of mouth conversation is a contribution that creates a snowball effect that will assuredly make Pittsburgh’s 1st annual Bondage Ball a huge success. We can’t thank all of you enough for your kindness, generosity, love, and understanding. We will raise the money needed, we will raise tons more to donate, and with our contribution to breast cancer research we are ensuring a beautiful tomorrow. Thank you all!

story:
My Story

Hello Everyone near and far! I am Katie, and in May 2011 I graduated from Alfred University where I received my Bachelor’s degree in theater and a minor dance. At Alfred University, I was awakened with this new found creativity as well as embraced with an amazing support system. Those influential people have helped me to become the person that I am today, causing me to want to make my own unique and positive impact on the lives of others. I found that I am inspired to create my performance work based on collaboration, mass (people), movement from site, happiness, spontaneity, and life experiences. Not only was I able to create work as a choreographer, but I was also able to develop as an actress as well by taking on various types of roles. These past four years of my life have been quite an exciting journey for me and have made me realize that I am looking for more!!     

Just this month I found out that I was accepted into Headlong Performance Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania for their Fall 2012, Post Baccalaureate semester! During this intensive semester I will have the chance to train, create, perform, and see work (including a full schedule of performances in the Live Arts/Philly Fringe Festival) in the heart of Philadelphia's vibrant and internationally-known performance scene. This intensive Philadelphia semester is a hybrid performance founded and taught by working artists, including artistic directors of Headlong Dance Theater and Pig Iron Theatre Company. This is an AMAZING opportunity to further my education, but I am turning to you for your support. Since graduation, I have have been looking for that place of both comfort and community as well as my favorite, HAPPINESS, just like I received at my own college, and I know that Headlong Performance Institute is where I need to be :D

I need YOUR support, so I can be that person to make a diffrence in the lives of others and get an OUTSTANDING education, because I am rasing the money all on my own! 

Although I was accepted, I can only go if I raise the money!

 ONLY  5,000 total!!!!! (but I can't change the amount on here!!)

Let's Reach 5,000 for my tuition!

 Tuition (not including housing, meals, etc)

**This will be paying for all HPI performances trips and tickets which are included in the tuition fee.

Let's reach 4,000 for housing and expenses!!!  

Be the Change You Wish to See In the World

There is no doubt in my mind that Headlong Performance Institute will help me grow as an artist through exploration while finding new and inventive ways to work with others. There are still there many skills which I have yet to learn and would love to attain at Headlong. I am at that stage in my life where I want to push myself as an individual artist and test myself in the most creative ways possible.

If you contribute to helping me further my education, you are helping me get  one step closer to acheiving my dream!  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

This means so help that you are able to take the time and help me out!

If you could spread the word to friends, family and colleagues that would be AMAZING!!!!

There are still there many skills which I have yet to learn and would love to attain at Headlong. I am at that stage in my life where I want to push myself as an individual artist and test myself in the most creative ways possible.
If you contribute to helping me further my education, you are helping me get  one step closer to acheiving my dream!  


 


Other Ways You Can Help
This means so help that you are able to take the time and help me out!
If you could spread the word to friends, family and colleagues that would be AMAZING!!!!

story:
Uranium Madhouse is a new Los Angeles-based theater cabal whose works manifest
the anarchic, rowdy core of human consciousness and social organization.
 We induce theatrical nuclear explosions that carry our audiences into a
bracing and vital confrontation with the now of our individual and
collective lives.

We look to bring hot, passionate, lucid acting together with an approach
to theater that constantly reconsiders the possibilities of the
theatrical medium itself.  We forge soulful, compelling performances in
the context of productions that take nothing for granted, least of all
our audience.  Learn more about us at http://uraniummadhouse.org

We are currently engaged in fundraising for our first season.  With your help, our inaugural production will be Rick Burkhardt’s Conversation Storm.  The play, a giddy shotgun marriage of Chekhov and Brecht, reunites three friends in a quiet café after a 20-year separation.   The friends quickly resume their custom of parry and riposte in an examination of the question of torture.  As they talk, an intricate game evolves, entailing time loops and role-playing. They imagine the unimaginable, save Manhattan, fail Manhattan, conjure atrocities, salvage humanity and try to get a glass of water from an inattentive waiter, all while attempting to answer the question, "Are people fungible?"

Named Best New Play at the 2007 San Francisco Fringe Festival, Conversation Storm jolts audiences from detached definitions of officially sanctioned interrogation techniques and confronts us with the real world consequences of our choices.  

Conversation Storm was written by Rick Burkhardt, the co-creator of Three Pianos, which is currently completing a triumphant run in New York and which the Wall Street  Journal described as “a hilarious, yet wise, examination of friendship, depression and classical music.”   We feel that Conversation Storm is the ideal piece with which to introduce ourselves to the Los Angeles community, in that it simultaneously interrogates urgent political matters, the limits of friendship and the theatrical situation itself.  


We are enormously excited to enter the production process, so we invite you to help us reach our funding critical mass, that is, our goal of $10,000.   In doing so, you will take part in instigating the extraordinary. 

Also, we will be posting a video pitch in the next ten days, so keep on a eye on this spot!

Uranium Madhouse is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions in behalf of Uranium Madhouse may be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us unleash a crowdfunding chain reaction by promoting this page to your social network, using the tools found above.  Leave Comments on this page, because that affects our GoGoFactor, the score IndieGogo uses to decide how hard to promote us.  Also, think about if there are others you know who would like to help build Uranium Madhouse whom you could approach directly about supporting our cause.

story:
THE RESCIGNOS VARIETY SHOW & THE ARACA PROJECT 

Our sweater vested gang is proud to announce that The Rescignos Variety Show has been selected for the 2012 Araca Project! We know what you're thinking: "That's fantastic! What does that mean?" As part of the Araca Project, the show will have a two week run in an Off-Broadway theater this September!

Now you're thinking: "That's terrific! But it sounds like it's going to be expensive." You're right! We're raising money to pay for all the things necessary to produce a show in an Off-Broadway theater: actors, musicians, lights, costumes, sets, sound equipment, etc...oh and vests, did we mention the vests?

Now you're thinking: "How can I help?" See...this is why we like you. Click "contribute" at the bottom of the page and donate what you can! Because our project is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, your donations are tax deductible! Neat! We can't begin to thank you enough for your financial contributions. Seriously, our gratitude knows no bounds. Because it is difficult to hug you via the internet, instead we are offering the nifty perks you see on the right! So consider the perks an online hug. And we give really good hugs. Ask anyone.

Now you're thinking: "Gee whiz, I wish there was some other way I could help!" Again...you are just the best. Your use of the phrase, "Gee whiz" is enough to make our hearts warm. And there's a bunch more ways you can help! You can like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, follow us on Tumblr...and come to the show in September! With lots and lots of friends! Our performance dates and times will be announced in the coming weeks. And heck, if you know anybody whose business cards read, "Proud Member of the 1%"...tell them about this fundraising campaign. A lot.

ABOUT THE SHOW

An obsessive-compulsive, socially awkward, tolerably attractive guy sings and tells jokes…and he has a twin! Donning sweater vests and each armed with a razor-sharp wit, The Rescignos are like Cain and Abel but with more singing and less fratricide. In The Rescignos Variety Show, the Rescigno boys join forces with a talented ensemble of actors for an evening of comedy, jaunty musical numbers, and sweater vests. We take our fun very seriously.

THE RESCIGNOS ON THE WEB

Website: therescignos.com
Facebook: facebook.com/therescignos
YouTube: youtube.com/therescignos
Twitter: twitter.com/therescignos
Tumblr: therescignos.tumblr.com

ABOUT THE ARACA PROJECT

The Araca Group (the folks behind Urinetown, Rock of Ages, and Wicked) began The Araca Project in 2011 with the objective to, "foster the emerging artist’s entrepreneurial spirit." For more information, check out The Araca Project online:

Website: araca.com/the-araca-project
Facebook: facebook.com/thearacaproject
Twitter: twitter.com/thearacaproject
Tumblr: thearacaproject.tumblr.com

story:
'The famous Edinburgh Festival's naughty grandchild' (Prague Post 2009), Fringe Festival Praha welcomes over 600 companies and thousands of theatre goers to the heart of the Czech capital from all over the world each year.  Built for Collapse has been invited to perform this year and we can do it with your support!

 

THE AMBITION

In an exciting push forward, Built for Collapse has been invited to perform Nuclear Love Affair at the Prague International Fringe Festival this June!  So weâ€™re packing up and heading out in 2012 to take the show to Europe.  Once we were accepted into the festival this past December, we recognized that this was our chance to really make waves overseas.  In the coming months our company will be working hard to secure even more opportunities to perform in Europe this year so that we can really make an impact; not only as a company but also in the promotion of Americaâ€™s emerging artists and what they care about.  Now, as we plan our most ambitious year to date, we need your help more than ever. 

 

We are working non-stop to raise the funds to sustain this exciting momentum.  And hereâ€™s the big truth of it all: Resourceful as we are, we still rely on your enthusiasm and generous donations to realize our goals.  We are driven to make the best work possible by bringing controversial and critical subject matter to the forefront in an artistic way.  More importantly, we are determined to find venues in which to share that work with the largest most diverse audience possible.  Donating this winter  (in the form of a tax deductible contribution) will bring us that much closer to ensuring our continued growth and future! 

 

OUR PLEDGE

Please help us make this vision a reality.  Share this, Tweet this, post us on Facebook and DONATE TODAY!  In exchange for your contribution and support, you will receive one-of-a-kind perks as listed to the right, as well as our pledge to use all the resources at our disposal to bring this 'extraordinary tale of victory, hypocrisy and ignorance' to the widest possible audience.  Look below for a breakdown of how money will be spent.  Please note: All IndieGoGo donations will go directly towards the "Travel Costs" portion of our budget.  Every gift is deeply appreciated. Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is tax-deductible.  From everyone in the Built for Collapse family we extend our sincerest "Thank You!!"

 

THE SHOW

Unnerving rhythms, disturbing text, and violent slapstick collide to create a pop culture explosion in this spectacular multi-media investigation of the Atomic Age.  Starring Marilyn Monroe and Charlie Chaplin, Nuclear Love Affair traces the evolution of the American Dream through the social and political chain reaction caused by dropping of the Atomic bomb. Harsh and hysterical, this 'vision of a world gone wrong' is 'an amazing theatrical experience' that leaves audiences 'blown away' (NYTheatre.com).

 

AWARDS + COMMISSIONS

2012 Foundation for Contemporary Arts Emergency Grant

2012 Lower Manhattan Cultural Council

2012 LaGuardia Performing Arts Lab Grant

2012 Prague Fringe Festival

2011 Ars Nova ANT Festival

2011 The Tank Space Grant for Development

2011 Hangar Theater Summer Residency

2011 Theater for the New City Dream Up Festival

 

OUR COMPANY

Built for Collapse is a New York based arts organization dedicated to building multi-disciplinary communal celebrations that apply pressure to traditional theatrical form. Through this process work is created that pushes the limits of what we consider performance and new ways of achieving our artistic vision are discovered. At times an erotic opera, at times a freakish and violent circus, Built for Collapse has been described as a subversive and â€œcreative new approach to theatre.â€  Built for Collapse was founded by Sanaz Ghajarrahimi and Ben Hobbs in March 2008.  Lead Artists: Sanaz Ghajarrahimi, Ben Hobbs, Vincent Santvoord, Emily Brazee, Adam Cochran, Diana Egizi, Eddie Gutierrez, Michael Krass, Sophie Labelle, Room 404 Media (Kate Freer + Dave Tennant), Derek Smith, Jenny Beth Snyder, Elinor Thompson, Colleen Toole and Nicole Weiss.

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

Please Note: All IndieGoGo donations will go directly towards the "Travel Costs" portion of our budget. 

 

Travel Costs â€“ 7 Cast Members, 3 Production Team Members: 70%

Airplane Tickets â€¢ European East Pass â€¢ Eurail Select Pass â€¢ Eurostar Tickets â€¢ Housing â€¢ Travel Insurance â€¢ Travel Visas

 

Festival Fees: 8%

Submission Fees â€¢ House Manager â€¢ Technical Director â€¢ Light and Sound Board Operators â€¢ Technical Staff

 

Materials: 7%

Media Materials â€¢ Costume Materials â€¢ Prop Materials â€¢ Lighting Packages â€¢ Music Instrument Rental

 

Publicity: 10%

Photographer â€¢ Poster/ Flyer/ Postcard Design and Printing â€¢ Bulk Mailing Costs â€¢ Listings/Advertisements â€¢ Website Design and Maintenance

 

Other: 5%

Rehearsal Space â€¢ Audio Recording â€¢ Video Recording â€¢ Script Copying â€¢ Ticket and Program Printing


Cheers and Love,

Built for Collapse

story:
The Alliance Theatre Lab and The Adrienne Arsht Center are set to bring the award winning play Brothers Beckett to the Carnival Studio in downtown Miami.

We need your generosity to get us there.

The Alliance Theatre Lab consists of an amazing group of people lead by Artist Director Adalberto J. Acevedo.

Our cast for the production is:

Gabe Hammad as Kevin Beckett
David Michael Sirois as Brad Beckett
Ashley Price as Tuesday Gretchen Jacobson
Julie Daniels as Dr. Joyce Elliot
Mark Della Ventura as Doug

When first produced in Miami Lakes... the show garnered the attention of Scott Shiller,the Vice President of the Arsht Center. He generously offered us the opportunity to be part of the lauded Theatre Up Close Series 2012-13 season.

The play itself was nominated for 3 Carbonells including Best New Work and has been named "One of the Five most Exciting Stage Events Coming to the Arsht Center This Season." - Miami New Times.

It was nationally recognized as a nominee of the ATCA/Steinberg Award and won a Silver Palm Award as well as Best New Work for the New Times.

By contributing to this campaign in any amount, you are helping to achieve a life-long dream for all of these fine artists. Any amount is a step in the direction of this goal.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this campaign is set at $5,000. With this amount we will be able to fund important fees like set construction, lighting designer, and actor salaries.

Plenty of Perks!

For contributing you will receive specific and personalized gifts from the Alliance. Such as signed postcards, free tickets, our undying love, but our best gift yet... a chance to be "Director for a Day".

The difference your contribution will make:

Your contribution will allow us to do the theatre we are passionate about, reach a larger audience, and during a time when it is so difficult to make artistic contributions to our community. The artistic community suffers when economic times are hard. But we need your help more than ever.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute money at this time, you can help us by spreading the word! Feel free to share our campaign with as many people as possible, or anyone with a passion for theatre and/or this play.

story:
Short Summary

For a small but fiercely passionate theater company like us, putting on a show is an incredible journey. It's challenging, it's exciting, it's complicated, it's expensive...but it's oh, so worth it to bring something new and original to life!

Right now, we are working on a sassy, sappy show about love to offer up this Valentine's Day weekend, but we need help to make it happen!

What We Need & What You Get

We need a budget for:

-Sets (approx. $250)

-Props (approx. $200)

-Costumes (approx. $200)

-Cast album recording costs ($150)

-Venue rental for performances ($500)

Obviously, the total here is more than our goal of $800. We are hoping for ticket sales to make up the rest, and of course if people want to keep giving once we surpass the goal amount, we won't complain! And even if we don't reach our goal, every little bit helps in the process of this production.

In exchange for helping us, you can gain recognition in our program, a free cast album, and/or a number of other awesome perks (in addition to good karma)!

The Impact

Original scripts and new works are the future of theater. If you have ever loved a play or musical, remember that at one point, that playwright was unknown and trying to find a way to share their shows with the world. That's where we're at now. 

To learn more about other shows we have done in the past and read testimonials,  you can check out the playwright's website: www.JamieMaletzMusicals.com

Risks & Challenges

The less money we can raise, the less we can do with our sets, props and costumes. This show is happening either way, whether we perform an epic version that pulls out all the stops or a low-budget version with props made of cardboard. But of course, we'd prefer the former, and we're willing to work hard to make it happen! 

Other Ways You Can Help

-Please help us spread the word. Post the link for this campaign on social media platforms, tell your friends, tell your family, tell your pets!

-We can also always use in-kind donations. To see a list of the props, costume pieces and set pieces we need, you can email jamie.maletz@gmail.com. If you're local and you have some things on the list that you are willing to lend out or donate, we'll come to you!

story:
We recently had to give our "elevator pitch" (industry term lol) to the annoyed, over worked receptionist of a big wig producer who we want to be involved with our show. It went a little something like this: 

Ugh…Who are you?

Hey! I'm Natalie Birriel (after a moment, from behind) and I'm Kelly Kolatac! What started off as two gals taking an acting class together years ago, has evolved into a full fledge comedic partnership. We write, produce and perform all of our own material. I mean really, don't you think the world with needs more lady driven comedies? (Awkwardly long pause) Yeah, we do too!

Recently, we were working hard in pre production with the web series version of "From 1 to 10." With our sights firmly set on web content, we never in a million years thought that our show could be mounted on a stage, but when the opportunity to be apart of NYNW Festival presented itself we knew we had to jump at the chance! 

Ok? So like, what's your project about? 

So glad you asked! 
"From 1 to 10" takes place at a full service marketing and research facility. At the helm is the office supervisor Brett, an over-weight, nerd, who puts the A in anti-social. Along with Brett are his employees, Natalie and Kelly. Natalie is a sassy Puerto Rican who falls in love with any guy with a great sob story. Kelly is the type of girl to shoot you with daggers from her eyes, then cloak you in a smile; the best friend you need, but really don't want. In the corporate world, these ladies always find themselves the assistant to the assistant, never the wife of the CEO, where they feel they truly deserve to be. 

Today, the head honcho from Coca-Cola is coming in, as the Research Center will be conducting a focus group on a new flavor. This is a huge account so everyone is on edge, under pressure, and stressed out. Everyone except for Natalie and Kelly, that is, who couldn't care less. It isn't until Brett informs them that Jack, the son of the CEO and essentially our generation's John "John-John" Kennedy Jr. is also coming in to make sure everything goes smoothly with the Coca-Cola people, do Natalie and Kelly get swept up in the frenzy of the day as well. 

Mistakes are made, secrets are unearthed, feelings are hurt, friendships are torn apart, someone looses an appendage - all before lunch - in this crazy workplace comedy. 

And like...What do you want?

Well, the truth is we need your donation to get our wickedly funny office comedy to the big stage and then to a screen near you! Just to be a part of the festival you must pay a fee, it's New York nothing's free! Not to mention, a show like this requires a talented team, and lots of pieces to bring it to light. 

Ughh…What's so special about this festival anyway and why even do it? 

The New York New Works Festival is a way for Broadway to give back. They promote up and coming writers, directors and performers and provide them with a platform to showcase their work in front of the Broadway and TV community. There are 3 rounds to this play festival, at each round the audience and judges vote on who will go to the next round! Culminating, in a Final Night Presentation in front of the industry. Each round is another amazing shot to showcase your work! 

So why this festival? First, there's no other festival like it, where each show is mentored by highly esteemed professionals. Secondly, many of the shows that take place in this festival, go on to be produced for Film and TV. So, we thought what better platform to debut our little office comedy then in front of Broadway & TV Producers!

Fine, Whatever…I'm into it 

Great! And today is your lucky day because your donation is a 2 for 1 contribution! Don't you just love those?! Now, your generosity will help in the creation of "From 1 to 10" (The Play) and the web series! 
Your donation will cover the cost of: 
Festival Fee
Director's Fee
Producer's Fee
Stage Manager
Props 
Set Pieces
Rehearsal Space
Marketing
Camera Rental
Camera DP
Sound Equipment
Sound Mixer 
Editor 

So, what do I get for this?

I'm so glad you asked! Depending on what your donation is we have a tons of fun perks! You can get anything from a shout out on Social Media, a personalized video message, an Associate Producer credit - the list goes on and on!

Sounds mildly fun. Can I follow you on Social Media?

I thought you'd never ask! Yassssss you can and WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT! 
If you are going to be in New York City on September 6th, then please come to the Elektra Theatre at 7pm; Tickets can be purchased online at http://www.nynwtheatrefestival.com/book-tickets and VOTE for our Show! 
Andddd…
Be on the look out for our "From 1 to 10" promos, also be sure to follow us on all Social Media outlets and You Tube;  we are all over everything so feel free to Like us! 

K great…

Now get away from my desk!

Thank you for your time and support! 

-Natalie and Kelly

Ugh…Who are you?
Hey! I'm Natalie Birriel (after a moment, from behind) and I'm Kelly Kolatac! What started off as two gals taking an acting class together years ago, has evolved into a full fledge comedic partnership. We write, produce and perform all of our own material. I mean really, don't you think the world with needs more lady driven comedies? (Awkwardly long pause) Yeah, we do too!

story:
Sickle Moon Productions are premiering a brand new show this September and we need your help!

The development of this show depends entirely upon the love and support of you, the hard working public, to help us out in any way you can. Whether it is a €5 donation or a €50 donation, a like on Facebook or a share on Twitter we will be eternally indebted to you for your help. 

The support we are asking for will go towards building our set, designing and making our costumes and props, and creating all of our beautiful promotional material as well as to pay and support the artists involved in the production. 

A BIT ABOUT US AND THE SHOW:

Sickle Moon are a Dublin and Meath-based theatre and film production company, led by Artistic Director Jeda de Brí, and actor/writer Finbarr Doyle.

We most recently co-produced "Cirque Des Reves" with Illustrated Productions, "Pitcher" for Smock Alley's Collaborations Festival 2015 ,"Trinkets" for Carrickmacross Arts Fest 2015 and "Strobing Effects" for 60 Minutes in Dublin @ The New Theatre. 

In 2014, Sickle Moon were the inaugural Company In Residence at Theatre Upstairs, Eden Quay where we produced three original plays - "Slippers", "Tactics" and “Spectres”.

Our newest play will premier this September and has been  in development for 2 years. With your help we can finally make it a reality. We would love to tell you a bit about the plot and the wonderful team we have involved but right now the show is top secret. One thing we can say is that it's our most ambitious project yet and is very dear to our hearts. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP: 

We wouldn't ask you to part with your hard earned money unless we didn’t truly believe this show is worth it. As an unfunded company we have no other way to make this dream a reality unless it's with your help. Every donation big and small is hugely appreciated and we believe it's only fair that your generosity is rewarded. You can select one of the rewards listed as our way of saying a massive thank you for your contribution to the production.

Thank you for taking the time to read this (that alone is hugely appreciated) and we cannot wait to premier this piece later in the year and show what your help has made possible. 

Now let’s kick it in the face!

Jeda and Finbarr of Sickle Moon Productions

story:
AnyStage Theater

AnyStage was formed in the summer of 2014, with the goal of presenting both original and well-known pieces of theater. Along the way, we adapted the motto of "weird and wonderful," which is a philosophy we plan to abide by. We've done a punk-rock inspired production of Hamlet in a park, and a (slightly) gender bent version of The Importance of Being Earnest in an art gallery. We're also currently working on an original play entittled "Amelia Earhart in Space," and it's exactly what it sounds like. However, we don't just want to experiment with history and the classics. We also want to use art to explore broader issues in the world. Which brings us to...

The Laramie Project

In 1998, Matthew Shepard was a 21 year old gay University of Wyoming student who was tied to a fence in a secluded area and beaten by two young men in an apparent hate crime. The case attracted worldwide attention, and the media descended upon the small town of Laramie, Wyoming. During this time, the members of a theater group based in New York City became interested in the story and decided to visit Laramie for themselves. For over a year, they met with residents of Laramie, as well as local police and first responders, friends and family of the victim and the suspects, and students from the university. Using only the transcripts from those interviews and public records, The Laramie Project was written. 

We chose this play for several reasons: The subject matter remains just as tragically relevent as ever; the idea of documentary theater is an interesting concept to us; and, finally, there's an exciting acting challenge at the heart of the play: It features over 70 characters, but only six performers. We've been working very hard over the past weeks and months to ensure that we do this right. Every person who appears in the play is real, so respectfully and truthfully representing each point of view is one of our top priorites. Attention is being paid to every detail. As a result...

We Need Help!

In the past, AnyStage has only performed plays that are in the public domain, which means no royalty fees were required. That's all changing with The Laramie Project. In addition, we're renting a beautiful space at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Reston. This location gives us the opportunity to continue AnyStage's titular goal: performing in a specific space that suits the production. The play features many discussions on religion, so an open-minded and accepting church is the ideal setting for this piece. We also need to aquire many costume pieces and props (as we mentioned, this play has a lot of characters.) Finally, we'd like to be in the financial position to give something back. Our plan is to turn our Saturday matinee into a special performance where 20% of ticket sales go to The Mathew Shepard Foundation (matthewshepard.org) and The Trevor Project (thetrevorproject.org)

To Sum It All Up:

AnyStage Theater will present The Laramie Project on January 8th at 8PM and January 9th at 3:30 and 8PM at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Reston, 1625 Wiehle Ave. Reston, VA 20190. Please give whatever you can to help this play be produced with the quality it deserves. Visit us at anystagetheater.com

story:
What is Party World Rasslin'? 


PWR is a community-supported party/wrestling/comedy/theater/party/event with cheap drinks and wrestling-style entertainment.  The amazing community that led to the rise of PWR has kept us alive for 5 incredible shows.  As we plunge forward into "PWR Presents: Darkwar", our most high-concept and immersive show yet, we look again to the Multiverse to help us shoulder the financial burden of COMPLETE, MAXIMUM EVIL.  Despite always stepping our game up each show, we've played it fairly safe as far as setting and story.  NOT THIS TIME.  This is basically our dream show, and we are diving headfirst into it.

What the HECK is Darkwar?

At our last show, JUDGMENT SLAM, a treacherous, sentient machine known as Deep Slam took the Partyweight Championship from the human hero Dock Master. Using a time portal opened from the future, he traveled forward into a dark distopia for reasons unknown, taking the Partyweight Belt with him and leaving PWR in ruin.  At DARKWAR, we will travel into the future and bring the audience with us as we begin the final battle for the fate of mankind. This show will be taking place IN THE FUTURE, so we will be going crazier with decorations, props, and lighting than we ever have before.  Think laser tag warehouse meets 80's cyberpunk distopia.  We have been VERY cost-effective with our budget and resources (most of our decorations have been crafted from literal trash) so this extra funding will help us make this show shockingly immersive and cool.

What We Need and What You Get

Here are all the things we're looking to include on the show:
* Bigger, better and MORE decorations (a crazy amount of blacklights, a fully functioning and 100% REAL time travel portal at the entrance of the venue, A BLOOD FOUNTAIN, lasers, etc.)
*Costumes
*Payments to own our ring, maintenance and upgrades (we're part of the way there thanks to past donations but the floor and frame still need some love)
*Support people working on PWR (Planning the events requires a crazy level of work and incurs a lot of incidental costs)
*Webhosting for our sweet website and webstore
*Video equipment for promos and show coverage

Covering these costs with donations ensures we don't need to have a door charge for the shows and can keep them FREE.

Risks & Challenges


Challenges:

PWR has mostly become self-sufficient, but now as it continues to grow we are entering a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before (but are very excited about!).  Thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all year.

Risks:

We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness."

Other Ways You Can Help


If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and our upcoming event, WINTER WONDERSLAM II.

Here is the facebook event page:

https://www.facebook.com/events/772227636220579/

story:
Help us raise $3500 by December 31st for our scholarship program!

The Chelsea 'Get Thee to the Funnery' Shakespeare Program is a fabulous community arts enrichment program serving youth in Chelsea, VT and the surrounding towns.  We offer confidence-building, laughter-cultivating, skill-sharing summer Shakespeare intensives for students age 10-18, as well as weekend workshops throughout the year.  We perform outdoors and in the historic Town Hall in Chelsea where we can practice booming our voices chock full of old English poetry out to our adoring and attentive multi-generational audiences.

In our programming students train in voice, movement, clowning, and improvisational theater as well as putting on free community performances of a Shakespeare production each summer.  The performances are entrancing, wild, sprawling and brimming with enthusiasm and heart.

Because of generous individuals and local businesses like you our program is able to fulfill its two part mission:

  • To create an enriching, community oriented, confidence building, and fun youth theater program in the community of Chelsea, VT and surrounding towns.
  • To offer these high quality artistic opportunities affordably to all interested students and their families.

This $3500 that we are raising is 25% of our annual budget for all the programming that The Chelsea Funnery offers throughout the year. Your donations go directly to:

  • ​Providing scholarships for any student in need, ranging from $25 to full tuition coverage.
  • Keeping our tuition costs low for every student​ 
  • Supporting low cost weekend workshops through out the year

This project is a labor of love for us, for the students, and for everyone involved in the community.  It is a joy to see these students risk and blossom over such a short period of time, as well as seeing them grow into powerful actors, and dynamic and compassionate adults year after year. We hope you will join us this summer to see it for yourself.

It takes a village, nay, a widespread community with lots of heart to make this program happen, and we, actors, families, and staff, are extraordinarily grateful for all the support we receive.

Find out a whole lot more at our website thechelseafunnery.com

The Chelsea Funnery is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Chelsea Funnery must  be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Happy Few Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Happy Few Theatre Company must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above perk value is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Our Company:

the goodbye room is the second production of Happy Few Theatre Company! Based in New York City, we aim to create actor-driven productions that find the fundamental joy of storytelling in both classic and new plays. We hope to engage audiences with productions that speak to ideas of community and what is continually human, in a stripped-down approach that is direct, inventive and fun.

Our first production, a seven-person As You Like It, received three New York Innovative Theatre Award nominations, for Outstanding Revival, Outstanding Ensemble, and Outstanding Original Music. Reviewers said the production was “gutsy, highly enjoyable,” and “leaves you happy,” while the actors were all “masters of their craft,” “hot,” and that “the whole cast brings alive the beauty of Shakespeare’s words with clarity and passion, and…keeps the audience propelled throughout with their talent.”

For our second production, we are excited to presenting the world premiere of a brand new play, which is an equally important kind of work for us, and with the same emphasis on a production that is what theatre’s really about—being together in a single room.

Your support is crucial. Whether you helped us found the company by contributing to our inaugural production or whether you’re thinking about helping us out for the first time now, your donations are the only thing that make our work possible. Our Indiegogo campaign for As You Like It was our sole source of funding for the production, and we used 98% of the funds raised for direct production needs and artist stipends.

Our Production:

the goodbye room, a new play by Eric Gilde, gives us a window into the relationship of two sisters following their mother’s death. Set in a quiet Midwestern town, the play’s four characters each have a story to tell, a contemporary lens on a timeless problem. Are grieving and moving forward two sides of the same coin? Simple but heartfelt, the play explores what we hide, what we share, and the individuality of response to this most universal of human experiences.

The production will run March 3 – 19, 2016, evenings and Sunday matinees, at the Bridge Theatre in Shetler Studios, conveniently located at 244 W. 54th street in midtown Manhattan.

Who We Are:

Happy Few Theatre Company is excited to welcome in a few new company members for this production! Co-Artistic Directors Eric Gilde (directing) and Ellen Adair (“Bex”) will be joined by the very talented Craig Wesley Divino, Sarah Killough, and Michael Selkirk. Sarah Lahue, our indomitable stage manager for As You Like It, will be returning, as will Brittany Crowell, in the role of production manager.

Our Budget:

Our budget is $10,250. Which is a lot of money—we know!—but we got to that number by adding together these ones:

$4,450 – Space. About half of our budget goes to renting the theatre for our tech process and three weeks of performances ($3,450) and our four weeks of rehearsal in the most affordable spaces we could find ($1,100). Many Off-Off Broadway theatre spaces in Manhattan can cost $3,000 PER WEEK, so we are trying to make this production happen as affordably as possible.

$2,500 – Artist stipends for 4 actors, 3 designers, a stage manager, production manager and a house manager, $250 apiece. Actors’ Equity requires that actors in its union are given payment for a transportation stipend in the labor-of-love contract that we’re all working under. We think it’s only fair that our tireless management team and brilliant designers and tech team receive the same compensation. We will be having a couple more performances of the goodbye room than our last production, so we have given everyone a little bit of a raise. Still, $250 for a couple of months of love of and work is far less than we wish we could give!

$200 – Volunteer Accident Insurance. To cover the lovely and talented people on the line item above.

$100 – Costumes

$1000 – Sets. We want to turn a little black box theatre into a Midwestern living room.

$200 – Props

$50 – Additional Lighting Equipment. Most of what we need is supplied by the theatre!

$1250 – Publicity and PR

$275 – Programs, Scripts

$125 – Stage Management Expenses (Rehearsal and Cleaning Supplies, Laundry)

How You Can Help:

Mounting a second production can be even more challenging than creating a first, and your support is more important to us now than ever. Please help Happy Few Theatre Company continue to make work that is truly audience-driven, but doesn’t have to cater to the production boundaries of organizations with a larger upkeep.

We know it’s a hard time for everyone to donate, but no gift is too small. A little can go a long way in the world of small independent theatre! Having a large number of donors behind us will support us in spirit as well as in practical financial terms. In addition, your donations are fully tax-deductible, through the sponsorship of this production by Fractured Atlas.

If you would prefer to donate by check, please email us at happyfewtheatre@gmail.com for specific instructions. Checks must be made out to Fractured Atlas; we cannot accept checks made out to the production or the company.

If you’re not able to donate but want to support us, please spread the word about this campaign and about our company. Follow us on Facebook for updates on the show and entertaining tidbits, and share our page with friends who might be interested in seeing the show or the work that we do.

Contributions and Perks:

If you are able to donate (whatever you believe in, bless you!), we have a few small perks as an effort to express our gratitude. Please know that the fair market value of our perks will not be part of your tax-deductible donation—if you would prefer not to get a perk and have the fully-deductible amount instead, enter the amount rather than choosing the perk.

Neighbor $10 – We will give you a personalized thank-you on your Facebook page and our own.

Friend $25 – You will receive one ticket to a performance, and your name will appear in our printed program in addition to our Facebook gratitude.

Best Friend $50 – Receive TWO tickets to any performance, your name in our printed program, and Facebook love. 

Sibling $100 – Receive all of the above, plus a magnet of the show art with a personalized thank-you.

Parent $250 – Sponsor-an-artist! For only $250, you can pay the stipend for an actor, manager or designer.  You will receive all of the above, plus credit in the program as the patron of the performance or design you have sponsored, and a magnet with the production artwork, signed by the artist you sponsored, AND a signed copy of the play!

Spirit $500 – Associate Producer! You will receive all of the above, except that you will be credited in our program as an Associate Producer, above an Artist Sponsor. You will also receive a signed copy of Ellen’s book of poetry about acting, plays, and a life in the theatre, Curtain Speech along with a signed copy of the goodbye room.

Angel $1000 – Producer! You will receive all of the above, plus credit on the front of the program as a Producer of the show. In addition to a signed copies of work by the Artistic Directors as mentioned above, you can commission Ellen for a matted original drawing of anything you choose, production-related or otherwise, come out with the cast after a performance for a toast, or both!

Here are a couple of examples of commissioned drawings of As You Like It, but Ellen will happily give a try to anything you'd like:


Please note that your offer of a ticket or tickets for any amount above $25 will still require making a reservation for a particular evening. We encourage you to make those reservations early since they will not guarantee you a space should performances sell out, and our performance space is very intimate—we want the audience to be part of the family!
story_txt:
Happy Few Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Happy Few Theatre Company must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above perk value is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.Our Company:
the goodbye room is the second production of Happy Few
Theatre Company! Based in New York City, we aim to create actor-driven
productions that find the fundamental joy of storytelling in both classic and
new plays. We hope to engage audiences with productions that speak to ideas of
community and what is continually human, in a stripped-down approach that is
direct, inventive and fun. 
Our first production, a seven-person As You Like It,
received three New York Innovative Theatre Award nominations, for Outstanding
Revival, Outstanding Ensemble, and Outstanding Original Music. Reviewers said
the production was “gutsy, highly enjoyable,” and “leaves you happy,” while the
actors were all “masters of their craft,” “hot,” and that “the whole cast
brings alive the beauty of Shakespeare’s words with clarity and passion, and…keeps
the audience propelled throughout with their talent.” 
For our second production, we are excited to presenting the
world premiere of a brand new play, which is an equally important kind of work
for us, and with the same emphasis on a production that is what theatre’s
really about—being together in a single room.
Your support is crucial. Whether you helped us found the
company by contributing to our inaugural production or whether you’re thinking
about helping us out for the first time now, your donations are the only thing
that make our work possible. Our Indiegogo campaign for As You Like It was
our sole source of funding for the production, and we used 98% of the funds
raised for direct production needs and artist stipends.

story:
Described by the Herald as 'dauntingly impressive', 'compellingly charismatic and compellingly watchable'  and as a 'choreographer of immense power'  by Gareth K Vile/ the Vile Arts/ The List, acclaimed choreographer Jack Webb is looking for your help!

 Hello!
My name is Jack Webb. I'm a choreographer based in Edinburgh and for the past 10 years I've been working internationally as a dancer and choreographer with various companies and choreographers. Read about me here - http://www.jackwebbperformance.com/jack-webb.html
I'm looking for your help to realise my latest work 'THE END'.
What on Earth is 'THE END'?
'THE END' is a new 70 minute contemporary dance performance and is a Tramway co-production.

  What's it all about then?

'THE END' is very important project to me. It emerged during a time of choreographic research when I was considering what it might mean if I were to STOP choreographing altogether. What would I be left with? 
But I found that the idea of endings became very inspiring because it suddenly made a lot of space for new and positive beginnings!

'THE END' will be a work that uses 'THE END' as a motivation to ask questions about the human condition by making similar dramatic provocations. What will the end of the world be like? What would you say in the last moment at the end of your life? What are our internal experiences and thoughts at the end of a performance or the end of a disco and what does that euphoric feeling leave us with for the future? By only ending our movements do we create a new way to speak to the audience? In the fragile and short moments between an end and a beginning, what sort of universe exists within that time that we could learn something from? When we end something, is this an opportunity to look at things differently, openly and begin again? In our society today, are we in between an end and a beginning, and if so, where are we now and where are we going next politically and culturally? Considering all of these provocations, 'THE END' mixes together personal, universal and primal experiences of the dancers and choreographer with an aim to communicate basic elements of the human condition that everyone can relate to. 

Where can I see 'THE END'?

'THE END' will premier at the world renowned Tramway in Glasgow on 10th and 11th June 2016 and then will tour in the UK to cities including

-Edinburgh

-Aberdeen

-London

-Dundee

-other venues TBC


Who is in 'THE END'?

'THE END' is performed by 3 extraordinary and inspiring dancers - Rachael O'Neill, Martyn Garside and Keren Smail all of whom are accomplished very talented dancers and performers. Oh and I'm in it too!


Where will your donation go?

Unfortunately a funding application wasn't successful to make this project happen. Boo! But I have some funds in place for some of the project but it's not quite enough. Another £5000 needs to be raised. Your donation will go towards

-paying 3 extraordinary dancers a decent fee

-paying the choreographer (that's me!)

-travel and accommodation on tour

-PR and marketing materials to advertise the show


PERKS!

For your donation you can receive a variety of perks to thank you including

-thank you on social media and my website and a personal email

- a personalised photograph

-a 1 minute special made dance video inspired by 'THE END'

- an invitation to see the work in progress before it premiers and a meet and greet with tea and cake in the studio


The Impact of you donation

I strongly believe that even if the circumstances aren't perfect, it's essential to try to make it happen anyway.
I'm committed to contributing to the cultural landscape of Scotland and the UK as much as I can. With my work, I aim to provide an opportunity that people can be inspired by, can spark social and cultural change, can contribute to the ongoing development and growth of contemporary dance as an art form and providing artists and the public with an engaging, compelling and thought provoking experience in a time where the world needs it most. Art is important, essential, fun, crazy, inspiring and can give us all something of value.
Your donation will ensure that the talented dancers I want to work with can be employed and free from exploitation, ensuring that our working practice is ethical.
It will also help me to create a rich artistic experience for the public, a small but hopefully important contribution to the world.
