story:
Mister USofA MI Nationals

My name is Maren Brucker, and I am a Male Illusionist out of Champaign Illinois known as Presley Stardust. https://www.facebook.com/PresleyStardust For many, Male Illusion simply means Drag King; however it equates to so much more than dressing in mens clothing. True Male Illusion involves extensive make-up, dancing, costumes and music that make it an art form beyond mere dress up.

I have recently earned my ticket to compete in the Mister USofA MI Nationals this year in Nashville, Tennessee as the 2nd Alternate of Ohio-Valley Team; and am beyond elated to be doing so. 

I have only been working on my craft for a little under a year and to have come this far in such a short amount of time is truly a dream that I could have never imagined to have achieved. Raising the funds for this event will allow me to continue pushing forward as an artist in this medium, and to learn and grow from my fellow artists who are Male Illusionists. 

The penultimate goal of Mister USofA MI Nationals would be for me to become Mister USofA MI. At this time I wish to achieve the experience of education, to learn as much as I can from my fellow brothers/artists, and to not come in last but prove myself to be more than a mere Drag King. 

Please feel free to obtain more information about the organization:

http://www.misterusofami.com/?page_id=96/

Getting Down to Financial Brass Tacks:

Male Illusion is not a cheap art, especially when you get to competing at the National level. All the money you will be donating will be spent down to the very last penny! I am hoping to at least to pay for hotel rooms and the rest is just gravy. I know times are hard, but I am hopeful.:

  • Hotel:Traveling down to Tennessee and staying for 5 nights adds up. 2 rooms at $50 a night + tax equals a little over $500.
  • Gas:Obviously it takes fuel to travel from Champaign, Illinois to Nashville, Tennessee and back with two vehicles. I am not at this point able to guess what the price will be in March.
  • Passes for Dancers:Optimally I will have 4 dancers traveling with me to Nationals. Each pass is $40 and that will total up to $160.
  • Whatever money is left over will all go to talent costumes and props, presentation wear, reworking my creative formal wear and hopefully a meal here and there.

Why should you donate?

We all have something we are passionate about and the art I am passionate about is slightly unconventional. It is difficult to find funding for this type of art, but it is still artistic and entertainment that allows expression and provides joy to many. 

I am also a 30 year old woman with a B.F.A. in Art and Theatre who has been searching for a long time to find a platform of expression that speaks to me the way that Male Illusion does. Many of these artist have been working on their craft since they were in their late teens and early twenties. Being a late bloomer in the game I am more than anxious to "head to Male Illusion college" and throw myself into the 60 foot pool to see if I can swim.  

Your donations help me to be a better performer, to shape me as an artist, and give me the opportunity to do things that I would not be able to do on my own fiscally. 

Times Are Hard Out There...

I realize that things are challanging financially for some, so if a financial contribution isn't possible at this time PLEASE get the word out about my campaign. Vital word of mouth and internet spreed are the best ways to get this quest up and running without financial contribution. Tell your friends, neighbors and family. And thank you for taking time to read about my cause and at least be a little more informed about my art.

story:
Our Story

Rhythm is our Business. And we are the American Tap Dance Foundation, a non-profit 501c3 Tap Dance Organization located in the West Village, New York City.

 

For 25 years we’ve been:

- creating new venues and original productions!


- presenting unique artists and contemporary choreography!

- educating the next generation and building new audience!


- preserving the American history of tap dance!

 

 

In January of 2010, we moved into our new home at the American Tap Dance Center. Our training programs promote the joyful embodiment of rhythm and build critical life skills through active cooperation, creative problem solving, patience, confidence, discipline and attuned listening. 

 

BUT, we need a new LIGHTING SYSTEM to function properly. We have lights, but they are old, broken down and very harsh. We have around 500 people coming each week for daily tap classes. 190 of these students are kids. They deserve to see and be seen!

The Impact

Our philosophy is that Tap Dance is MUSIC and a UNIVERSAL form of expression; plus it’s FUN, HEALTHY and ACCESSIBLE to everyone!

 

Supporting our programs, and helping us raise enough funds for a new lighting system will give ALL of us (our teachers, our students, and our staff) a brighter future. 


Join us in CELEBRATING 25 YEARS of bringing Tap Dance into the world by donating $25!

What We Need & What You Get

Your donations, large or small, will make this happen. We have already enlisted the DONATED services of a parent who is an expert in the field, and Con Edison is offering a 70% discount on energy efficient systems. We know what we need, and we are ready to act. The cost of our new lighting system will be realized in savings on our utility bill within two years!

 

If you choose to support this project, we would like to acknowledge your gift online, on-site and in future monthly newsletters. And as a gift back to the community, we want to hold a number of FREE educational events that will be open to the public and celebrate our new home and new lighting system. LET THERE BE LIGHT!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this project with your friends and families. And if you live in New York, come on down and see what we're all about. Many thanks!

story:
Bref résumé

Cinq femmes, cinq amies… ou presque.  Quand l’une d’entre elles meurt du cancer,
une étrange entente qu’elle a conçue avant sa mort remet en question  l’amitié des cinq femmes. 

L'entente donne vigueur à cinq femmes Québécoises d'origines diverses: Québec, Amérique Latine, Europe de l'Est et l'Inde.  Ces cinq femmes sont éduquées, intelligentes et indépendantes.  On ne parle pas d'images stéréotypiques de femme immigrante - femme de ménage, femme soumise.  Place à cinq comédiennes d'être les vedettes d'une pièce de théâtre sous la mise en scène d'une femme.

Message du metteur en scène Jacqueline van de Geer

5 femmes, venant de différentes origines, toutes amies depus des années, toutes heureuses sur la surface avec du comfort et du succès.  Mais quand l'une d'elle souffre du cancer, la réalité les force de laisser tomber leur façade, l'une après l'autre.  Quand j'ai lu cette pièce, je me suis sentie liée à l'histoire, l'amitié entre ces femmes, leurs jalousies, leurs petites compétitions et l'humour, surtout le thème qu'une maladie détruit les superficies entre elles.  De plus, je suis ravie de travailler avec une distribution multiethnique et féminine, une chance rare car, en général, la plupart des scénarios prêtent plus d'importance aux rôles masculins.  J'espère que L'entente sera disponible au publique francophone bientôt car "la langue des thèmes" de cette pièce est universelle!

Ce qu'en pense nos spectateurs

« La distribution est fantastique.  Même Jen et sa mère qui ont fait face a une perte semblable tous récemment on senti que le tout a été présenté non seulement avec bon goût mais aussi avec de l’optimisme réaliste qui les a touché. »

Donald Rees, comédien, producteur

« Quelle superbe performance!  Bravo Christine Rodriguez et votre équipe douée!  J’ai été de plus impressionnée par votre spectacle à 100% rempli. »

Kristina Tomaz-Young, chroniqueuse, productrice VC-TV

« … Actrices incroyablement bonnes, chacune dans son style, très réelles, attachantes, j'ai adoré..... » 

Nancy Normand-Phillips

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous espérons collecter $1000 pour nous aider à couvrir les coûts de la production et lever des fonds pour Cancer de l'ovaire Canada (en relation à l'histoire de L'entente). 

Voici un bref apperçu du budget:

Coûts prévus:

Location de salle de spectacle: $2800

Location de salle de répétition: $620

Éclairage et scénographie: $540

Coût de marketing et promotions: $900

Total des coûts: $4860

Revenues prévus:

Ventes de billets: $1860 (net après le don à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada)

Campagne Indiegogo: $800 (net après le don à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada)

Dons des artistes: $2300

Total des revenus: $4960

Profits net: $100 à partager comme salaire entre les artistes...

Tout surplus qu'il pourrait nous rester à la fin des spectacles, si nous obtenons un nombre de spectateur plus élevé que prévu, serait distribué également parmis les artitstes qui, en ce moment, travaillent sur la production sans aucun salaire: comédiennes, metteur en scène, régies, directeur de son et de musique.

20% des fonds collectés vont à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada.  Ce qui veux dire que votre appui aidera à la fois le théâtre et à la fois le lutte contre le cancer.

Vous pouvez visiter www.5femmes.com pour en savoir plus sur les artistes qui font partie de l'équipe de L'entente ainsi que sur les projects antécédents entrepris par ces artistes y compris Dreaming in Autism de Christine Rodriguez qui a remporté plusieurs prix et nominations artistiques au courant de la dernière année: www.dreaminginautism.com.
story_txt:
Bref résumé
Cinq femmes, cinq amies… ou presque.  Quand l’une d’entre elles meurt du cancer,une étrange entente qu’elle a conçue avant sa mort remet en question  l’amitié des cinq femmes.  
L'entente donne vigueur à cinq femmes Québécoises d'origines diverses: Québec, Amérique Latine, Europe de l'Est et l'Inde.  Ces cinq femmes sont éduquées, intelligentes et indépendantes.  On ne parle pas d'images stéréotypiques de femme immigrante - femme de ménage, femme soumise.  Place à cinq comédiennes d'être les vedettes d'une pièce de théâtre sous la mise en scène d'une femme.
Message du metteur en scène Jacqueline van de Geer
5 femmes, venant de différentes origines, toutes amies depus des années, toutes heureuses sur la surface avec du comfort et du succès.  Mais quand l'une d'elle souffre du cancer, la réalité les force de laisser tomber leur façade, l'une après l'autre.  Quand j'ai lu cette pièce, je me suis sentie liée à l'histoire, l'amitié entre ces femmes, leurs jalousies, leurs petites compétitions et l'humour, surtout le thème qu'une maladie détruit les superficies entre elles.  De plus, je suis ravie de travailler avec une distribution multiethnique et féminine, une chance rare car, en général, la plupart des scénarios prêtent plus d'importance aux rôles masculins.  J'espère que L'entente sera disponible au publique francophone bientôt car "la langue des thèmes" de cette pièce est universelle!
Ce qu'en pense nos spectateurs
« La distribution est fantastique.  Même Jen et sa mère qui ont fait face a une perte semblable tous récemment on senti que le tout a été présenté non seulement avec bon goût mais aussi avec de l’optimisme réaliste qui les a touché. » 
Donald Rees, comédien, producteur
« Quelle superbe performance!  Bravo Christine Rodriguez et votre équipe douée!  J’ai été de plus impressionnée par votre spectacle à 100% rempli. » 
Kristina Tomaz-Young, chroniqueuse, productrice VC-TV
« … Actrices incroyablement bonnes, chacune dans son style, très réelles, attachantes, j'ai adoré..... »  
Nancy Normand-PhillipsCe dont nous avons besoin
Nous espérons collecter $1000 pour nous aider à couvrir les coûts de la production et lever des fonds pour Cancer de l'ovaire Canada (en relation à l'histoire de L'entente).  
Voici un bref apperçu du budget:
Coûts prévus:
Location de salle de spectacle: $2800
Location de salle de répétition: $620
Éclairage et scénographie: $540
Coût de marketing et promotions: $900
Total des coûts: $4860
Revenues prévus:
Ventes de billets: $1860 (net après le don à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada)
Campagne Indiegogo: $800 (net après le don à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada)
Dons des artistes: $2300
Total des revenus: $4960
Profits net: $100 à partager comme salaire entre les artistes...
Tout surplus qu'il pourrait nous rester à la fin des spectacles, si nous obtenons un nombre de spectateur plus élevé que prévu, serait distribué également parmis les artitstes qui, en ce moment, travaillent sur la production sans aucun salaire: comédiennes, metteur en scène, régies, directeur de son et de musique.
20% des fonds collectés vont à Cancer de l'ovaire Canada.  Ce qui veux dire que votre appui aidera à la fois le théâtre et à la fois le lutte contre le cancer.
Vous pouvez visiter www.5femmes.com pour en savoir plus sur les artistes qui font partie de l'équipe de L'entente ainsi que sur les projects antécédents entrepris par ces artistes y compris Dreaming in Autism de Christine Rodriguez qui a remporté plusieurs prix et nominations artistiques au courant de la dernière année: www.dreaminginautism.com.

story:
SHE Dance Production Is a brand new Company that has been launched since July 2013, created and founded by Mireille Kabala. 

 This production is created to celebrate the essence of different African Art projects by fusing traditional and Modern culture together through Dance and ART.

 It is a Metaphor based on a relationship between Old African generation and New African generation cultural battle of life style and morals. 

 This production was inspired in respect of the late Mrs Bankina (Mireille's grand mother). The first project from SHE is called "Battle of the Vixens".

 A battle between the tribal and the futuristic fighting for power.. The SHE Production is seeking funding to film a short film which will showcase the story telling. 

 The location of the project is in a beach which is why the production team is looking to film in a sunny location like the south of Spain for a 2 day filming. The funding will cover

 *Travel

 *Filming Equipment 

 *Editing 

 *Costumes/ Make-up

 *Cast & Crew 

This project was designed to create opportunities for artists who want to build a portfolio and gain new skills, The production team believes that new inspiring artists create amazing, organic work and also offers to be expressive and creative. 

 We hope that your generous donation will allow us to preform an amazing concept.  

Thank you

story:
Another Evening of Awkward Romance has been accepted into the New York International Fringe Festival!

Wendy Herlich is back, with a whole new collection of awkwardly romantic characters and situations. The second in a series, Another Evening of Awkward Romance features six laugh-out-loud vignettes, including a chronic sinus infection sufferer who is infatuated with her pharmacist, a pair of lovelorn auctioneers, and dueling church choir members. This two-person comedy offers an unvarnished take on the search for love, and celebrates human beings at our most odd, endearing, and vulnerable.

Another Evening of Awkward Romance is the follow-up to An Evening of Awkward Romance, which ran at the Tank in NYC in February of 2012. Theatre Is Easy said, "...Fast-paced, hilarious, playful, and often-poignant writing...It's a successful mix: clever, evocative, and tender." The Happiest Medium said, "Ms. Herlich proves that she is not only a gifted writer with the ability to create short sketches which manage to be sweet, funny and (yes) awkward all at once, but she is also a deft comedic actress who can play any number of roles, ranging from whimsical to deadpan, with equal results: an audience that finds itself erupting in laughter as one scene after the next plays out."

We are so excited about this opportunity. FringeNYC is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, and provides great exposure for the project. Our broader goal includes exploring future possibilities for this production, and FringeNYC is a great step in that direction.

Ruthie Levy is back on board as our director, and Aaron Phillips has joined Wendy Herlich to make up the cast.

How you can get involved

Your contribution will help underwrite the following expenses:

  • Payment for all staff involved, including talent, lighting board programmer, director, video editor, venue director, and stagehands
  • Fringe fees, which cover administrative and venue costs
  • Rehearsal space rental fees
  • Insurance for the production
  • Publicity and marketing costs
  • Costumes, props, and set
  • Postcards and programs

By contributing, you are supporting independent theatre, and you will be a part of this exciting project, which we hope will have a long life beyond this festival. All of the donations will go toward the expenses associated with mounting this production. The most exciting perk is the one for those who donate $1,000 or more: your name included in the show!*

Other ways you can help

Come and see the show! FringeNYC runs 8/9 through 8/25. We will have exact performance dates and times assigned sometime in early July; like us on Facebook so you can stay updated. 

Spread the word and let others know where to buy tickets for Another Evening of Awkward Romance.

For more information, visit wendyherlich.com. Thank you for your support!

*It might be just your first name, just your last name, or both. It might be mentioned once, in passing, or be the given name of a main character. But somehow, it'll be in there!

story:
THE PLAY

As the tenth anniversary of September 11th approaches, Apple Core Theater Company will produce By the Dawn's Early Light, two new one-acts by Mel Nieves illustrating the impact of that fateful day on three Latino families in New York City. Directed by Walter J. Hoffman, performances will begin on August 11th at the Studio Theatre on Theatre Row.

 

In Los Embrujados, a nervous waiter at the Windows on the World restaurant studies with his gregarious brother for his impending U.S. Citizenship test. It's a time of possibilities on this bright, clear September morning, and as he prepares for his new life, "Los Embrujados" illuminates what it means to be an American.

 

Our second play, Midnight Mass, follows a group of New Yorkers connected by 9/11: a war veteran whose trauma may cost him his family; his brother, who must leave his pregnant fiancee to go on his first tour of duty; a nurse whose husband perished in the Towers; and a fireman desperate to reclaim the courage he knew as a First Responder. In the wake of tragedy, Midnight Mass reveals the profound struggle to regain hope and faith. 

THE DEAL

We are so, SO thankful for the generous friends we've met over the past year who have made the first phase of development for this project possible. But as a Tennessee Williams character might say, we must not only depend upon the kindness of our friends, but upon EVERYONE. That guy we always see on the train to work, the exceedingly cool couple we met at a buddy's party in Brooklyn, and grade school teachers whose first names we never knew. And you.

 

With two months before the show to go, we hope to raise $2,000. And we hope you'll help us with a completely tax-deductible donation.

 

And what's more, your campaign will not only help us put on this beautiful show:

** Just as we fundraised over $1,500 for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS during our recent production of As Is, we will "pass the hat" after every show to raise money for organizations that serve First Responders and the families of 9/11 victims.

** As affordability and accessibility are primary components of our mission, your support will also help keep our ticket price at a remarkable $15. You can't beat that in NYC.

** And of course, you'll make a lot of working theater artists who are passionate about the project very, very happy.

Want some reassurance that your donation -- no matter how great or small (or GRRRRRRRRREAT!!!) -- will make a difference? Then check out the levels to your right, which break down what your donation could pay for.

THE OTHER DEAL

Can't contribute now? For our sake and yours, don't go sleepless at night -- you can still make By the Dawn's Early Light possible. 

** Help us fundraise by sharing this link with your family and friends! Please consider Facebook, Twitter, email, smoke signals and semaphore!

** If you're in New York City, you can still make a huge impact by donating (or even lending!) furniture and props to the show. Just contact allison@applecoretheatercompany.org for more information. 

** We always need friends to get the word out about the shows.Tell them to like us on Facebook (and in real life), follow us on Twitter, to read our blog, and to sign up for our mailing list at www.applecoretheatercompany.org.

** Or maybe you want to see the show! And not only that, but we want to see you. Remember: tickets are only $15. At the beginning of July, you can find us on www.telecharge.com.

Thank you -- really, thank you for all your support. We look forward to sharing By the Dawn's Early Light with you this August!

story:
Flashmobs Against Rape 

Summary: I am raising $10,000 to go on tour for 6 months through East and Southern Africa beginning in January 2014. My goal is to use dance as a platform to support leadership development of girls and boys to end violence against girls and women.

Why Africa? 

My commitment to Africa began as a child. When those terrible Sally Struthers commercials would come on, I would bust into tears upon seeing the starving children with flies all over them. I would beg my mother to call the phone number on the screen. I would cry, 'We have to do something mom!' My mom would call and we would get the materials. We didn't have much, but we shared what we had. 

'What can I do?' This was the question that moved me to write poetry for Africa as a child and day dream of solutions to end famine. Later, in high school, it would lead me to join forces with my best friend Kim Morgan and make a presentation in one of our classes on Apartheid. We showed the video of the song Sun City by Artists United Against Apartheid (http://youtu.be/TlMdYpnVOGQ). I realized that art is such a powerful way to raise awareness. 

When the song 'We Are the World' came out, I believed every word. When I look back on it art and activism and Africa have always been connected for me. It was the beginning of vague notions that art could change the world. I have never stopped asking 'What can I do?' With time, arts and activism in Africa would be my answer. 


Why Focus on Violence Against Girls and Women?

When my brother died in 2001, I decided that life was too short to not realize my dream of going to Africa.  Unable to afford most exchange programs, I contacted foundations funding in Africa and identified reputable grassroots organizations. I contacted the organizations directly and set up my own work exchange program.

On my 30th birthday, I threw a fundraising party complete with soul food and a DJ and  invited everyone I knew. I bought my airline ticket and left for six months. I lived with total strangers in six different countries (South Africa, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Tanzania, Zanzibar and Kenya) and visited advocacy focused organizations. Mind blowing -to say the least- I realized that this is what I wanted to do with my life. 

One of the organizations that I lived with was Girl Child Network (GCN) in Zimbabwe.  Eight years later, GCN Founder Betty Makoni would win the CNN ordinary heros award for providing a safe haven for girl survivors of sexual abuse. 

One woman can make extraordinary change in this world! 

Unfortunately, I was raped in South Africa the night before I left Africa. This launched a 12 year healing journey for me that centered on expressive arts and faith. I would like to share my experience, strength and hope of overcoming violence, poverty and gender based discrimination with African girls. 

African girls often face a large social narrative that their hopes and dreams do not matter. The obstacles are large and significant: 

  • discrimination based on gender 
  • lack of access to education 
  • harmful cultural practices such as early marriage and
  • poverty

The perils of poverty often force girls to make horrific choices: food or sex? Sanitary pads or education? Basic needs or domestic work where they often face abuses of power including sexual exploitation and rape. 

Violence against girls and women is an issue that hurts us all. We need girls to survive. We need boys to understand their power to create instead of destroy. We are being called to healing, so we can survive, live and maybe even thrive as a human race. 


Violence Against Girls and Women on the Rise in Africa

My first position working for Africa was in 2002 when I was Africa Program Director at International Development Exchange. During a site visit to Zimbabwe, I was asked to give a speech to more than 100 girls. I wrote a speech called, 'What do you hold onto in difficult times?' Here is an excerpt: 

You have gone through too much

You have come to far to stop now

You survived for a reason 

You are a warrior

Your eyes were not made for crying only

You were not born to suffer

Did you see the moon? Did you see the flowers?

Did you look in the mirror? How beautiful! 

Put your hand on your heart -You are still here- and that is everything

Hold on to your dreams

Hold onto hope

Hold on to each other

We can walk through together 

Ending Rape:We Can Walk Through Together 

I have been to East and Southern Africa on five different occasions:

  • 2001: Tour at advocacy focused organizations
  • 2002 and 2003: Africa Program Director (focus: economic development) 
  • 2006: Consultant for foundations (focus: grassroots giving)
  • 2011: Country Director (focus: education of girls) 

However, my passion for being a critical link to creating a better and safer world for girls and women in Africa, never left me and I tracked rape and sexual violation cases in Africa. 

Over the years, I have noticed a disturbing trend of sexual violence in Africa. 

I was in South Africa when a nine-month old baby girl was raped by six men in 2001: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/1362134/South-African-men-rape-babies-as-cure-for-Aids.html).

At the same time, I have also begun to read more and more about the rape of boys:  http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Brave-boy-walks-home-with-baby-after-rapes-20130807).

When I was working and living in Kenya from 2011 to 2013, everyday I read articles in the national newspaper that reported sexual violence against girls. One article featured local hospitals warning that sexual violence against children was on the rise. 

Here is an example of article about the gang rape of a 16 year old girl in Kenya: 

http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/DN2/When-rapists-go-scot-free/-/957860/2022572/-/skd9s8z/-/index.html

South Africa has been dubbed the rape capital of the world with a South African woman more likely to be raped than educated: http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/a424c0804af19b5e9583fd7db529e2d0/SouthAfrica,-worlds-rape-capital:-Interpol-20121904

In Zimbabwe, rape of girls is on the rise: 

http://allafrica.com/stories/201309020810.html

Historically, sexual violence has been used as a weapon of war with Rwanda being no exception: http://www.nation.co.ke/oped/Opinion/-/440808/1999494/-/iw6nvbz/-/index.html

Join Me In Being Part of the Solution 

With your support, I would like to be a part of the solution that ends sexual violence from the ground up and inside-out. Flashmobs Against Rape will use dance as a platform to capacity building girls and boys to be leaders in their communities to end sexual violence in their lifetime. The Flashmobs Against Rape tour will take place in South Africa, Zimbabwe, Rwanda and Kenya. 

Flashmobs Against Rape: The Power of Organizing Girls Through Dance

Why Flashmobs? Dance is a powerful way to support leadership development of girls.  In a culture of silence and invisibility, dance is a powerful way for a girl to stand up and say, "I am here!' 

Flashmobs Against Rape affirms the human rights of a girl child and the power of boys to be allies to girls. Flashmobs Against Rape affirms the right of a girl to express herself, to been seen and heard and to be safe and powerful in this world. 

In 2011, I ran a school for 90 girls in rural Kenya. I decided to organize the girls into a flashmob for International Women's Day. After 75 hours of rehearsal with no mirrors, too many boxes of biscuits (cookies) to count and more than 15 hours of editing, this is the result: http://youtu.be/BlDD-7aP068

Comments from the girls: 

  • The flashmob was very nice indeed. I came to realize that one can make it no matter how difficult a situation can appear. The girls at first thought they could not perform the dance, because it looked so complicated, but due to the determination of [Kisha] the girls made it. Through the flashmob, we have come to know that one needs to care for herself before others can care for her. WISER girls need to be proud of themselves and tell people that they can make it.

 

  • What I realized is that there is no activity for boys and girls. What boys can do girls can also do. Flashmob is another way of controlling stress as it is a form of doing exercise.

 

  • I liked the flashmob due to the fact that it gave us a chance as girls to express our feelings to the community. I would like to thank [Kisha] for coming up with such a wonderful and powerful activity.

 

  • The flashmob helped me to develop confidence in myself. It enabled me [to] gain courage of acting in front of a crowd which I have never done before.  The song was interesting as it gave out the reality of what we as Muhuru girls go through. I really love the flashmob. 

How Does it Work? 

Flashmobs Against Rape is a tour that will span across 4 different countries in Africa and will set the groundwork for the creation of a model that can be replicated across the African continent and world!

Flashmobs Against Rape uses dance as a platform to bring together girls and boys to address the underlying and root causes of sexual violence against girls. Often root causes of sexual violence are linked to issues of power, cultural narratives around gender roles and place of children (purpose/value), health (i.e. popular misnomers such as sex with a virgin cures HIV/AIDS and children left vulnerable after loss of caregivers/parents death due to AIDS), trauma and poverty. 

Step 1: Identification of Girls: Girls will be identified through networks that I am currently engaged in, community based organizations and schools that I visit as part of the tour. 

Step 2: Flashmob Practices: Girls will be shown examples of flashmobs and will choose the music and any signs they want to create as part of their creative protest. Dance practices will be timed such that the mob is performed, taped and uploaded on Youtube in time for large international days (i.e. International Women's Day/Earth Day/International Day of the African Child) in order to support girls in linking their individual stories with global citizenship.

Step 3: Helping Girls Find Power In Their Stories Storytelling Workshops: Free workshops will be given to girls (and separate workshops for boys) as an extension of rehearsals for the Flashmob. Using Theatre of the Oppressed (drama based games that focus on power), writing, visual arts and music, girls and boys will be given the opportunity to explore who they are and how they choose to use their power in the face of larger social and cultural narratives that support sexual violence. 

Her Birth Right: 

To Be Safe and Powerful In this World

Her Place Her Power Her Possibility Her Story 

Flashmobs Against Rape is all about helping girls to love themselves. 

The tour will have the following outcomes: 

Leadership Development of Girls: Flashmobs Against Rape help girls to link their individual struggles -as girls- with a larger platform of human rights for women globally. Flashmobs Against Rape supports girls in harnessing their power to make powerful choices for themselves and make change in their community. 

Break Isolation and Shame: Gender based discrimination and sexual violence often leaves girls feeling powerless in their own lives. Stigma is a powerful force that keeps girls quiet, living in secret that undermines them. The storytelling workshops provide girls with a safe platform to ask questions, speak up and out and break isolation and shame. I plan to help her to harness their power in the face of old past time narratives that limit her place, her power and her possibility. Flashmobs Against Rape is a way for her to write a new story: her story! 

Healing:  Many girls that I have interviewed over the years suffer from such profound loss, the pain of discrimination and rejection and the emotional toll of poverty. The arts can be a powerful tool for healing and transformation of larger social narratives that get in her way of realizing her full potential. Through expressive arts, we support girls to tap into their inner power and creativity to be change agents to end sexual violence and poverty in their lifetime. 

Public Education: The flashmobs give girls what they don't have in their communities: a public platform for her to express herself, tell the truth of their experience (and be believed) and send a message that violation of girls and women is not okay. 

Create Community: Often girls get lost in their individual story, not realizing that their stories are inter-connected with other girls as they are individually confronting a larger story that you do not count or matter. When they can come together, they find support, strength and similarity of experience through something as simple and profound as dance.  

Flip the Script: Dancing with other girls can give her the power to take a stand that she may not otherwise take on her own, while writing a new script of her value, her vision and her place on the planet. Flashmobs Against Rape helps girls make their dreams come true. 


Funky, Fresh and Fierce!


Girl Power like Never Before!!

Innovative, moving, powerful and sustainable, the tour will culminate into organizing girls into a network called Girls Idea Generation which will support poor girls translating ideas into income generation. My intention is to follow the hopes, dreams and inspirations of the girls and created what is in the highest good for the girls. In the long term,  I plan to create a non -government organization: Girl Child Nation and institutionalize the learning from Flashmobs Against Rape. The focus of Girl Child Nation will be leadership development of girls. By 2017, Girl Child Nation will create a leadership development institution based in Africa for girls. The main goal of the institute will be to capacity build girls to use expressive arts as a tool for positive change at the grassroots throughout Africa. 

Goals of Flashmobs Against Rape Tour:

1,000 Girls in their Power: To reach 1,000 girls through the storytelling workshops and produce four flashmobs. 

Girl Child Survival Guide: As part of the storytelling workshops, I will be asking girls to give advice on how to survive as a girl in Africa. The art, poetry, essays and wisdom will be compiled into a book that will used as a peer to peer support guide offered to girl focused organizations globally. 

Girl Tech Africa: Using Technology to End Poverty and Sexual Violation      Ending inter-generational poverty is often linked with ending cycles of violence. I will sit in circles with girls as part of a listening campaign where I will ask girls: what are her dreams? What is in the way? How can we-as a global community- help you get there? Built from her hopes, dreams and her vision for herself, I will create an online platform to help make her dreams come true. Whether her dream is to access education or gain start up capital for entrepreneurship initiatives or network with professional women in her chosen field, Girl Tech Africa will lead social change for girls by following her wisdom. Girl Tech Africa bridges girls, technology and development on terms that support girl child leadership development.

Boy Child Alliance: Understanding that the empowerment of girls is interconnected with the empowerment of boys, I will create intentional forums to listen to boys, their issues, their challenges and their inheritance as boys. A core motivating question for me will be, 'What would it look like for a boy be fully in his power without violence against females?' I am planning on having workshops for boys that will use drama, dance and expressive arts to create dialogue on cultural and social narratives of manhood. This listening campaign will be the basis of creating a future network of boys called Boy Child Alliance that will focus on economic development of poor boys and developing a curriculum that can be implemented in schools to help boys to be allies to girls.

Wisdom Circles: External answers to grassroots economic development are not sustainable. I will be facilitating meetings with African women entrepreneurs and women in business to tap into their internal wisdom as to solutions on gender equity and economic self-sufficiency of girls and women as part of a larger vision of a women mentoring program for girls. 

Through supporting Flashmobs Against Rape you will be part of creating a new and innovative model of leadership development of African girls and boys! 

How Will I Use the Funds? 

$2,000 Round Trip ticket to Africa

$800 Flashmob (equipment/ snacks/logistics)

$500 Storytelling workshops (paper/pens/markers/materials)

$2,700 Food (estimated at $15/day for 6 months)

$500 Travel Insurance

$1,500 Travel within Africa (very expensive, but will use road as time allows)

$200 Visas 

$500  Medical expenses (paid cash and reimbursed through travel insurance)

$1,000 Housing (I am planning on using home based stays as much as possible) 

$300  airtime for phone  

=$10,000 

How is Flashmobs Against Rape's Model of Development Different? 

  • No Development without Addressing Trauma: Most traditional models of international development overlook the one thing that can undermine most efforts at empowerment of girls and women: trauma. Without addressing healing of trauma, efforts at educating and funding gender equity are not sustainable and are often undermined as girls and women attempt to cope with the fall out of sexual abuse, violence, loss, poverty and discrimination. 
  • Internal Healing, External Change: Flashmobs Against Rape bridges healing and social change activism and literally puts creativity back into her hands. Once she understands she has the power to create, she can create her future and her reality in the face of gender based oppression.  Through helping girls and women tap into their inner power and faith, I will support girls and women to live whole, healed lives as a means to ending inter-generational poverty and trauma.
  • We Need African Boys and Men to Survive: Working within a framework of healing trauma, Flashmobs Against Rape recognizes that poor boys are often also survivors of trauma. Far from criminalizing men, Flashmobs Against Rape works with boys to create a whole new possibility: one where boys and girls need each other to live whole and healed lives, share power and where they value the safety and well being of all. We will need the whole community to end sexual violence against girls and women. 

Thank You for Donating to Our Cause!

Your Love is Amazing!!

Ain't got no chedda? Don't worry! 

  • Share my Indiegogo link in your community. You would be surprised how a little link can go a long way! 
  • Host a Healing Party! I will send you a healing kit or come to you if you are on the West Coast! This is a great, fun and powerful way to both raise money for a great cause and help create a healed world. 
  • Ask your school, organization or corporation to sponsor the tour. We will feature their logos on our website!!
story_txt:
Flashmobs Against Rape 



Summary: I am
raising $10,000 to go on tour for 6 months through East and Southern Africa beginning in January 2014. My
goal is to use dance as a platform to support leadership development of girls
and boys to end violence against girls and women.
Why Africa? My commitment to Africa began as a child. When those terrible Sally Struthers commercials would come on, I would bust into tears upon seeing the starving children with flies all over them. I would beg my mother to call the phone number on the screen. I would cry, 'We have to do something mom!' My mom would call and we would get the materials. We didn't have much, but we shared what we had. 

'What can I do?' This was the question that moved me to write poetry for Africa as a child and day dream of solutions to end famine. Later, in high school, it would lead me to join forces with my best friend Kim Morgan and make a presentation in one of our classes on Apartheid. We showed the video of the song Sun City by Artists United Against Apartheid (http://youtu.be/TlMdYpnVOGQ). I realized that art is such a powerful way to raise awareness. 
When the song 'We Are the World' came out, I believed every word. When I look back on it art and activism and Africa have always been connected for me. It was the beginning of vague notions that art could change the world. I have never stopped asking 'What can I do?' With time, arts and activism in Africa would be my answer. 
Why Focus on Violence Against Girls and Women?When my brother died in 2001, I decided that life was too short to not realize my dream of going to Africa.  Unable to afford most exchange programs, I contacted foundations funding in Africa and identified reputable grassroots organizations. I contacted the organizations directly and set up my own work exchange program.
On my 30th birthday, I threw a fundraising party complete with soul food and a DJ and  invited everyone I knew. I bought my airline ticket and left for six months. I lived with total strangers in six different countries (South Africa, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Tanzania, Zanzibar and Kenya) and visited advocacy focused organizations. Mind blowing -to say the least- I realized that this is what I wanted to do with my life. 
One of the organizations that I lived with was Girl Child Network (GCN) in Zimbabwe.  Eight years later, GCN Founder Betty Makoni would win the CNN ordinary heros award for providing a safe haven for girl survivors of sexual abuse. 
One woman can make extraordinary change in this world! 
Unfortunately, I was raped in South Africa the night before I left Africa. This launched a 12 year healing journey for me that centered on expressive arts and faith. I would like to share my experience, strength and hope of overcoming violence, poverty and gender based discrimination with African girls. African girls often face a large social narrative that their hopes and dreams do not matter. The obstacles are large and significant: 



discrimination based on gender 


lack of access to education 


harmful cultural practices such as early marriage and


poverty



The perils of poverty often force girls to make horrific choices: food or sex? Sanitary pads or education? Basic needs or domestic work where they often face abuses of power including sexual exploitation and rape. 
Violence against girls and women is an issue that hurts us all. We need girls to survive. We need boys to understand their power to create instead of destroy. We are being called to healing, so we can survive, live and maybe even thrive as a human race. 

Violence Against Girls and Women on the Rise in Africa
My first position working for Africa was in 2002 when I was Africa Program Director at International Development Exchange. During a site visit to Zimbabwe, I was asked to give a speech to more than 100 girls. I wrote a speech called, 'What do you hold onto in difficult times?' Here is an excerpt: 



You have gone through too much
You have come to far to stop now
You survived for a reason 
You are a warrior
Your eyes were not made for crying only
You were not born to suffer
Did you see the moon? Did you see the flowers?
Did you look in the mirror? How beautiful! 
Put your hand on your heart -You are still here- and that is everything
Hold on to your dreams
Hold onto hope
Hold on to each other
We can walk through together 

Ending Rape:We Can Walk Through Together 
I have been to East and Southern Africa on five different occasions:


2001: Tour at advocacy focused organizations
2002 and 2003: Africa Program Director (focus: economic development) 
2006: Consultant for foundations (focus: grassroots giving)
2011: Country Director (focus: education of girls) 



However, my passion for being a critical link to creating a better and safer world for girls and women in Africa, never left me and I tracked rape and sexual violation cases in Africa. 
Over the years, I have noticed a disturbing trend of sexual violence in Africa. 
I was in South Africa when a nine-month old baby girl was raped by six men in 2001: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/1362134/South-African-men-rape-babies-as-cure-for-Aids.html).
At the same time, I have also begun to read more and more about the rape of boys:  http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Brave-boy-walks-home-with-baby-after-rapes-20130807).
When I was working and living in Kenya from 2011 to 2013, everyday I read articles in the national newspaper that reported sexual violence against girls. One article featured local hospitals warning that sexual violence against children was on the rise. 
Here is an example of article about the gang rape of a 16 year old girl in Kenya: 
http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/DN2/When-rapists-go-scot-free/-/957860/2022572/-/skd9s8z/-/index.html
South Africa has been dubbed the rape capital of the world with a South African woman more likely to be raped than educated: http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/a424c0804af19b5e9583fd7db529e2d0/SouthAfrica,-worlds-rape-capital:-Interpol-20121904
In Zimbabwe, rape of girls is on the rise: 
http://allafrica.com/stories/201309020810.html
Historically, sexual violence has been used as a weapon of war with Rwanda being no exception: http://www.nation.co.ke/oped/Opinion/-/440808/1999494/-/iw6nvbz/-/index.htmlJoin Me In Being Part of the Solution 
With your support, I would like to be a part of the solution that ends sexual violence from the ground up and inside-out. Flashmobs Against Rape will use dance as a platform to capacity building girls and boys to be leaders in their communities to end sexual violence in their lifetime. The Flashmobs Against Rape tour will take place in South Africa, Zimbabwe, Rwanda and Kenya. 

Flashmobs Against Rape: The Power of Organizing Girls Through Dance

Why Flashmobs? Dance is a powerful way to support leadership development of girls.  In a culture of silence and invisibility, dance is a powerful way for a girl to stand up and say, "I am here!' 
Flashmobs Against Rape affirms the human rights of a girl child and the power of boys to be allies to girls. Flashmobs Against Rape affirms the right of a girl to express herself, to been seen and heard and to be safe and powerful in this world. 
In 2011, I ran a school for 90 girls in rural Kenya. I decided to organize the girls into a flashmob for International Women's Day. After 75 hours of rehearsal with no mirrors, too many boxes of biscuits (cookies) to count and more than 15 hours of editing, this is the result: http://youtu.be/BlDD-7aP068
Comments from the girls: 



The flashmob was very nice indeed. I came to realize that
one can make it no matter how difficult a situation can appear. The girls at
first thought they could not perform the dance, because it looked so
complicated, but due to the determination of [Kisha] the girls made it. Through
the flashmob, we have come to know that one needs to care for herself before
others can care for her. WISER girls need to be proud of themselves and tell
people that they can make it.


 

What I realized is that there is no activity for boys and
girls. What boys can do girls can also do. Flashmob is another way of controlling
stress as it is a form of doing exercise.


 

I liked the flashmob due to the fact that it gave us a
chance as girls to express our feelings to the community. I would like to thank
[Kisha] for coming up with such a wonderful and powerful activity.


 

The flashmob helped me to develop confidence in myself. It
enabled me [to] gain courage of acting in front of a crowd which I have never
done before.  The song was
interesting as it gave out the reality of what we as Muhuru girls go through. I
really love the flashmob. 


How Does it Work? 
Flashmobs Against Rape is a tour that will span across 4 different countries in Africa and will set the groundwork for the creation of a model that can be replicated across the African continent and world!
Flashmobs Against Rape uses dance as a platform to bring together girls and boys to address the underlying and root causes of sexual violence against girls. Often root causes of sexual violence are linked to issues of power, cultural narratives around gender roles and place of children (purpose/value), health (i.e. popular misnomers such as sex with a virgin cures HIV/AIDS and children left vulnerable after loss of caregivers/parents death due to AIDS), trauma and poverty. 
Step 1: Identification of Girls: Girls will be identified through networks that I am currently engaged in, community based organizations and schools that I visit as part of the tour. 
Step 2: Flashmob Practices: Girls will be shown examples of flashmobs and will choose the music and any signs they want to create as part of their creative protest. Dance practices will be timed such that the mob is performed, taped and uploaded on Youtube in time for large international days (i.e. International Women's Day/Earth Day/International Day of the African Child) in order to support girls in linking their individual stories with global citizenship.
Step 3: Helping Girls Find Power In Their Stories Storytelling Workshops: Free workshops will be given to girls (and separate workshops for boys) as an extension of rehearsals for the Flashmob. Using Theatre of the Oppressed (drama based games that focus on power), writing, visual arts and music, girls and boys will be given the opportunity to explore who they are and how they choose to use their power in the face of larger social and cultural narratives that support sexual violence. 
Her Birth Right: 
To Be Safe and Powerful In this World
Her Place Her Power Her Possibility Her Story 
Flashmobs Against Rape is all about helping girls to love themselves. 
The tour will have the following outcomes: 
Leadership Development of Girls: Flashmobs Against Rape help girls to link their individual struggles -as girls- with a larger platform of human rights for women globally. Flashmobs Against Rape supports girls in harnessing their power to make powerful choices for themselves and make change in their community. 
Break Isolation and Shame: Gender based discrimination and sexual violence often leaves girls feeling powerless in their own lives. Stigma is a powerful force that keeps girls quiet, living in secret that undermines them. The storytelling workshops provide girls with a safe platform to ask questions, speak up and out and break isolation and shame. I plan to help her to harness their power in the face of old past time narratives that limit her place, her power and her possibility. Flashmobs Against Rape is a way for her to write a new story: her story! 
Healing:  Many girls that I have interviewed over the years suffer from such profound loss, the pain of discrimination and rejection and the emotional toll of poverty. The arts can be a powerful tool for healing and transformation of larger social narratives that get in her way of realizing her full potential. Through expressive arts, we support girls to tap into their inner power and creativity to be change agents to end sexual violence and poverty in their lifetime. 
Public Education: The flashmobs give girls what they don't have in their communities: a public platform for her to express herself, tell the truth of their experience (and be believed) and send a message that violation of girls and women is not okay. 
Create Community: Often girls get lost in their individual story, not realizing that their stories are inter-connected with other girls as they are individually confronting a larger story that you do not count or matter. When they can come together, they find support, strength and similarity of experience through something as simple and profound as dance.  
Flip the Script: Dancing with other girls can give her the power to take a stand that she may not otherwise take on her own, while writing a new script of her value, her vision and her place on the planet. Flashmobs Against Rape helps girls make their dreams come true. 







Funky, Fresh and Fierce!


Girl Power like Never Before!!
Innovative, moving, powerful and sustainable, the tour will culminate into organizing girls into a network called Girls Idea Generation which will support poor girls translating ideas into income generation. My intention is to follow the hopes, dreams and inspirations of the girls and created what is in the highest good for the girls. This listening campaign will be the basis of creating a future network of boys called Boy Child Alliance that will focus on economic development of poor boys and developing a curriculum that can be implemented in schools to help boys to be allies to girls.

story:
Theatre Apprenticeship In Greece


Written, Produced, and Directed by: One Year Lease Theatre Company

Featuring: Myself and Thirteen Incredibly Talented Theatre-makers

Setting: Northern Greece, Summer 2014


I, Taylor Dalton, a rising senior at Vassar College

Have spent the last three years working toward

Obtaining majors in both English and Drama.

I have recently been blessed with the opportunity

To study the Art of Theatre-making in Northern Greece

With One Year Lease Theatre Company. 

This program is highly competitive, only accepting 

Fourteen students each year to participate in the program.

These fourteen students, along with the members

Of One Year Lease, come together to learn more about 

Ensemble Theatre-making while creating a production 

Over the course of the month-long program.

I hope to be one of these fortunate fourteen!

The program costs $6,000 - frankly, $6,000 I do not have.

So I'm asking for your generous support 

In order to help me pursue an amazing opportunity 

That will allow me to simultaneously hone my acting abilities

While expanding my knowledge and relationships in the Theatre.

I know this program will teach me so much about the Dramatic Arts - 

But I also know that that knowledge will transcend the theatre

And will make me a more aware and giving world citizen. 

So I humbly ask for your help to support my goal

Of studying Theatre in Greece this coming Summer!

Any support is greatly appreciated! Thank you!

story:
Our Story

Romantasy Cabaret is a naughty lil vaudeville cabaret based in Phoenix Arizona and was established in 2007. The cast and crew have been performing in the Greater Phoenix Area since June 2007's debut show and now seek the opportunity to make a professional demo video of their performances to share their talents with a broader audience base. Romantasy Cabaret wishes to gain greater exposure and hopes to begin traveling with their show in 2012.


The Impact

The core crew of Romantasy Cabaret consists of several hard working people who do everything to help put on shows from selling tickets, creating seating charts, setting up fund-raising shows, hosting raffles to raise money, greeting and seating our guests, mingling with our fans for photo opps, arriving early on show days to set up the venue as well as the stage set, staying well after the 3-hour show to tear down and pack away all of our gear, to creating their own costumes, editing their own music, attending photo shoots that they pay out of pocket for, honing their craft with endless hours choreographing and practicing their dances, routines, and crafts, attending rehearsals, making their props, and many of these invaluable people hold regular jobs and have families at home to take care of too.

Having a professional video will aid this crew of artistic people in chances to promote their show to entities looking to hire a professional cabaret. Being paid for their time and talent will keep the cabaret alive and will, after 4 years (5 full seasons), earn the performers and crew, the financial rewards they so richly deserve.

If the cast and crew do not benefit from financial assistance, they will not be able to afford funding a video, thus will likely not be seen by talent and booking agencies, and may remain a small-time, city-bound cabaret.

What We Need & What You Get

So far, the director, writer, producer and primary emcee for Romantasy Cabaret has offered $500 towards the video project. Another private donor has offered $150 and most of the cast and crew has offered to donate amounts varying from $20-$100 each.

The funds we raise will go towards rental of a professional recording space, a professional videographer and editor, a lighting tech, a sound tech, an aerial apparatus to rig up our aerial artist, performers insurance, and food and hydration beverages for the day(s) of the shoot.

$6000 will cover these costs and should any funding be left over after the video project is complete, the funds will be deposited directly into a fund for sole use of Romantasy Cabaret.

The cabaret has been self-sustaining since 2007 with time donated by all involved and often times expenses paid out of the managing partners' pockets. The cast pays for their own lessons and classes, costuming, props, supplies and we all do our own hair and makeup for the shows. We have survived on the thinnest of shoestring budgets but some of the old-timers with the cabaret since inception, could use a boost.
A professional video will aid us in getting that boost.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cant thunk down a few bones to help us out, you can at the very least help by spreading the word of our campaign. Contributors who toss in $50 will earn a pair of seats at our video shoot. Contributors who donate $100 or more will receive a pair of seats to an upcoming cabaret so you can see your money at work. Contributors of $500 will earn a pair of seats for the August 27 and October 22 shows as well as a pair of seats at the video shoot. Any amount from $10 on up is HUGELY appreciated. $10 buys a case or two of water so yeah, ever bit helps.

If you know of anyone interested in donating or becoming a sponsor for Romantasy Cabaret, please pass this along!

So far, the director, writer, producer and primary emcee for Romantasy Cabaret has offered $500 towards the video project. Another private donor has offered $150 and most of the cast and crew has offered to donate amounts varying from $20-$100 each. 
The funds we raise will go towards rental of a professional recording space, a professional videographer and editor, a lighting tech, a sound tech, an aerial apparatus to rig up our aerial artist, performers insurance, and food and hydration beverages for the day(s) of the shoot. 
$6000 will cover these costs and should any funding be left over after the video project is complete, the funds will be deposited directly into a fund for sole use of Romantasy Cabaret.The cabaret has been self-sustaining since 2007 with time donated by all involved and often times expenses paid out of the managing partners' pockets. The cast pays for their own lessons and classes, costuming, props, supplies and we all do our own hair and makeup for the shows. We have survived on the thinnest of shoestring budgets but some of the old-timers with the cabaret since inception, could use a boost. A professional video will aid us in getting that boost. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you cant thunk down a few bones to help us out, you can at the very least help by spreading the word of our campaign. Contributors who toss in $50 will earn a pair of seats at our video shoot. Contributors who donate $100 or more will receive a pair of seats to an upcoming cabaret so you can see your money at work. Contributors of $500 will earn a pair of seats for the August 27 and October 22 shows as well as a pair of seats at the video shoot. Any amount from $10 on up is HUGELY appreciated. $10 buys a case or two of water so yeah, ever bit helps. 
If you know of anyone interested in donating or becoming a sponsor for Romantasy Cabaret, please pass this along!

story:
First off, thanks for visiting. We got you this far so we'll get to the point.

The Bridge Theatre Company is the only organization in New York City that produces exclusively Canadian work. Since 2004, we've exposed New York audiences to 17 plays by 15 Canadian playwrights. 

Why?

  • Because Canada deserves cultural representatives in the cultural capital of the world.
  • Because New York audiences deserve to see the best that Canadian theatre has to offer.
  • Because Molson Canadian gives us a lot of free beer. 
This year the Bridge is proud to present Matthew MacKenzie's The Particulars at the New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC). This project represents the fruits of our labor as well as any since our founding and is the reason for this campaign.

The Production

The Particulars meditates on the biggest and smallest issues of our time. Our storytellers are Lillian, a youth minister recently returned from a journey to the central African jungle, and Gordon, a member of Lillian's congregation desperate to navigate societal norms after a tragic loss. Both long for answers amongst the daily distractions that permeate their lives. 

Since graduating from the National Theatre School in Montreal in 2010, Matthew MacKenzie has quickly established himself as one of Canada's best and brightest. His play SIA, won the 2010 Alberta Playwriting Competition and was part of our seventh season. SIA was subsequently picked up by The Actors Company Theatre (TACT) as part of their inaugural newTACTics Festival. Matthew went on to win the prestigious Urjo Kareda Residency Grant in August of 2011.
 
The Particulars will be directed by Jordana Williams, who comes to us with two FringeNYC Outstanding Production awards already in her pocket (for Viral in 2009 and Hail Satan in 2007). Ashlie Atkinson (Neil Labute’s Fat Pig, Broadway’s The Ritz) and Brian Silliman (Advance Man, Control Room) star as Lillian and Gordon.

The Campaign

While FringeNYC remains the most cost-effective way to expose Canadian playwrights to commercial and critical attention in New York City, doing it right requires considerable support. This is our third consecutive go at Fringe producing. We've seen what works and what doesn't. The $5,230 we need to raise encompasses all aspects of the production. Our artists are paid (though not nearly what they're worth). Our marketing budget allows for advertising in new and old media. Our programs, our press photos, and our show art are all done by professionals. Our budget isn't about "pulling it off", it's about putting on the show our playwright deserves.

The Perks

Supporting this campaign is about more than getting tickets to a performance, drinks at a hip bar in Greenpoint, or limited edition prints from an award-winning illustrator -- though we're thrilled to be able to provide those too. It's about investing in the journey and committing to the cause that will continue through the Fringe and well beyond The Particulars. It's about inspiring like-minded Canadians on both sides of the border to bring their work to places like New York (with or without our help - believe us, we'd love some competition). It's about continuing that 3000ish year tradition linking cultural and economic exchange. 

And, of course, it's about free beer.
 
We humbly ask that you climb aboard. Money would be great, but sharing this page and spreading the word will do just fine.
 
Seriously though, money would be really great.

story:
So who are you anyway?

We're Six Lips Theatre - that's Hannah, Anna and Roxanna. We're a York based theatre company, formed in 2010,

We aim to produce theatre that is engaging and magical, while celebrating the real. We love storytelling, and like to create shows that are not just textually rich but also a visual treat.

We open up our projects for collaborations with other emerging and established artists, hoping to provide a platform for everyone's fledgling ideas.


What are you fundraising for?

We've been working away on many shows around Yorkshire, but now we're ready to go futher and do more. Our goal for the year is to take Six Lips to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. To be blunt, this costs money - a lot of money. Venue hire, transport, accommodation, print and marketing, and all the boring additional things that you don't think of but are totally necessary. We need your help - we can't do this without you!

What's the show?

Faustus. Now wait, you might think you know this show, but hang on a minute and think again.

In the bowels of the industrial revolution, change is brewing. A particular kind of hunger is bubbling inside one of the world’s most powerful minds, and when an offer is made that promises to satisfy that hunger, he makes a choice. A bargain. With the devil. You see, even the best and wisest amongst us do things we later regret…

Under the bleak skyline, a company assembles to pass judgement on the greatest of a generation.

Actor musicians, live music. Heartfelt and gritty. It's everything you know turned on its head and pushed to the extreme in this new, modern language, version of a timeless story.

OK, so what's in it for me?

Apart from the knowledge that you're obviously an all-round good sort of person? Well, we have all sorts of fabulous exciting perks. If you're here on Indiegogo, you're probably just like us, in the fact you're probably a struggling/starving arts-sort. So we've kept all the wonderful perks at an accessible rate. Remember that if you donate at one level of support, you still get all the perks from the levels beforehand! How awesome is that?

Is there anything else I can do?

 

Absolutely! If you're able to give us some pennies, then thank you so much! If you can't, then hey, we understand that too. But there's plenty that you can do, and some of it won't cost you a single penny

  • Follow us on Facebook - http://www.facebook.com/sixlipstheatre
  • Follow us on Twitter - http://www.twitter.com/sixlipstheatre
  • Subscribe to our blog - http://sixlipstheatre.wordpress.com
  • Come see one of our shows! You can always find out what we're doing and when by checking out any one of the sites we've just mentioned
  • Tell your friends - even if you can't help, it's possible that they can!
  • Donate something to one of our silent auctions that we're doing to do yet more fundraising. If you've got something you don't want that someone else might, or have a skill we can use, drop us a line at info@sixlips.co.uk
  • Or if there's anything else you think you can do to help that we might not have thought of, just get in touch!

story:
Our Festival:

PLANS is a contemporary play festival produced by Dave Fertik and Stage Left Theatre Company, in association with producer Steve Wei. Our company got started in East Brunswick, New Jersey, as an entirely student-run theatre company, under the firm belief that studying our craft wasn't enough: to really learn anything, we had to put up shows. We had to own our work. When our studies took us to Philadelphia, we brought the work with us. These shows are going up one way or another, but as dirt-poor students, it's a strain to do it without help. Your greatest donation would be coming to see our shows (http://plansfestival.brownpapertickets.com/), but if you can't come see us, or want to give more, your contributions here will mean we can get a decent lunch on our breaks--or better yet, we can put up more down the line.

The Deal:

A show costs thousands of dollars to do right. Hundreds go to performance insurance, renting our space, creating and buying costumes, sets, and props, and overall making the world of the play. We don't just have one play, we have three. The sum of $2000 will only cover half of our budget for all of those things, but ticket sales will cover the rest. As we said, the biggest contribution would be for you to show up. If we sold every seat,  we'd still break even. But your contributions here will give us an extra element of security, and let us get some cooler props, give our set that extra finish, or get really magical with our costumes and makeup.

We want to show our community that student work is not just viable as art, but is financially maintainable. Your assistance will help us prove both at once! Our continued work aims to give the rising generation of theatrical artists a voice, and every single dollar helps!

Don't even have a single dollar right now?

Believe us when we say we understand.
 
But you can still contribute in other ways!
 
- Word of mouth is one of our strongest advertisement! Tell a friend! Bring them to the show!
- Put an ad in our program! E-mail Steve Wei at steve@temple.edu if you'd like to advertise your small business to hundreds of students and members of a robust community!
- Share this page! Or share our facebook page at http://on.fb.me/102lwlg!
- Come see our show! Tix are $5 at the door, but you can also reserve them online (see link above)!
 
Thank you so much for your contributions! Hope to see you at the show!

story:
The Active Theater's 2012/2013 Development Series

FINAL WORKSHOP PRESENTATIONS!

We are thrilled to finally present the culmination of a year-long development series! In line with our commitment to emerging artists, The Active Theater is dedicated to teaming with "up and coming" playwrights to help lead new plays through a development process. This year, we will be presenting 5 fully-staged workshop performances of both IN THE MIDDLE by Megan Sass,  and TIMEPIECE by Ben Bartolone.

 

What We Need & What You Get

$2000 will put a big dent in the costs of renting both rehearsal and performance space, as well as providing lighting, set pieces, sound equipment, and transportation costs. Not to mention, of course, printing scripts and re-writes along the way. We want to present our writers' works to the absolute best of our ability, in hopes that they get the attention they deserve. And we can't do it withtout your help!

PLEASE NOTE: With your credit card, donations are 100% tax-deductible. If you'd like to use PayPal, they are unfortunately not tax-deductible. We like whatever's best for you, so please keep this in mind!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute monetarily??? Not a problem! Do you have an old kindle or other electronic reading device you aren't using anymore? Help Active GO GREEN by making a tax-deductible donation of your e-reader, so that we can load script changes and updates onto the readers for actors to use during rehearsals. You're saving us money and you're saving the planet's trees at the same time! What could be better than being a super-green superhero and supporting the arts as well??? Email us at info@theactivetheater.com for more information!

story:
After much soul-searching and deliberation, I have decided to have a wee go at crowdfunding. As many of you will know, I'm often found banging a drum for someone or other, but this time it's all about me. For a wee lassie fae the West of Scotland, this bit is excruciating so please bear with me. Here goes...

In early 2013, I attended a two-week cabaret course. The process was extremely intense and I was reduced to tears on more than one occasion. Still, I emerged unscathed, enlightened and proud. I took the plunge and gave up my job in the voluntary sector and went on to gain experience hosting, as well as singing, and even dipped my toe into the murky waters of stand-up comedy. I was offered a two-night residency, every week, plus a regular gig with a popular tribute act. My YouTube video has had over a thousand hits. Oh, but that I had charged a pound a peep! As fate would have it, just as I was offered a prime weekend gig in a Glasgow venue, I experienced a period of ill health and had to take some time off, on doctor's orders. I have been diagnosed with fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue, anxiety and depression. I will never be 100% well but that doesn't mean I can't be a first rate performer. And that's where you come in...

I have the opportunity to attend a level 2 cabaret course where I will participate in master classes run by world-class performers, and (most importantly) I will learn how to brand and promote my act and all the boring (but essential!) business stuff. If you have a look at http://singerscabaretworkshop.co.uk/course.htm you will see a quote at the bottom right-hand side of the page. That quote is from me. 

Unfortunately, this time around, I don't have the cash to fund my place. The course will run over 4 days so I need to cover the fees and also travel to and around London, accomodation and subsistence. I've set a highly optimistic monetary goal which would ensure I could get the most out of my experience, e.g. I might also be able to attend shows by other performers as valuable research. I will also need appropriate clothing, stationery, sheet music etc. This money would allow me to achieve my dream of running my own business as a performer. No donation is too small and shares on Facebook etc. would be greatly appreciated. If you can't give, maybe someone else on your friend list can. Every pound takes me one step closer and I'll be thankful from the bottom of my heart. 

(This mob will take 9% of what I achieve, so let's push for the target :-)

Watch me in action at http://youtu.be/ZNsMYrL2G3U

story:
The Story of American Latinos Heroes

Veteranos: A Legacy of Valor is a theatrical tribute written & directed by actor/writer Enrique Castillo (Weeds, Blood In Blood Out, Mi Familia), and dedicated to the countless Latinos who have fought and died in America’s Defense. The play is a bilingual, multi-visual production telling the story of American heroes through live music, audio-visuals and a dramatization of each of the heroes' life.
 Veteranos: A Legacy of Valor tells the story of Eugene Arnold Obregon's heroic action when he was killed while saving the life of Burt Johnson, a fellow soldier, at the age of 19.  For his bravery he received the highest honor a U.S. soldier can receive, the Medal of Honor.  

The performance will be co-presented by LatinHeat Media Institute and the L.A. Mayor's Obregon Veterans Network at Patriotic Hall, 1816 S Figueroa St, Los Angeles, CA 90015.

Help us honor our Veterans and see an award-winning play about Latino heroes who have fought in America's defense since the American Revolution.

Net profits will benefit the Eugene Obregon Memorial Foundation (see below)

Donate below:

If you are a Veteran you can attend for free!  Send us an e-mail to: lhmediainstitute@latinheat.com.   

So buy a ticket, buy a veteran a ticket, sponsor this show and come see a great performance and in show your appreciation of the brave men and women who fought for our freedom.

We are looking to raise $5,000  

Your contribution will be used...

  • To allow Military veterans to attend the performance for free
  • For venue and equipment rental
  • To pay a stipend to 9 actors, director, musical director, stage manager & producer
  • For printing of posters and program

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute monetarily,  you can still help in the following manner:

  • In-kind donations of lighting package, printing, signage 
  • E-blast about the performance to your mailing list
  •  Share on social media 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the news about our campaign 

Award-Winning Production 

  • This production has already had 2 successful national tours.
  • Veteranos: A Legacy of Valor received an Imagen Award for Best Live Performance
  • The full production which tells the story of 4 Medal of honor recipients.

NET PROFITS WILL BENEFIT 

Eugene Obregon Medal of Honor Foundation (Website here) This organization has already built a wall dedicated to all Medal of Honor receipient at Sierra Park near Olvera Street and is raising funds to complete the monument dedicated to Latino Medal of Honor recipients.
