Eugene Obregon Medal of Honor Foundation (Website here) This organization has already built a wall dedicated to all Medal of Honor receipient at Sierra Park near Olvera Street and is raising funds to complete the monument dedicated to Latino Medal of Honor recipients.

story:
WHO ARE WE? 

We are The Crude Mechanicals, a group of actors based in Fayetteville, Arkansas. Our members are current students or recent theatre graduates from the University of Arkansas and Pace University in New York City. We have come together with a shared passion for theatre, and a love of Shakespeare. We collectively believe anyone should have the opportunity to experience the magic of Shakespeare without ticket cost being a barrier to access. Our plan is to make all of our productions free of charge and open to the public.

The goal of The Crude Mechanicals is to create accessible and enjoyable theatre—while embracing the original sense of community and storytelling that drew us into theatre in the first place. Our motto is “Tragedy. Simplicity. Love.” with an emphasis on simplicity. This idea evolved after discussing productions of “Romeo and Juliet” our cast members have experienced, and how the best examples of this classic seem to emphasize comedy, rather than allowing the performances to be overburdened by tragedy. We seek to create a simple, fun, and evocative production of the classic tale of star-crossed lovers, bringing new light to a story familiar to everyone.

Fayetteville is a fortunate community brimming with quality theatre, but we have observed a lack of content originating from our young adult age group that is independent of educational institutions. We hope to apply the skills we are learning from our universities to establish new and evocative productions. Our mentors have emphasized that one of the best ways to do theatre is simply to go out and make it happen. We are individually committed to creating our own art, and believe establishing The Crude Mechanicals will help us to do just that.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

We are seeking nominal financial assistance for our staging of “Romeo and Juliet”. To fully realize our production we will need a little help (we are broke college students, after all). We are respectfully asking for modest donations. We have all worked to financially support ourselves as we pursue our educations, and we recognize that small sums add up to accomplish significant things. Donations will help us develop and implement a marketing plan to build a wider audience base. Your support will help us purchase modest costume and set pieces (our keyword is still “simplicity”), as well as pay for performance venues. This money will be stretched to ensure every cent is invested in the show. All of our generous supporters will receive special printed recognition in our program, as well as periodic acknowledgement through social media.

QUESTIONS?

For more information email  zstolz@uark.edu, or visit The Crude Mechanicals Facebook page. Events will be posted and updated through social media, and as we secure support, we will promote our shows more broadly.

story:
“When I’m taking dance class, I just feel so able. I feel like my body can do anything; like I’m Wonder Woman or something.”                                             Louisa Mascuch, Studio Lab alumnae

Campaign Goals

$10,000 and 314 donors

(Our goal is 500 donors for the academic year, we currently have 186.)

Who benefits from my donation?

“Dancing meant so much to me and helped my self-confidence. It is a place where I can express myself and be free…”  Lucy, Teen Summer Camp dancer

Thousands of children like Lucy benefit from Luna dance classes. During our Teen Summer Program Lucy explored elements of dance in relation to African dance aesthetics and created original choreography. She deepened her own sense of artistic expression. Our classes are offered in schools and community programs year-round.

Why Dance?

“Dance is expressing your feelings when you don’t talk.”                                    New Highland Academy student, East Oakland

Dance gives life and brings us joy and hope. All humans need hope to persevere, be inspired, to care about our fellow human beings. As humans we are compelled to create, to play, to love and to communicate through movement – gesture is our first language. Current research provides evidence that dance supports empathy, problem-solving, curiosity and physical development. Dance cultivates the BODY, MIND and SOUL.

Where does my donation go?

“Remarkable things happen when you allow a child a safe space to be creative.  Underserved children need a voice; they need to be seen. Luna allows me to bring my best self as an educator forward and teach dance classes that foster the gifts each child contains in their embodied selves."          Katherine McGinity, Luna Teaching Artist

Each donation goes directly toward providing a dance teacher for a classroom full of children. Luna’s teaching artists are a remarkable group of choreographers and educators who teach children and families in low-income Oakland schools, public libraries, residential treatment centers and our Berkeley Studio Lab. Dance classes in community and educational settings are free. Through our studio Luna provides tuition assistance for families in need. All of our classes are inclusive of diverse learning styles, body types and abilities.

When do dance classes take place?

“When I see young children dancing . . . they are also laughing. They are expanding their sense of self and each other. Maybe that’s the beginning of school and social transformation.”  Oakland School District 1st grade teacher

During the school day, after-school, early evenings, and on Saturdays. Luna is committed to dance access for ALL children—besides providing dance programs in schools, we offer programs at times that working parents and caregivers can access.

What is Luna?

20,000 children each year experience holistic dance classes through Luna Dance Institute’s programs – MPACT (Moving Parents and Children Together), School & Community Alliances, Studio Lab, and Professional Learning. Visit www.lunadanceinsitute.org to find out more.

Our mission is to broaden dance ACCESS to all children. We focus on community service with integrity and creativity as the foundation for dance in education. Our nationally acclaimed programs have been featured in Dance Studio Life and Dance Teacher magazine.

Why should I donate to this campaign?

“Dance has made me change my life and experience what life is about through dancing.”  School and Community Alliances student, Oakland, CA

Only .2 % of children in Alameda County where Luna is based have an opportunity to dance at their school.* Yes, you read that correctly, 99.8% of children are not reaping the benefits dance can bring. A $10 donation gives a child in a low-income school a dance class with a caring and creative Luna teaching artist. The entirety of your donation provides equitable dance education to children in Alameda County.

If you are already one of our generous contributors and wish to give again - the children welcome your donation!

If you wish to take a tax deduction for your contribution, please donate through the Luna website - http://lunadanceinstitute.org/donate/

* California Department of Education Educational Demographics Office.  Statewide Course Enrollments 2012-13.  http://www.cde.ca.gov/ds/.  11 March 2014.

story:
Help Dry Cold add another branch to the Addams Family Tree - Money raised by this campaign will allow Dry Cold Productions to showcase two more professional and emerging Manitoba actors as the delightfully dead Addams Family ancestors.

We're truly blessed with having so many talented performers in our city, and we really want to bring more of them into what is sure to be another amazing show. All we need is some additional funding, so pledge, and maybe you can come join us on stage!  Be an honorary Addams Family member by lending your name to a character, carving it on a tombstone or becoming a cast member yourself!

If you are too shy to join the undead or name a tombstone, please feel free to donate an amount of your choice!!  

Tickets available at www.royalmtc.ca/addamsfamily

story:
Short Summary

Hi friends,
 
I've been self producing theater for over ten years. 
 
This year I'm collaborating as an actor, writer, and co-director with Nicole Philippidis of 277 Dance Project (www.277danceproject.com)
 
We have a preview of our new work at Dixon Place May 31st at 7:30.
 
We've invited several producers to see the work in the hopes that they'll produce the show next year.
 
In the mean time, we've been paying for the rehearsal space, insurance, costumes etc...
 
I'm raising money to help pay myself back.
 
We were given the opportunity to perform on the 31st before we had the chance to do a proper fundraiser.
 
Here's the breakdown:
$175 for insurance (required by Actor's Equity)
$250 to pay my share of the stipend to 5 of the 10 actors
$340 for costumes.
 
We finally found someone who is going to organize a big fundraiser for a full production of the show.
 
This will happen during the summer.
 
Feel free to contribute even just the cost of a ticket ($15) if you can't make the show.
 

xxoo Stacey

story:
Short Summary

In four years of performing, Sex T-Rex has become a pillar of the Toronto comedy scene. Winners of the $1000 Grand Prize at ITC's Cage Match, we’re a team of former George Brown Theatre School students with a passion for creating high-energy, unpretentious and above-all fun theatre. We’ve toured extensively as an improv troupe across the U.S. and Canada, delighting uninitiated audiences from New York City to London Ontario. Last summer we made our maiden departure from improv and our first scripted play, Callaghan, played to sold-out houses, rave reviews and award nominations in Montreal!  Now we’re finally ready to bring it home.  

Callaghan is the perfect gateway drug for theatre- imaginative, fast-paced and hilarious, it’s a whirlwind show packed with action and heart.  It’s also a show that we love and we're ready to bring our performance of it to the professional level so often missing from live comedy.  We want to present an experience on par with the major theatres in the city but with the verve and energy of a young and eager team and the creativity Toronto has come to expect from Sex T-Rex.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $6000 to properly stage Callaghan in its ideal form. We have already secured a space and our cast is set- we require funds to rent rehearsal space; to purchase props, costume pieces and materials for puppet making; and since Callaghan features an elaborate dance sequence and several fight scenes, we require funds to pay experts in these fields to run workshops and rehearsals to bring these elements up to a professional level. Finally, this project will require taking time off from our day jobs and we'd use some of our funding to pay ourselves for that time.

In return, most donors will receive a ticket to an evening performance of their choice. Larger donations will also earn exclusive, homemade Callaghan merchandise (generally distributed on attendance of the show, but postal arrangements can be made), and even tickets to our exclusive opening night party! The highest donors will receive unique perks such as having a character in Callaghan named for them, a private improv performance from Sex T-Rex at a time of their choosing, or even free admission to all Sex T-Rex shows for life!

Any extra funds we receive will go towards our operating budget for 2013- to ensure that we can continue to bring Toronto, and other cities, the kind of high-quality content our audiences have come to expect, and continue to raise the bar on the professional standards of our shows.


The Impact

Sex T-Rex has travelled to many cities & festivals, always expanding the scope of our shows. This is our best opportunity to create the show we've always wanted and to show it to the people we care about.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see our shows! Like us on Facebook and check out our website! Follow us on Twitter! We have at least a show a week at Comedy Bar, Free Times Cafe, Unit 102, or any of the many amazing comedy venues in the city.  Come see us, say hi, and tell us what you thought!

story:
Hatmaker's Attic Productions is a new community theatre company based in New York's Hudson Valley. We're currently raising money to get our debut season off the ground, starting with our first production -- Jason Robert Brown's beautiful 'SONGS FOR A NEW WORLD'. 

This universal show explores themes that touch all of our lives -- our own personal "new world", the risks we take on our journey there, and what we find when that journey is complete. 

We're very excited to get to work on creating a powerful and heartfelt production, but first we need to raise a little money. Our starting budget is $5,000, which will cover the cost of renting the theatre space for two weekends and purchasing the rights to produce the show. 

As this is only our starting budget, we will likely end up needing more -- so if our project Fuels over 100%, any additional funds will go to props, costumes, tech, musicians and promotion. 

 

Founded by William and Ed Gibbons-Brown, HATMAKER'S ATTIC PRODUCTIONS is working from the ground up towards 501(c)(3) nonprofit status.
Based in New York's beautiful Hudson Valley, we're a brand-new community theatre company working from the ground up towards 501(c)3 status.
We’re enthusiastic and ready to build this emerging company from the ground up, rehearsing and performing in any space available and pushing the envelope on a shoestring budget. As our company gains momentum and resources, we plan to expand beyond simply mounting quality productions to offer a range of educational programs and opportunities which will have a positive impact on our community. We’ll offer classes and workshops in acting, singing, dance, stage combat, playwriting, technical theatre, and music. We’ll reach out to local businesses, other theatre companies and community organizations to create a rich environment for creative growth.
Our mission: To build an exciting grassroots theatre company and creative community offering quality productions and a range of programs, classes and workshops.

Our philosophy: We'll rehearse in an attic, we'll perform anywhere we can. The world is our stage and the sky is the limit. 

Our Commitment: To tell you a story you've never heard before.

story:
Short Summary

Greetings! I’m Deanna Downes, a director of theater committed to telling the stories of people of color on stage. I am a doctoral candidate at the University of Colorado Boulder with an amazing opportunity to study the performing arts of Cuba for 5 weeks, basically the month of June, in Cuba!

Which brings me to the need for this campaign. The program is a fixed rate of $5,398.00 not including the airfare from Colorado to Miami, our departure city. I have secured a $550 scholarship through the Study Abroad program at CU Boulder but there is still a gap in my funding. Hence, this campaign is solely to help me raise the remaining funds for my journey.

As an artist scholar of African American theater I am excited to learn and compare the content of theater in Post Soviet Cuba, which is still under a U.S. trade embargo. What comparisons can be made between African American contemporary theater and Cuba’s theater? Are there folk plays, are there propaganda plays, and who are the playwrights? These are all questions I hope to find answers to in my studies.

Funding Breakdown

The program costs $5,398.00

Instructional Costs  -- $3,336.00 -- We have class from 9:30 am to Noon every day taught by the Cuban leaders in the fields of history, performance arts and politics. We also have a mandatory Spanish language course each day.

Health Insurance –$70.00 -- required part of the program

Housing and Meals – $ 1,992.00 -- We will be housed in dormitory style housing with two meals provided each day. The campus is one mile from our dormitory and I will be walking to and from classes each day – Woohoo! I’m really excited about this opportunity to experience the culture and people of Cuba each day to and from class.

ANY and ALL funds will be put towards my participation in this program. If you are unable to help me please forward this email to a friend. Getting the word out is just as important!

The Impact

Those of you who know me know that I am the daughter and granddaughter of children’s librarians. I spent my youth tucked in library corners sitting on small chairs, reading children’s books. Children’s books hold the best life lessons that example how to be an awesome human. It’s those stories mixed with the highs and lows of living life that evolve and become plays that I long to direct. In my life there is power in hearing a story that I identify with and seeing a reflection of myself onstage to learn from or to challenge. This is the intention I bring to this trip and my studies in Cuba and the US and to the theatrical work I direct and produce. What are the stories that elders tell their children in Cuba? Can I see a reflection of my life in theirs? How are our lives different? How are they similar? This curiosity in the stories different cultures tell is leading my desire to study Cuban theater.

On a practical note, the experience of this trip will inform the layers of my dissertation writing about women playwrights of color. While I am on the island I have made plans to engage Cuban theater-makers in a joint exploration of a play that has touched my life, Ntozake Shange’s For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow is Enuf. This joint exploration will culminate in a small tour of the production in Cuba and a later production in New York City at La Mama, ETC. Plans and another campaign for the NYC production will be forthcoming!

The Impact
Those of you who know me know that I am the daughter and granddaughter of children’s librarians. I spent my youth tucked in library corners sitting on small chairs, reading children’s books. Children’s books hold the best life lessons that example how to be an awesome human. It’s those stories mixed with the highs and lows of living life that evolve and become plays that I long to direct. In my life there is power in hearing a story that I identify with and seeing a reflection of myself onstage to learn from or to challenge. This is the intention I bring to this trip and my studies in Cuba and the US and to the theatrical work I direct and produce. What are the stories that elders tell their children in Cuba? Can I see a reflection of my life in theirs? How are our lives different? How are they similar? This curiosity in the stories different cultures tell is leading my desire to study Cuban theater.
On a practical note, the experience of this trip will inform the layers of my dissertation writing about women playwrights of color. While I am on the island I have made plans to engage Cuban theater-makers in a joint exploration of a play that has touched my life, Ntozake Shange’s For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow is Enuf. This joint exploration will culminate in a small tour of the production in Cuba and a later production in New York City at La Mama, ETC. Plans and another campaign for the NYC production will be forthcoming!

story:
WHAT IS 4.48 PSYCHOSIS? 

For one year we have worked tirelessly to devise, choreograph, and design this production of Sarah Kane’s infamous play, 4.48 Psychosis. During this compelling process we engaged in a deep theatrical investigation of fantasy, violence, abandonment, the thin line between life and death, and the delicate balance between the carnal and the civilized.  Now re-envisioned, this story stands as a testament to one woman’s turbulent journey through her distorted memory as she searches for relief from her inner turmoil. Fifteen audience members per performance will move through this immersive and nightmarish landscape that attempts to blur the boundaries between theatre/performance- spectator/participant.

WHO ARE WE? 

Over a year ago, eighteen women were drawn together by the mysterious laws of attraction to a small classroom on a well-known arts school campus to work on The Skriker by Caryl Churchill. Little did we all know this project would be the string that sutured us into one ambitious monster. Today, Wirehead Collective is a collaborative-coalition made up of eleven women (and a few choice men!) dedicated to discovering the pulse of an emerging generation through theatre and performance art that is blatantly aggressive, provocative and impossible to ignore or avoid. 4.48 Psychosis declares our first official company production!

 

OUR ASK:

With your help we will be able to afford to create this viscerally exquisite, In-Yer- Face experience for our audience to move through. Our goal is to raise $1,000. This will cover the production costs for: lumber, fabric, Mylar, tarps, light fixtures, sound, prop and video rentals, (did I say set materials?), costumes for our cast of 7, and much much much more!

WHO IS INVOLVED


Directed by Genee A. Coreno

Assistant Director: Kelsey Rai Lurie

Stage Manager: Dani Ortiz

Cast: Arden Winant, Nayelin Monegro, Dena Kopolovich, Brian Jones, Chris Smith, James McDermott, and Brett Solomon.

Set Design: Jeanette Mieses

Technical Director: Ori Bensihmon 

Costume Designer: Marissa Martin

SPECIAL THANKS TO Greg Rutkin and his awesome crew of STOOD Coordinators!

story:
We are Hot Patooties! South Bend's Rocky Horror Picture Show Shadow Cast

We are preparing for our first show on November 8 at the State Theater in beautiful Downtown South Bend, Indiana.

What began as a call-out for interest in late July has become a full cast and crew of students, wallflowers, performers, and (all) Rocky fans with mind-blowing talent. We Love Rocky!

In preparation of our first performance, and every one that follows, our creative crew is building sets and key props, but we are faced with costs and expenses. We need your help! Partner with us. We'll make it worth your bucks!

Your dollars will help our crew build a set that brings the movie to life! Even more, Hot Patooties is contributing to the renaissance of South Bend. By contributing, you are investing in the talent and creativity of artists who are passionate about our city! Be a part of something special!

Please help us meet our goal of $750

Let's break it down...

  • Your support will help build the creation tank, weight set, criminologists' office, and will provide essential costumes and props to the actors. These pieces are solidly built and will support the cast in numerous productions.
  • The best part is what YOU get. Incentives include signed posters by cast and crew, a cool handmade lightning pin, tickets for future shows, a premium seat in the house for you and two friends, fishnet stockings! and a chance to do the Time Warp during a show! (we know you're jumping all over that)
  • For the sake of clarity, we want to let you know that all monies will be provided to Hot Patooties even if we don't meet our goal.

You will have an impact on this immensely talented shadow cast, which will have an impact on the city, which will have an impact on the good citizens of this city, including your children and your children's children, and children of your children's children, and chil....for generations to come. They will be talking about this shadow cast for decades and you will be famous (or infamous) because you supported Hot Patooties!! (if we had confetti to throw and horns to sound, we totally would right now)


if you are unable to support us financially, send us your toilet paper for survival kits...we would love that!

story:
What it be:


My name is Chuck Clay, I am an actor, director, and writer as well as a theater professional and a full-time stage enthusiast.  Not long ago I moved to Southern California from the East Coast.  I found myself with a long commute to work and I fell in love with podcasts:  The simplicity of a guest, a microphone, and a story to tell.

The problem:  

Out of thousands of podcasts that are created daily, there are very few that focus on the life and work of theater professionals.  There are some great podcasts out there, don't get me wrong, but since the American Theatre Wing stopped producing the now defunct "Downstage Center" podcasts (which were excellent), there are fewer and fewer places to hear working theater professionals tell their stories. 

My solution:

Curtain Call with Chuck Clay.

Here's my pitch, in a nutshell:  

Each episode, go behind the scenes with the leading artists, technicians, and craftspeople on stage and behind the scenes of today’s top theaters with Curtain Call, a monthly theatrical interview program that spotlights the creative talents working in the theatrical industry across the country and around the world.  Putting the spotlight on folks who don't normally get a chance to shine—house managers, stagehands, dressers, casting directors, agents, producers, writers, actors, electricians, accountants, and more--guests get the chance tell stories about what brought them to the stage and what makes them stay, or keeps them coming back time after time. They all love what they do, and you will end up loving them and the work the they do on and off the stage, with these in-depth creative conversations that can't be found anywhere else. 

Think Charlie Rose-style in-depth conversations, but in a much artsier- alternate universe where all conversations are about our shared passion for the stage!  Or think Nerdist for the theatre geek in all of us.

I am not into a hard sell here.

If this sounds like an interview series that you would listen to, or if you know people who would enjoy this podcast, please give to my campaign, or help spread the word!


The straight dope:

By giving to this campaign you are providing:

  • Podcasting equipment, hardware, software, website licensing and fees, etc.  I want to produce a professional and sonically pleasant podcast listening experience.  Most of this falls into the realm of start-up capital.  Podcasting is fairly inexpensive and therefore fairly democratic, but to do it right is to do it well.
  • 100% of funds earned will go towards building a better podcast.  Any funds earned up to but shy of the campaign goals, will still go directly to podcasting equipment and licensing.  Any funds raised above the stated campaign goal will go toward funding future initiatives, i.e. a travel fund, so that vibrant theatre scenes from across the country (and the world) can be included in our conversations.


Why it matters:

Curtain Call with Chuck Clay is designed to fill a noticeable gap in  podcast programming.  If you are a theatrical professional, amateur, hobbiest, or a full-time stage enthusiast like myself, this is a podcast for you!

Right now we live in a world without Curtain Call.  How does that feel?  Now close your eyes and imagine a world WITH Curtain Call streaming through your earholes.  Ahhhhhh!  Now, isn't that better?

story:
bound (v. restrict; n. a territory limit or boundary; n. a leap onward or upward; ; adj. destined, sure, certain)

bound is an evening length multimedia performance created by Yaa Samar! Dance Theatre Artistic Director Samar Haddad King, that tells the universal story of people who are restricted by society, politics, geography or gender. 

This Fall, bound will tour in the Arab World and Asia, with performances and workshops spanning from Palestine to Japan. Tour engagements extend from October 9 - 25 and include:

        •  Two performances of bound in Palestine on October 9 and 10.
        •  Workshops for non-dancers presented by the Seoul International Dance                       Festival in Seoul, South Korea on October 16.
        •   A closing-night performance of bound at the world-renowned Seoul
            International Dance Festival in Seoul, South Korea on October 18. 
        •  Workshops at Chonbuk National University in Jeonju, South Korea, October
            20-21.
        •  Workshops at the Kobe Art Village Center in Kobe, Japan, October 23-25.

Situated between mobile planes that act as buildings, borders, and projection surfaces, the seven performers of bound are continuously confronted by an evolving landscape of boundaries that tests their physical and emotional limits. Layered over and between the live action, the story of two lovers separated by circumstance unfolds via Skype. Set to an original score by boikutt, this production examines what it means to be bound: to a place, to a person, to an ideology, to noise, to silence.


why now

        •  This season represents the culmination of ten years of Yaa Samar! 
            Dance Theatre's dedication to transcending boundaries through international
            communication and cross-cultural collaboration.       
        •  This tour of bound was created across continents, and features an
            international cast of American, Japanese, and Palestinian performers,
            representing the best in live performance from around the world.
        •  Our workshops will reach broad populations including non-dancers and
            aspiring artists, sharing YSDT's unique approach to movement.
        •  This is the company's fourth and largest international tour.
        •  After teaching and performing throughout the Arab World, Europe and the
            U.S for the past ten years, this is the company's first trip to Asia! 

why us
        •  Yaa Samar! Dance Theatre (YSDT) is 501(c)3 non-profit organization
            and multimedia performance company based between New York
            City and Palestine, using art and technology to create performance
            across disciplines, cultural geographies, and physical borders.
        •  YSDT was founded in 2005 by Artistic Director Samar Haddad King, and 
            has a proven track record of ten years of successful performances,
            workshops, and residencies around the world.
        •  We have already raised half the cost of this large-scale international tour
            through government grants, individual donations and a generous space grant 
            from Sareyyet Ramallah Group.
        •  We can already cover the cost of transportation for our team of nine
           artists across continents, and the construction of sets that are integral
            to the work.
        •  It is our mission to bring dance to new audiences, and illuminate the
            untold stories of people and communities around the world. Inspired by world
            events and personal histories, our narratives are accessible to experienced
           dance viewers and novice audiences alike. 


why you

        •  We still need to raise $17,000 to cover the cost of this tour, including:
            payment of international visa fees, rehearsal space rental in New York City,
            and most importantly, to pay our artists!
        • You believe in art that addresses and transcends geo-political divisions
            and as a contributor you know you will join a strong international network of
            like-minded individuals.
        •  You know one or more of our artists and want to make a difference in their
            lives, and in the lives of the audiences they touch through performance.
        •  Even you can't make a donation at this time you, know that you can help by
          sharing this campaign on Facebook, and sending directly to your
           communities via email, to help us spread the word about the work that we do!


WE CAN'T DO THIS WITHOUT YOU. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

SHUKRAN!

why you
        •  We still need to raise $17,000 to cover the cost of this tour, including:            payment of international visa fees, rehearsal space rental in New York City,             and most importantly, to pay our artists!        • You believe in art that addresses and transcends geo-political divisions             and as a contributor you know you will join a strong international network of             like-minded individuals.        •  You know one or more of our artists and want to make a difference in their             lives, and in the lives of the audiences they touch through performance.        •  Even you can't make a donation at this time you, know that you can help by           sharing this campaign on Facebook, and sending directly to your            communities via email, to help us spread the word about the work that we do!
 
WE CAN'T DO THIS WITHOUT YOU. 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!


SHUKRAN!

story:
Crabtree Carabetta Collective
Teaming up officially for the first time, long term collaborators Brian Crabtree and Audra Carabetta will be presenting a concert of largely new work under the banner of The Crabtree Carabetta Collective. Combining a rich history of dancing together in duets and ensemble work, both choreographers are excited to present dances that have been in process over the past year. As dance makers, they have a shared interest in careful and thoughtful composition, fluid musicality, and context. Both have distinctive movement sensibilities, and apply their wealth of experience in the studio with a mature and dedicated group of dancers. With musical scores that run the gamut from Chopin to Zoe Keating, the focus for both is the illumination of music with carefully made dance phrases that are sometimes chopped, turned, minimalized, sent in several new directions, and changed during rehearsal through dancer ingenuity. A process that yields dances worthy of a second look. The concert will run about one hour and a half with a short intermission. Tickets will be 25.00. 
Audra and I are sharing a show as part of the Dance Complex series this fall. November 21st and 22nd at 8 p.pm.  


Specific to this project, we need funding to pay for Jayne Murphy, our wonderful lighting designer, to offset the price of the space and to help pay for a stage manager. We both have worked with Jayne before and she is sensitive and responsive to both of us as dance artists. We are setting a goal of $2000 to make a beautiful project run smoothly and be well lit. 

This is the first project we have formally shared after years of dancing together. Our work has been well received and we both have an established reputation for thoughtfully crafted work. 

New Works:

Brian Crabtree

ROUTINE SPLENDOR/ a suite of three dances set to the beautiful nocturnes of Chopin, played by Arthur Rubinstein. Directly inspired by the interpretations of these pieces by Rubinstein, I wanted to make a series of dances that build not only in personnel, ( from duet to trio to quartet) but also in dramatic urgency and the complexity of their composition. The first is very pastoral, the second overcast by the addition of a third who keeps a steady flow in and out of the action, and the third a dark and stormy quartet, with one couple being surrounded and eventually enclosed by another. 

Audra Carabetta

TAKE MY HAND/ a trio set to the beautiful music of Zoe Keating, explores the passing of time and it's effect on human relationships.  Energetically, the piece works with quick bursts of movement that soften at the end of asequence, and it plays with a balance between grounded, bound movement, release and flow. Dancers work together creating various repetitive, patterns that weave through space with strength and precision. 

   -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"Alone among the Boston Moves competition winners, Crabtree understands that dancing inhabits and sculpts the space within it exists: the other choreographers could learn a lot by studying him."

“Audra Carabetta moved with a lush, full-bodied sweep punctuated by gestures of crystalline articulation in the hands and feet. “

- The Boston Globe

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kelli  and I am heading in to my final year at Biola University as a Theatre Major.  I have been working towards my Bachelors off and on for the last 14 years.  During some of those off times, I taught theater to elementary, junior high and high school students and found I have a passion for directing.  The theater department at Biola is small and it just officially became it's own major about 3 years ago.  Because of this there is not a lot of performance opportunities.  Several of my classmates had approached me saying that they would love to work with me as a director.  Knowing that I still needed some upper division elective units, I approached the head of the department about being able to direct a full production during my final semester...giving me the ability to finish my degree requirements and giving all of us in the department the chance to work on a show together before we graduate.  The downfall though, is that there is no money for the show.  That's where this campaign comes in.  

What We Need & What You Get

This fundraising goal will cover all of the production costs associated with this show including scripts, performance royalties, sets, costumes, lighting and sound design, advertising and the sponsor perks.  Because we value all of our contributors so much, there will be some fun, personal perks for each of the people who give to the campaign.

The Impact

This is the last chance for many of us to work together before graduation.  Many of those who will be in the cast will be moving on to pursue professional performance opportunities or furthering their education.  I will be using this show in my portfolio for grad school applications so I would love for it to look as amazing as the talent that will be in it.  I am passionate about theater and the impact it can have on the cast and crew, as well as on the audience.  The story of "The Diviners" is a beautiful and tragic one that I feel will have the ability to stretch the performers as well as move our audience.  Help us tell this story!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you personally cannot contribute financially, help us spread the word!  Share this link with everyone you know.  And if you are in the local area, come see the show next spring!
